XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: ‘Walk a day in my shoes’ Program
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.32 am): People like Rhonda Miller are part of the vital pulse of our capital city. Rhonda is part of a team of close to 5,000 people who work within what amounts to a small city within our city--the Princess Alexandra Hospital--at a time when the great majority of us are tucked up in our beds with work the furthest thing from our minds.

Rhonda is a wards person working the graveyard shift at the PA, and has been doing so for close to 30 years. Last Thursday night I clocked on with Rhonda for her 11 pm to 7 am shift, as we commenced our government’s new program, ‘Walk a day in my shoes’, which will give each and every one of us on this side of the House the opportunity to connect with working people within our individual communities by actually going to work with them and performing their jobs alongside them.

This is not a program that simply involves tagging along and observing; it is a program that involves getting down in the trenches and doing the jobs that millions of Queenslanders undertake each and every day, as I found out last Thursday. This is about going to the coalface and carrying out those jobs that keep our cities and our towns and our regional communities moving along--those critical jobs that are often the unseen lifeblood of those communities.

Over the coming months people can expect to see our government’s ministers and members getting out and about performing a variety of these jobs. They will see them walk a day in the shoes of shop assistants, abattoir workers, restaurant waiters, teachers aides, roadside traffic controllers--across the gamut of workplaces that they intend to visit.

Not only was it a fascinating and eye-opening experience to walk a night in the shoes of Rhonda Miller, it was also a privilege. There is nothing quite so valuable as experience, and Rhonda has it in spades. As I said, she has worked at the PA for 28 years as a wardie and it shows. It shows not only in the fact that she knows every inch of this major hospital--and indeed seems to be on first name terms with most of its staff members--but it shows in the dignified, caring, dedicated way in which she goes about what can be at times a difficult and confronting job. Rhonda and her work partner, Mark, do the rounds of the hospital in the emergency department, intensive care as well as the PA’s rehabilitation wards.

As I worked alongside them last Thursday night I quickly came to realise how hardworking this pair and their colleagues are and how hard their work can be. I also came away with a renewed appreciation for people like Rhonda and Mark and their team who keep public facilities like the PA working around the clock while the city around them sleeps.

I also had the opportunity to talk with nurses, doctors and other hospital staff. We talked about the tough issues like payroll and asset sales but we also chewed the fat about general issues of life such as the Titans football team and adult children living at home. I thank Rhonda, her whole team and all of the staff at the PA for their very warm welcome to their workplace and for sharing their stories and experiences so generously.

Our government’s ministers and members will be walking a day in the shoes of Queensland workers across the state over coming months. I expect to undertake my next opportunity alongside a Queensland worker before the end of the month. As I said when I announced this program, I know there will be cynics and knockers. It is my experience in life that you always learn something when you take the time to walk in the shoes of another person.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts)
(9.36 am): She is without question an international superstar whose influence is such that with a single endorsement she is able to turn books into bestsellers, films into box office blockbusters and help people choose a holiday destination. So it is huge news today that Oprah Winfrey has announced that she will bring her internationally syndicated television show Down Under. I am pleased to advise the House that she will visit Queensland to film a separate television special that is destined to reach literally hundreds of millions of viewers across the globe.

This is all thanks to a unique partnership between The Oprah Winfrey Show and Tourism Australia and Tourism Queensland. It will involve the talk show host staging her show from the Sydney Opera House and visiting Queensland as part of an Australian special--Oprah’s Ultimate Australian Adventure.This is a phenomenal opportunity for Queensland--an opportunity to show millions why we are arguably the best holiday destination on the globe. As our crucial tourism industry continues to claw its way back in the fallout of the global financial crisis, this is an opportunity for a massive boost in international visitors to our state.

This project began last year when Ben Southall--the winner of our phenomenally successful Best Job in the World competition--appeared on The Oprah Winfrey Show in a live cross from the Great Barrier Reef. Ben spoke about his Queensland adventures and invited Oprah and her viewers to come and visit. We are thrilled that Oprah Winfrey has taken up the invitation to visit Queensland.

Regardless of the future benefits that Oprah Winfrey’s international broadcast will bring, her visit will be in itself a big boost for our tourism industry. Ms Winfrey will bring 300 of her most loyal viewers on her eight-day, seven-night trip to Australia, including Queensland. The details are yet to be finalised, but the Queensland episode is likely to be filmed in Cairns and on the Great Barrier Reef. In fact during Ms Winfrey’s promotion of this project on her show yesterday she featured footage of the Great Barrier Reef. That is now showing on the Today program.

The Oprah Winfrey Show is seen by more than 40 million US viewers every single week. It is broadcast in 145 other countries, picking up many tens of millions more. Additionally, Oprah Winfrey has 2.3 million Facebook fans and holds the No. 8 ranking on Twitter worldwide, with 4.1 million followers.

Once details are confirmed, Tourism Queensland will work with Tourism Australia and other partners to develop Queensland packages that mirror the destinations and experiences featured in the show so that viewers can have their own Oprah Queensland experience and adventure. As I mentioned, Oprah Winfrey with such innovations as her Oprah’s Book Club has the capacity to influence what people read, what they pay to see at the cinemas and where they choose to go on holiday. Her enormous influence and reach across the globe is a great shot in the arm to our tourism industry, particularly in Far North Queensland, when it needs it most. I congratulate everybody, particularly Tourism Queensland and the Minister for Tourism, Peter Lawlor, for their involvement in pulling off this major logistical exercise.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Queensland Asbestos Related Disease Support Society
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.40 am): The impact of asbestos on the lives of Queenslanders living with asbestos related disease is both painful and, for many, devastating. Asbestos and mesothelioma are diseases that are on the rise nation-wide and, on current estimates, are unlikely to peak until 2020. As many members of the House will be aware, mesothelioma, for example, can carry between a 10- and 70-year lag time and on average will not manifest itself until 40 or 50 years after contact with the asbestos product. In the 10-year period from 1998 to 2008 over 1,000 Australians were hospitalised with asbestos, and the rate of diagnosis continues to grow. In the last two decades the rate of Queenslanders diagnosed with mesothelioma has almost tripled. That is why I am very pleased to announce today that our government has approved through the Minister for Health an allocation of $533,000 in funding over the next three years to the Queensland Asbestos Related Disease Support Society.

This funding through Queensland Health will enable the society to employ a full-time social worker and two support workers to provide a level of service continuity and support to people who are affected by these diseases and their families. I am sure many members on both sides of the House will be aware of the very good work that is done by the Queensland Asbestos Related Disease Support Society. It is a not-for-profit organisation founded in 1992 to support people affected by asbestos related diseases and their families. The society has for nearly two decades provided support to hundreds of people and the more than a thousand members who rely on it. Sadly, since its founding year, more than 300 members have died from asbestos related disease, but for every one of those members the support provided by the society has been invaluable. This society helps its members feel less socially isolated and offers emotional support as members deal with common issues like ensuring a future for their wives, their husbands and their children while they battle with conditions which are both life limiting and terminal.

It is our hope that this funding will enable this great organisation to expand the great work that it does and the support that it provides to asbestos disease sufferers throughout Queensland. I would like to acknowledge the many volunteers who work for the society, but in particular I note the great work and leadership of Helen and Ray Colbert, the president and secretary of the association, who I am reliably informed are one of the finest husband and wife leadership teams Queensland has. I also want to particularly thank and acknowledge the member for Bulimba, Di Farmer, and the member for Waterford, Evan Moorhead, who have championed the work of the society and advocated on behalf of its members for this support to continue to provide the important services it delivers. Well done! It is the support provided by people like the dedicated volunteers at the Queensland Asbestos Related Disease Support Society that fosters the optimism that Queenslanders carry with them each and every day.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.43 am): It is with delight that I congratulate the Gold Coast Titans on winning their first finals series game in what can only be described as a physically and emotionally tough encounter in front of a packed Skilled Park last Friday night. The Titans will now host a preliminary final at Suncorp Stadium on Friday, 24 September. Titans fans travelling from the Gold Coast for the game will be able to catch one of three additional express services scheduled specifically for the game. Two additional services will leave Varsity Lakes at 4.30 pm and 5.15 and run express from Beenleigh to Milton and an additional service will leave Varsity Lakes at 5.45 and run express from Robina to Milton. All other scheduled Friday evening trains will run as normal on the night and there will be three additional return services back to the Gold Coast after the game.

This is a significant boost to the Gold Coast to Brisbane service, and for game fans we hope it will make all the difference in getting to the stadium on time. Queensland Rail will be showing its support for this great Queensland team by decorating the trains’ interiors in Titans colours and I encourage all Gold Coast fans to come to the match and of course to get on board and come by Queensland Rail. I urge all Queenslanders, no matter what team they generally support, to get behind the Titans for this historic match. As that great Broncos supporter the Treasurer of Queensland said to me, ‘We’re all September Titans now.’ As we have seen with previous Broncos premierships and regular State of Origin games, when Queensland gets behind a team we give them the competitive advantage on the field. There is nothing like a hometown crowd to spur a team on and get them over the line, and that is what we all look forward to on 24 September.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Sunshine Coast and Maryborough, Health Services
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (9.45 am): Regrettably, Ashgrove GPS in which Jens Springborg played on the weekend beat the Wynnum fibros in which Mike Lucas and Jack O’Sullivan, my nephew and the nephew of the LNP Treasurer, also played. The Ashgrove silvertails beat the Wynnum fibros, but it was a good game anyway. Both fathers were very proud of their sons playing.

Last week I had the opportunity to visit both the Fraser Coast and Sunshine Coast to announce a boost in services and a more localised focus in the delivery of services. In November last year I committed to a review of Fraser Coast health services. This review confirmed that the Fraser Coast’s rapidly growing and ageing population means renal services are a core priority for the community. This issue was first highlighted by the member for Maryborough, and I thank him for his continued advocacy on behalf of his community. I gave my commitment to have a snapshot review into services, particularly at Maryborough Hospital.

There has been a lot of scaremongering around the future of Maryborough Hospital. I have put it on the record before and let me put it on the record again: the Maryborough Hospital has a solid future on the Fraser Coast. That is why last Friday I was pleased to announce a new $3 million satellite renal unit at Maryborough Hospital. This will deliver a six-chair renal unit to the Maryborough Hospital and means that Fraser Coast residents will be able to receive their dialysis at Maryborough or Hervey Bay hospitals from mid next year. Further, I was pleased to announce that Maryborough Hospital will become the centre for first-class rehabilitation and subacute care. A new $1.8 million, 22-bed rehabilitation unit at Maryborough Hospital will not only provide first-class services for those patients requiring care but will also free up acute beds at Maryborough and Hervey Bay hospitals for patients who need an acute bed in hospital.

This was further reinforced through the review, which outlined Hervey Bay Hospital would continue to provide the majority of acute services for the Fraser Coast while Maryborough Hospital will be developed and enhanced to provide the majority of elective day surgery and become a rehabilitation hub. This means some services, such as the intensive care unit, maternity services, paediatrics and neonatal care, will continue to function from Hervey Bay Hospital and it means the Maryborough Hospital has a very important future in the development of safe and sustainable health services on the Fraser Coast. Today you would not build two hospitals there, but they are there. Taxpayers’ dollars are tied up in them and I want to give them both a meaningful role. The review also highlights the development of a new $8 million, 13-chair oral health facility to be built near the Hervey Bay Hospital, more than doubling the capacity of the current six-chair facility. There is also the $4.27 million pathology lab planned for the Hervey Bay Hospital which is expected to be completed mid-2011.

As part of my visit I was also pleased to announce that from 1 November this year the Sunshine Coast and Wide Bay health service districts will commence operation as individual districts--a further sign of our commitment to regional Queenslanders. These will be locally run by a CEO and senior clinicians who will be solely focused on local Sunshine Coast and Wide Bay health services. No longer will these growing regions have to share a district CEO. I am pleased that Sunshine Coast-Wide Bay CEO Kevin Hegarty will stay on as CEO for the Sunshine Coast. Mr Hegarty’s focus will now be on driving the expansion of health services on the Sunshine Coast and the new $1.97 billion Sunshine Coast University Hospital in one of Queensland’s fastest growing regions. It also means our Wide-Bay CEO, whom we are in the process of recruiting, will be able to focus on the expansion of health services in Wide-Bay--for example, the $45 million Bundaberg Hospital expansion and the new services at Maryborough. What is more, the new district structure matches our and federal Labor’s commitment to localising health service delivery. The Hervey Bay and Maryborough hospitals--half an hour apart--work closely to provide the community with a broad spectrum of care for a growing and ageing population.

Queensland is the most decentralised state in Australia. We have over 150 hospitals spread across an area six times the size of Victoria. The importance of our hospitals working together as networks to ensure that all Queenslanders have access to high-level health care cannot be understated. That is why initiatives such as the national broadband network are so important--to ensure that we can continue to provide our nation-leading telehealth program. As well, investing in training more rural and regional specialists and GPs and investing in rural and regional hospitals is vital because, more than any other state, Queensland is a story of regions. That is why the Bligh government is committed to securing their future.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (9.49 am): At the last election we said we stood for building a stronger economy and creating Queensland jobs. We stood up for jobs, not job cuts, and that is exactly what we are delivering. The ABS labour force data for August, released last Thursday, showed job creation in Queensland for the 13th straight month. We are now more than halfway towards meeting our commitment to delivering 100,000 net new jobs and we are still less than halfway through the term.

However, it should not go unnoticed that the August figures reveal a more subdued labour market than in recent months. This softness, however, remains in line with Treasury’s budget forecast of a year-average unemployment rate for 2010-11 of 5 per cent. In those figures is a message that we must not turn away from: that the recovery is not complete and that the challenges still remain. It is a reality other economies are experiencing. Over the weekend the OECD forecast that growth across the G7 would slow down to 1.5 per cent in annualised terms for the second half of the year.

The resilience of the Australian economy, and Queensland within it, continues to defy the forces crippling other developed economies. That does not mean that we should down tools and stop working to protect the jobs of those in the workforce and create new ones for those who are trying to break into the workforce. Our plan is to build a stronger economy and deliver jobs, just like we said we would. However, critical to our economic plan is delivering our reforms of the state’s balance sheet. That process is well underway.

In June this year, the government completed the Forestry Plantations Queensland transaction at value for $603 million. We are in the binding bids phase for the Port of Brisbane, where a number of consortia are in the data room and we are on track to complete by the end of the year. Preparations for the initial public offering of QR National remain on track. The government is in a position to begin preregistration by the end of the month, paving the way for a float later this year.

The public float of a vertically integrated QR National has long been the government’s preferred sale model. Providing for an integrated above-rail and below-rail company--keeping the coal track with the trains--will build a stronger, more efficient and truly great national company headquartered here in Queensland. It is the best result for the workers who helped build QR--a strong company with a strong balance sheet to grow into the future. The listed QR National will hold a lease for 2,300 kilometres of coal track, with 7,800 kilometres of the track, including the suburban network, the regional network and the north coast line all remaining in the publicly owned Queensland Rail. QR National will obviously utilise the north coast line between Rockhampton and Gladstone under arrangement with the publicly owned Queensland Rail, which will see it responsible for the maintenance and upgrades of this part of the network.

Vertical integration--keeping the tracks with the trains--is the model pursued by the class 1 railways of North America. It is the model that is utilised by many of the world’s largest resource companies both around the world and in other parts of Australia. QR has been a vertically integrated company throughout its history and, in this next chapter of its future, will continue as a vertically integrated entity.

I acknowledge that some do not support integration. Members will recall that in May a group of coal companies sent the government a letter which outlined an unsolicited, non-binding offer to purchase the Central Queensland coal network, that is, the coal tracks. The government said that it would engage with the coal companies constructively and in a genuine process. That is exactly what we did and that is exactly what the coal companies have acknowledged, both on the public record and in my subsequent discussions with them.

Between May and September, the state spent a significant amount of time and resources working with the consortium. For the record of the House, in July the state and the consortium agreed on a deadline of 31 August for the consortium to lodge a non-conditional, binding bid for the tracks. The state subsequently agreed to extend that deadline to 10 September at the request of the coal company group. This included a month of due diligence, in which the state formally answered over 350 questions put to it by the consortium in the data room. For the record of the House, on 9 September the consortium chairman, Mr Nick Greiner, telephoned me to advise that the consortium was not in a position to lodge a binding bid. The issues around the position of the consortium are now a matter of public record. The government and industry have reconfirmed their commitment to an open, competitive and efficient export supply chain from mine to port.

Improving operational and investment efficiency is good for our mining companies, good for jobs in regional Queensland and good for the state’s and, indeed, the nation’s economy. Our plan remains exactly the same: reforms to the balance sheet, restoring our fiscal position and building a recovery--jobs, not job cuts, just like we said we would.

Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (9.53 am): The Christmas-New Year period is a special time of the year, with a number of public holidays allowing families to celebrate the birth of Jesus Christ and to spend valuable time together. The importance of this period to families is reflected in the penalty rates that apply in many occupations. For the inconvenience of being separated from their families, particularly on Christmas Day, workers have been eligible to receive extra financial reward through penalty rates. But in the past this benefit has been denied to workers when Christmas Day and New Year’s Day have fallen on a Saturday.

The Bligh Government is moving to right this wrong and will introduce legislation today to ensure that Queenslanders working on these special days and who are required to be away from their families will get the penalty rates that they deserve. The only person likely to object to workers being paid their proper entitlements on Christmas Day would be Ebenezer Scrooge himself.

The Holidays Amendment Bill 2010 will allow the government to declare extra public holidays on Christmas Day this year and New Year’s Day 2011. In adopting this position, the Queensland government will ensure that Queensland workers will be treated the same as their counterparts interstate. Workers in New South Wales and Western Australia already have this entitlement for Christmas Day 2010 while workers in New South Wales, Western Australia and Victoria will receive it on New Year’s Day 2011.

This move is good news for those seven-day occupations where workers have to work over the Christmas-New Year period. This includes many health workers, firefighters and ambulance officers who sacrifice so much of their family lives for their communities. These changes will also benefit the hotel and hospitality workers who work at numerous Christmas Day functions throughout the state, bus and train drivers who provide public transport, staff at fast-food outlets and even workers at suburban medical centres.

In a busy world, when so many people are trying to balance work and family commitments, it is important to ensure that families are given the opportunity to spend important occasions such as Christmas Day and New Year’s Day together. This decision, which has been well received by the unions and Queensland workers, corrects a substantial inequity in our public holiday regime and ensures that workers in Queensland will have the same entitlements as their interstate counterparts over the Christmas-New Year holiday period.

Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (9.54 am): On Saturday mornings on radio 4BC a small program called the Real Estate Show is broadcast from Brisbane. I do not know what sort of real estate agent its host, Kevin Turner, is but as a shock jock he is a pretty poor excuse. For some time now Mr Turner has delighted in--
Mr Messenger: He’s getting under your skin, Robbie.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I take the interjection from the imbecile up the back, Mr Speaker.
Mr Messenger: You don’t like what he has to say.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Minister, that is unparliamentary. You will withdraw that.
Mr SCHWARTEN: Sorry, Mr Speaker. I forgot that telling the truth is unparliamentary. I apologise, Mr Speaker.
Mr Messenger: Why don’t you go on the show?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member for Burnett. You have had the protection.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I note that the honourable member has featured on the program on a number of occasions, which gives evidence to like minds attracting one another.

For some time now, Mr Turner has delighted in running a weekly attack on the Building Services Authority, its staff and me. Unfortunately, Mr Turner went far too far on Saturday, 4 September, when he said that 4BC should run a campaign telling people not to use tradespeople licensed by the BSA. I take it that the member for Burnett supports that view.
Mr Messenger: You have a glass jaw, Robbie.
Mr SCHWARTEN: For the record, the member for Burnett does support dealing with unlicensed builders.
Mr MESSENGER: I rise to a point of order. I find those words offensive, untrue and I ask that they be withdrawn.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member has claimed that he is offended by the minister’s remarks.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I withdraw, but I will let the statements speak for themselves.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member for Burnett, you have had your go. No more.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Mr Turner is recommending that home builders employ unlicensed tradespeople and he is encouraging unlicensed tradespeople to accept work and break the law--and endorsed again by the member for Burnett on his program. This advice could cost people their life savings. I cannot imagine a more irresponsible and plainly idiotic thing to tell listeners of a real estate show.

Mr Turner is putting his listeners in a potentially ruinous financial situation. Homeowners who use an unlicensed contractor have no idea of the contractor’s qualifications, experience and financial stability. They have no way of checking the contractor’s work history and, more importantly, they cannot benefit from the BSA Home Warranty Insurance Scheme which is the best scheme of its type in Australia and, as far as I am concerned, in the world.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!

Mr SCHWARTEN: I take that endorsement from both sides of the parliament. I particularly want to thank the shadow minister who went on that program recently and did not agree with those sentiments at all or the sentiments of Mr Turner in calling the BSA corrupt. In Queensland anyone doing building work worth $3,300 or more is breaking the law if they are not appropriately licensed by the BSA. I have written to 4BC requesting that it repudiate Mr Turner’s very reckless and unprofessional comments of 4 August. I note that builders in Queensland advertise on 4BC and I would suggest to builders that they review their advertising package in light of what 4BC seems to have as its official policy, which is that unlicensed builders are the best people to deal with in Queensland. If I was a licensed builder I certainly would not be advertising on 4BC.

I have also demanded that Mr Turner set the record straight and apologise to homeowners, tradespeople and the BSA. The BSA takes the job of protecting homeowners very seriously. I am, and I know the shadow minister is, cooperating with the inquiry being undertaken by KPMG. Every piece of legislation in this parliament dealing with building regulation has enjoyed bipartisan support. Of course, we can always do better. That is why we are having a review. To suggest that people not deal with a licensed contractor is brainless and highly dangerous to the economy of Queensland and to the building industry as well. I call on Mr Turner and his mate Nick Newton, who apparently is a licensed builder, to apologise to people they have put on the wrong track.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (10.01 am): The Bligh government is building on its commitment to make Queensland the greenfield exploration capital of Australia by 2020. That is why the Bligh government is focused on the future as we continue to provide tangible support to the resource industry and to their exploration efforts. We are investing $18 million through our Greenfields 2020 program to encourage exploration in frontier and under-explored regions of the state. We are also investing $12.5 million in streamlining initiatives to help industry projects through government approval and regulatory processes and a further $10.7 million on upgrading tenure management systems.

These initiatives have produced extraordinary results. I am pleased to report today that during 2009-10 Queensland attracted a record exploration investment of $917.1 million. That is a massive 43 per cent increase on the 2008-09 figure of $639.9 million. Exploration expenditure in the minerals sector, including coal, increased 24 per cent from $351.7 million to $436.6 million in 2009-10. It is interesting to note that Queensland’s mineral exploration expenditure was greater than the combined total of $402 million invested in New South Wales, South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania. During 2009-10 Queensland’s petroleum and gas exploration investment jumped 66 per cent from $288.2 million in 2008-09 to $480.5 million. This represents 60 per cent of the total Australian onshore petroleum expenditure and clearly reflects the intense exploration activity in the search for coal seam gas.

Queensland’s performance clearly shows that the exploration industry recognises our potential for further mineral and energy discoveries and underpins our reputation as an attractive exploration investment destination. It also reflects the outstanding success of the Bligh government’s $49 million Smart Mining--Future Prosperity and Smart Exploration programs. In fact, exploration expenditure in Queensland during the life of these programs increased from $244 million in 2004 to the present $917 million. That well and truly delivers on our 2006 election commitment to double exploration expenditure to $540 million by 2009.

A healthy exploration sector means a healthy economy, regional development and, most importantly, jobs. Strong and resilient mining and energy sectors are the backbone of jobs creation and Queensland’s ongoing economic prosperity. Mines have finite lifespans and the government is focused on the future as we rise to the challenge of unearthing new mineral and energy deposits that will deliver new projects and jobs to replace existing mines as they close. Put simply, today’s exploration means tomorrow’s mines and jobs.

Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability)
(10.04 am): Over the past 18 months the Bligh government has taken real action to invest in Queensland’s future and safeguard our state against the impacts of climate change. Our primary producers in rural Queensland are on the front line of our response to climate change and that is why we have been working closely with them to implement more sustainable industry practices and protect our environment. We know it takes innovative solutions to combat the challenges of climate change and that is why we are delivering substantial funding to help landholders implement such solutions through the Rural Water Use Efficiency Initiative.

Today I am pleased to announce the recipients of the next round of $4.5 million in funding under this program. This funding will help irrigators in rural Queensland improve on water conservation and energy efficiency and prepare for the challenges that lie ahead. Peak industry groups working closely with irrigators will be sharing in this funding, with grants awarded to Queensland Dairy Farmers, Growcom, Canegrowers, the cotton industry, Nursery and Garden Industry Queensland, Queensland Turf Producers Association and the Flower Association of Queensland.

I am advised that through the first four years of this program we have delivered savings of 150,000 megalitres of water a year and achieved $280 million in improved profitability in irrigated agriculture. We want to see these results continue, particularly in the area of energy efficiency, which is why we are extending this program to 2013. Peak bodies receiving funding will be able to directly assist farmers through workshops and programs, providing practical information on the ground with new technologies that they can introduce onto their properties to save money, energy and water. Grants of between $290,000 and $1.7 million will be provided to the groups so they can deliver this assistance on the ground. Irrigators taking part in the program will be able to improve their water efficiency by up to 10 per cent and energy efficiency by up to 20 per cent.

This initiative is a vital component of the Bligh government’s climate change strategy, ClimateQ: Toward a Greener Queensland. We developed this strategy because we know Queensland needs a plan for the future, one that addresses the modern challenges that our state faces.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training)
(10.06 am): NAPLAN results are one of the many tools used to assess the educational progress of young Queenslanders. I am pleased to advise the House that this year’s test results show that Queensland is continuing to close the gap between other states. NAPLAN is a diagnostic tool that allows parents, teachers and government to ensure students and schools are being supported where they need it most. There has never been a level playing field when it comes to education in Australia. Every state and territory is taught differently with different curriculum and deals with state-specific educational issues and challenges. The Labor government is, however, committed to fixing this on a state and national level.

The Gillard Labor government is doing what the Howard Liberal National Party government put in the too-hard basket for more than a decade: introducing a national curriculum. On a state level, the Bligh Labor government has delivered more than 6,000 extra teachers over the last 10 years, it is investing more than $10 million a day with the federal government in new school infrastructure, it is delivering $320 million in up to 240 new kindergarten services throughout Queensland over the next five years and it is supporting early childhood literacy through programs such as Books for Bubs and Queensland Ready Readers.

I was extremely disappointed to see the member for Surfers Paradise had not reviewed the NAPLAN data when he promptly fronted the media attacking teachers and parents last Friday. If he had read the data he would have congratulated teachers for helping ensure Queensland students were improving at a faster rate than any other state in Australia. I will repeat that: if he had read the data he would have congratulated teachers for helping ensure Queensland students were improving at a faster rate than any other state in Australia. He would also have acknowledged that every state is achieving an average of 90 per cent of students at or above the national benchmark including Queensland. But he cannot even cobble together an education policy so why should we be surprised.

Many members here today received an education in Queensland private and state schools from our many wonderful and hardworking teachers. I ask the member for Surfers Paradise to shelve his dislike for Queensland state schools and teachers, join the quiet revolution and celebrate the great work that is being done by our students and teachers throughout all of Queensland. Through our world-leading education reforms, the Bligh government is giving every young Queenslander a flying start to learning and life.

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.09 am): During the last parliamentary sitting, the member for Mulgrave drew to my attention serious allegations of inappropriate behaviour at the Innisfail work camp. The allegations were made through local media outlets by a former inmate of Queensland Corrective Services. Queensland Corrective Services responded swiftly to these allegations by temporarily closing the work camp and returning all prisoners to the high-security prison at Lotus Glen. The Chief Inspector of Prisons immediately commenced an investigation into the allegations and I am pleased to inform the House of its preliminary findings. To date, the investigation has not found any evidence to support the allegations of serious misconduct or criminal activity.

One allegation was that prisoners at the camp were using illegal drugs. Queensland Corrective Services testing reveals that, of the 154 urine tests and 252 breath tests carried out at Innisfail work camp since 1 July 2009, all returned a negative reading. Additionally, and following the temporary closure of the camp, a search of the work camp site was undertaken by the QCS Dog Squad and no prohibited items were found. Another allegation suggested that prisoners were unsupervised when doing their weekly shopping and on ‘outings’ and when driving the prison bus. The investigation to date has found that weekly shopping and outings have been undertaken under the supervision of QCS officers and that the work camp bus is driven by the camp supervisor.

The investigation has also found that offenders do not have access to pay TV and nor do they order in pizza from an external pizza company, as was claimed. Despite these preliminary findings, the Innisfail work camp will remain temporarily closed pending the final outcome of the Chief Inspector’s report of the investigation.

Prison work camps are an important element of Queensland Corrective Services’s endeavours to rehabilitate offenders and they also make a valuable contribution to many Queensland communities. Last financial year, work camps contributed around $2.2 million worth of labour to regional communities through the performance of more than 110,000 hours of community service. It is important, however, that these work camps are appropriately managed and that the community has confidence in the security measures and management provided by Queensland Corrective Services.

All of the allegations made in relation to the Innisfail work camp will be thoroughly investigated and the camp will not reopen until QCS is confident that it has addressed any matters which require attention.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (10.11 am): Today I am pleased to announce the membership of the new Australian Agricultural College Corporation Board. The AACC board consists of an impressive membership of appointees who will lead the corporation into the 21st century by providing agricultural career paths in the bush. The high calibre of appointees whom the board has attracted is an example of how important education and training in regional and rural Queensland is to the Bligh government. This is representative of the Australian Agricultural College reforms, which we announced in April, coming to fruition.

By expanding the delivery sites of the college from five to 14, we responded to industry and training needs in rural Queensland to be able to provide the skills and education needed for the future growth in primary industries. The announcement of a state-wide corporation board will secure the financial and strategic direction of the colleges into the future. The state-wide board will also be provided with on-the-ground local understanding of issues affecting producers from industry advisory committees.

The board appointees bring a wide range of expertise, including finance and banking, links to academia and rural training networks and research and development experience in grains, beef, cotton and sugar. Chair of the AACC board, Graham Hart is the former Chief Executive officer of the Bank of Queensland and has solid agricultural and business networks. Deputy Chair Mary Corbett brings high-level strategic experience in the agricultural sector and has practical educational experience in cotton and sugar research and development. Mr Chris Bazley brings solid industry networks and important linkages to the University of Queensland Gatton campus. Ms Prudence Bonfield has extensive experience in the role of training employers and employees. Mrs Sharyn Gordon is currently the State General Manager, Regional Queensland of Westpac Banking Corporation and in this role spends a significant portion of her time in rural communities across Queensland. Ms Jo Sheppard is currently Mayor of Paroo shire and through her work as a rural consultant has great networks in training and rural industries. Mr Michael Smith has experience in running large and complex agricultural enterprises through his role as General Manager, Bundaberg Farms, Bundaberg Sugar Limited.
It is an impressive board and the successful candidates will provide excellent leadership for the college to provide relevant agricultural training and education into the 21st century.

Hon. D BOYLE (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (10.14 am): These are difficult times for local government--facing growth pressures, rolling out infrastructure, implementing higher standards of financial management and suffering impacts from the global financial crisis. As the saying goes, when the going gets tough, the tough get going, and I have to say that this applies to Queensland’s councils. In these tough times councils are innovating.

One example of this is at the Torres Strait Island Regional Council, which had arguably the most difficult amalgamation of all. Fifteen island councils, spread over a huge ocean landscape remote from the centres of power, have combined into one. The TSIRC under the leadership of Mayor Fred Gela has embraced the opportunities of information and communications technology for his council and for the benefit of the people of the Torres Strait. Bringing faster broadband services to the Torres Strait is a major project, with council signing a contract with Telstra to build high-capacity microwave links and upgrade exchanges. My department is providing $3 million in already allocated funding to support council’s new ICT platform. The benefits of information technology for remote communities, separated by sea at the northernmost points of Australia, are nowhere near as important as they are there.
Mr Hobbs interjected.

Ms BOYLE: De-amalgamate the Torres Strait. That is the scandal of your policy. Members would guess, too, at how difficult it is in these geographic circumstances--and how costly for the council--to hold full council meetings every month. Today I am pleased to announce that I have signed off on the TSIRC’s request for permission to hold some council meetings by videoconference and teleconference. Some flexibility in the meeting requirements along with innovative use of videoconferencing and internet streaming is to be allowed in the interests of improving the council’s accessibility for all Torres Strait Islanders and at the same time generating significant savings to the council budget. While council has been rotating meetings between islands to share the load and give residents better representation, the costs of boats, flights and accommodation for meetings is in the order of $50,000 per meeting. How amazing it will be for the proceedings of the TSIRC meetings to instead be available in real time over the internet.

I pass on my congratulations to the council. This has been made possible by the contribution of the Bligh government and we can surely claim that this is a great example of innovation in the Smart State.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill
XML.LegAssembly: Ministerial & Or Office ... Bill; Integrity Reform ... Bill; Public Interest ... Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.17 am), by leave, without notice: I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That, in accordance with standing order 129, the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill, the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and the Public Interest Disclosure Bill be treated as cognate bills for their remaining stages, as follows:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) separate questions being put in regard to the second reading of each bill;
(b) the consideration of the bills in detail together; and
(c) separate questions being put for the third readings and long titles of each bill.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Speaker, as you know, it is a well-established practice in the Westminster system of government for similar bills to be dealt with as a cognate debate. It is also an efficient way of managing the business of the House. That is why I have moved this motion today.

The Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill, the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and the Public Interest Disclosure Bill implement the second stage of legislative reform as outlined in the November 2009 Response to Integrity and accountability in Queensland. The government has committed to implementing these reforms by mid 2010 and remains committed to the timely implementation of these reforms.

These integrity reform bills implement a comprehensive package to strengthen Queensland’s integrity and accountability framework. The bills implement significant improvements to the public sector employment and management framework, including establishing a new, discrete framework for the employment of ministerial and opposition staff; reforming the ethical principles which apply to public sector employees; and further extending the post-separation disciplinary regime across the public service.

The bills also modernise and enhance Queensland’s legislative framework to support a strong ethical culture by providing protection for those in the public sector who do the right thing and stand up to wrongdoing. Together, these bills implement a coordinated program of reform that ensures that Queensland has a robust integrity system supported by a public sector culture that emphasises strong leadership and a conscious dedication to ethical values. The three bills deal with related issues and have been developed simultaneously to facilitate a coordinated transition to the significantly improved public sector governance framework that the government committed to implement through its integrity reform process.

Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (10.18 am): The opposition is always cautious about cognate debates in this House, especially in a case such as this where it is proposed to debate cognately three separate pieces of legislation. However, the opposition has looked closely at the three bills. We have considered the proposition just outlined by the Leader of the House that the bills taken together constitute a program of reform that the government wishes to implement. Given that the cognate debate will allow each of the bills to be considered at the end of the second reading debate through a separate question, we have concluded that this is an appropriate move to facilitate the business of the House. We will be supporting the government’s motion for a cognate debate on these bills.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (10.19 am): I strongly oppose the motion before the parliament to debate cognately these three pieces of legislation. With a unicameral parliament, that is, no upper house, structurally Queensland has the least accountable government in Australia. Practically speaking, we have the most unpopular government in Australia. The main reason for that, apart from a crying lack of talent from those opposite and it appears from those on this side as well, is because there has not been a chance to properly scrutinise or consider government decision making and legislation. Ironically, the government is presenting as a legislative package bills that will allegedly strengthen integrity reform, but is doing so in a manner that fundamentally undermines the principle of integrity. Each of these bills deserves to be debated separately.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Honourable member, you are debating the bill. I ask you to debate the matter before the House.

Mr MESSENGER: I question why these bills have to be rushed through this parliament in a cognate debate. If we do not have enough hours of parliament, let us increase the number of days that parliament sits. Let us work on Fridays, instead of finishing parliament on Thursdays. Making this a cognate debate is nothing more than a half-smart political trick designed to reduce the speaking list and, therefore, reduce the amount of time that the Premier has to spend in this chamber.

Yesterday when I looked at the daily Notice Paper this legislation was ranked fourth, fifth and sixth behind disaster management, building and education legislation. This government is saying that education and training are not as important as the ability of the Premier to hire ministerial staffers. I think differently. Disaster management legislation should be completed before ministerial and other staff bills. Cyclone season is fast approaching. The sooner disaster management plans are in place, the sooner children, women, the sick, elderly and disabled will be better protected. I oppose this government motion. I urge the LNP to show some courage, fight for regional and rural constituents and grow a backbone. I urge them to stop being Labor light and oppose this political bullyboy.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (10.22 am): I join the member for Burnett in opposing the cognating of these three bills. In my view, these are three separate bills that deal with separate subject matters. One bill deals with the employment of ministerial staff, members of the opposition staff and members of the crossbenches staff. There are totally different terms of reference in terms of employment. Another bill extends disciplinary proceedings to public servants. Certainly I have had recent experience with public servants who have been dealt with very assertively by middle management to the extent that I believe that some middle managers are--to use the topical word--bullying junior staff. I believe that the three bills deal with separate matters. It is worthwhile that the parliament debates the three bills separately.

Mr McLINDON (Beaudesert--Ind) (10.22 am): The problem is that we need parliamentary reform. If we had shorter speeches, obviously we could treat each of these bills separately. As the Leader of the House has suggested in the past, in this place there is a lot of hot air, repetition and irrelevance. Given the significance of the need for integrity reform, in this place speeches are far too long. If we shortened them through parliamentary reform, we could deal with these pieces of legislation one at a time. I will oppose this motion. I hope that the opposition can slow the legislation down, because in Queensland people need less regulation and more innovation. We need to look at these pieces of legislation one at a time and give them the warranted time that they need to ensure that the best decisions are made in relation to these bills.

Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.23 am): As I have pointed out, in Westminster tradition it is quite common to cognate similar bills. This week the government wants to pass these three bills. We also want to get through another three bills that are on the Notice Paper , so we have a very big legislative agenda this week. I make the point that there is no intention to stifle debate on these bills or the other three bills that we intend to pass through the parliament this week. Everyone will have an opportunity to speak. In the past I have been critical of the workings of this parliament and, particularly, the opposition’s attitude to the workings of the parliament. Today I am pleased to say that in the past six months we have had a better working relationship with the opposition--
Opposition members interjected.
Ms SPENCE: Credit where it is due.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting.

Ms SPENCE: Credit where it is due, Mr Speaker. As a result of this new level of cooperation, we have not had to guillotine debates and we have had some sensible sitting hours. People have still been able to participate in debates. The fact that today the opposition is taking this sensible course of action in supporting the cognating of the three bills shows that we can work together to make sure that the parliament works very effectively. It is very disappointing to see that the Independents do not want to work with the rest of us to make this parliament work effectively. In fact, I have to say that sometimes the attendance in this parliament of some members of the Independent team is quite ordinary, particularly late at night and on Thursday afternoons, when the rest us are here, sometimes into the late hours of the night, debating and voting on bills. I will not take up too much of the time of the House today. I am happy to conclude there.

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr NICHOLLS (Clayfield--LNP) (10.35 am): As acting chair of the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee for this matter, I table report No. 110, Matter of privilege referred by the Speaker on 11 June 2010 relating to the discharge of a member from a parliamentary committee . I commend the report and the committee’s recommendations to the House.

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (10.35 am): I give notice that I will move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House notes that:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. A Bundaberg businessman John Greenalsh, who pleaded guilty to two charges of sexually assaulting a teenage boy was given 10 month’s probation, a two-month suspended prison sentence and ordered to pay $500 compensation to his victim.
2. Greenalsh was not placed on the sex offender register.

3. The parents of the victim are reported as saying that ‘Greenalsh had shattered the entire family, called the sentence a slap on the wrist and we have been 100% completely failed by the justice system’.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And calls on the Attorney-General to appeal the sentence against Greenalsh, and support a parliamentary committee study which is commissioned to examine the sentencing of child sex offenders for the last 5 years, in order to determine if those penalties are in keeping with community expectations and standards.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr McLINDON (Beaudesert--Ind) (10.36 am): I give notice that I will move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House calls on the Government to undertake genuine parliamentary reform through the following proposals:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. In question time, Government members are restricted from asking the Government questions.
2. That answers for questions without notice be limited to two minutes.
3. That 15 questions be allocated for the opposition to the government.
4. That 5 questions be allocated for the government to the opposition.
5. That members’ speeches to legislation are limited to 10 minutes.
6. That adjournment speeches commence at 6.30 pm for one hour in order to allow every member to be allocated an adjournment speech at each parliamentary sitting.
7. That the House adjourns at 7.30 pm.
8. That a vote not less than two thirds of the parliament be recorded to enact the guillotine on any legislation.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Today we will be visited by students and teachers from Woodridge North State School in the electorate of Woodridge, Agnew School in the electorate of Nicklin and Biggera Waters State School in the electorate of Broadwater.
Mr SPEAKER: Question time will end at 11.37 am.

Mr LANGBROEK (10.37 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. I refer to the Premier’s recent state of the state address where she was asked what she would have done differently in relation to Labor’s secret agenda to privatise and sell off assets such as Queensland Rail, our ports, motorways and forests. The Premier claimed that she should have been more ‘upfront’. Will the Premier explain why she and Labor were not upfront with Queenslanders?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. As I would expect, his question often contains material in it that is simply inaccurate. Our government had no secret agenda. We had a very clear agenda that we took to the last election that the global financial crisis was seriously impacting on our economy and we would have to face some very difficult decisions as we maintained our building program and as we made jobs our No. 1 priority.

I was invited at the CEDA speech to outline what did I think was the best thing our government had done since the election in 2009. Without hesitation I said that the best thing we had done was maintain our building program, because it delivered on an election commitment. It delivered the jobs that were needed to keep the economy moving at a time when private investment was most sluggish and, most importantly, to keep regional economies moving. You can go to towns like Mackay and cities like Townsville and Cairns and the only cranes you will see on the skyline are there because of government investment, whether it is federal government or state government. It was important. It was one of our biggest election commitments, and we have delivered it.

I was then invited to say what did I think was the worst decision we had made or what would I improve if I had my time again. It is a fool who thinks that they could never learn from experience and go back and, with the value of hindsight, do something differently. I nominated the fact that I thought, because the building program was so obviously and so clearly critical to keeping jobs and keeping the economy moving, I underestimated the attachment that people would feel to some of the assets that we were selling to keep the building program going.

I have been very upfront about this. If we could go back we would talk to people more about it earlier rather than, for example, put the myths and facts document out at the end of last year, as we did. I make no apologies for being very honest at the CEDA lunch and saying, ‘Could we have done this differently or better? Of course.’ But do I regret for one minute putting our jobs program first? Absolutely not. Do I regret for one minute delivering the biggest building program in the country of any state government? Not for one minute. Do I regret the fact that families are being supported by our building program? Not for one minute.

This was the right economic strategy. It has been endorsed by every serious economic commentator in the country. It is backed by the credit rating agencies. It stands in stark contrast to those opposite who still have no alternative. They come in here and whinge about it, but they have no alternative--not one alternative economic strategy. Is this a tough one? Yes, it is. Are there easy options out there? No, there are not. So if the Leader of the Opposition wants to talk about an alternative, come on--put it up.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is also to the Premier. Last week the Premier claimed Labor was forced to privatise after the election because before the election she did not know the impact of the global financial crisis on the state’s economic bottom line. Yet on the eve of the state election Labor’s Treasurer released a statement, which I table, which stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The full force of the global financial crisis on Queensland was given a price tag of $12 billion.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Ministerial media statement by Hon. Andrew Fraser, dated 20 February 2009, titled ‘Global Financial Crisis wipes out $12 billion of revenue: Fraser’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Given the Premier clearly knew the price tag of the global crisis prior to the election, why are the Premier and Labor still trying to dupe Queenslanders?

Ms BLIGH:
Not only were we open with the Queensland public about what the global financial crisis was doing to our economy and our budget, we published a budget update. We were the only state to do so. We published an update on the Friday before I called the election and it was in fact the basis and reason I called the election when I did. It was absolutely clear that our budget position was being critically attacked by the global financial crisis.

It is easy to sit here now and feel comfortable about it, as the opposition tries to do, but the world was spiralling downwards. Nobody knew where the bottom would be. Mining companies were laying off 400 and 500 people at a time. Building companies were going to the wall during the election period.
Mr Schwarten interjected.

Ms BLIGH: I take the interjection from the member for Rockhampton. Major companies were dropping workers and workers were losing jobs. It was not this side of politics that stood up and said that we were exaggerating the GFC, that it did not exist, that there was no recession; it was the then Leader of the Opposition, the member for Southern Downs. It was not this side of politics that were the deniers of the GFC; it was those opposite. It was the member for Southern Downs.
Did revenues go down? Yes, they did, and that is what the published documents showed.
Mr Springborg interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I call the honourable the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: Then immediately after the election the GFC continued to have an effect not only on Queensland but on Australia. The federal government then published its own budget updates which indicated that the revenue from GST had radically fallen, as we would expect in a serious economic downturn--people stop spending, consumption slows and so consumption taxes like GST similarly slow and drop. What happened? Every state lost GST revenue as a result. Not only did we say before the election that the global financial crisis was causing devastating damage to our budget and our economy, it continued after the election.

It is the Leader of the Opposition who should be upfront with the people of Queensland about what his economic strategy is. People in Queensland know what our economic strategy is. It is a difficult one, but we are determined to see it through to make a stronger Queensland. What is it that the Leader of the Opposition will do? He arrogantly thinks he does not have to tell people. At least the shadow Treasurer is upfront and open when he says that they are going to reassess the building program. Watch out for the reassessment in your electorate. In every electorate in Queensland every project will be reassessed.

Mrs KIERNAN:
My question without notice is to the Premier. Can the Premier please update the House on the government’s latest efforts to support jobs and emerging industries like the LNG industry?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. As the member will know, it was one of the four planks of our job creation strategy that we would do everything in our power as a government to support new and emerging industries wherever they were found, but we certainly nominated the liquefied natural gas industry and the solar industry as two that we would put effort into. That is exactly what we have done. We have done what we said we would do. We are delivering new industries to Queensland.

I was very pleased that the Deputy Premier could represent the government last week at a signing ceremony of one of the largest trade deals in Australian history. Santos Australia, Petronas, a Malaysian company, and Total, a French company, signed a deal that is worth $100 billion over the next 10 years. This is great news for the Queensland economy and for Queensland jobs. It is great news for regional Queensland. It is great news for cities like Gladstone and Rockhampton and Central Queensland. It is great news for the south-west, with cities like Dalby, Chinchilla, Roma, Toowoomba--
Mr Lucas: It keeps kids in the bush.

Ms BLIGH: I take the interjection from the Deputy Premier. These are projects that can keep kids in the bush and give those rural families an opportunity for their children to have jobs in the towns and cities that they grew up in and not have to leave.

This project will deliver more than 6,000 jobs for Queensland by 2014. What it will deliver over the life of the project is a $3 billion boost in royalty revenue--$3 billion from that one contract. Exports of five million tonnes of LNG each year will go to markets in Asia and Europe as a result of this signing.

It means that the new LNG facility at Gladstone--if it does receive federal government tick off--could start construction as early as the first quarter of next year. That means that Santos would then be leading what everyone knows is a race to become the world’s first project to convert coal seam gas to LNG on a large scale out of Gladstone.

We saw the potential and we swung into action more than a year ago. That again stands in stark contrast to those opposite. Last Sunday we saw the member for Condamine being slapped down by the member for Callide over claims that the coal seam gas industry should be scrapped. Then we saw the member for Condamine saying that there should be a moratorium. The member for Callide does not like it. I think he does like having a bit of a stoush with the member for Condamine. The member for Callide is very sensibly recommending reinjecting water into the aquifers. I support him on this. I am pleased to have his support. But he needs to start talking about which one of these is the policy of the opposition.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Premier. The Premier claimed she should have been more upfront with Queenslanders on privatisation. Will she now be upfront with Queenslanders and release the smoking gun--the pre-election cabinet document from October 2008 which included a privatisation discussion paper from Queensland Treasury?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. Today we have members of a desperate opposition asking rehashed questions that they have asked on many occasions. We are very clear on this side of government: we need to restructure our budget to match the modernisation that is happening in the Queensland economy. We need to position Queensland for the future opportunities that are there for us to grab. If we want to be--
Mr Springborg: So you planned to privatise in October 2008?
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Ms BLIGH: If we as a state want to be in a position to harness the opportunities that are on our doorstep with programs like a new solar industry, like renewable energy sources and like liquefied natural gas, we need to position our budget so that we can back those communities with the social infrastructure they need--the roads, the hospitals and the schools they will need to make these industries a reality. Our government is determined for Queensland to continue to develop as the powerhouse state of Australia. We have been absolutely clear about our economic strategy. I have answered the question asked by the member for Southern Downs numerous times in the public arena. We as a government faced the worst economic circumstances that we have seen in this country--
Mr Springborg: No-one had heard of the GFC in October 2008.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides will cease interjecting.
Ms BLIGH: I take the interjection from the denier, the member for Southern Downs.
Mr Fraser: You better ring Glenn Stevens, because he introduced a package in October. I’ll get you the Reserve Bank Governor’s phone number, mate!
Ms BLIGH: The member for Southern Downs said that nobody had heard of the GFC in October last year.
Mr Springborg: In 2008.
Ms BLIGH: In fact, Glenn Stevens had started talking about the stimulus package in, if my memory serves me correctly--
Mr Fraser interjected.
Mr Springborg: Six months before the election.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides will stop the crossfire so I can hear the Premier.
Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. Lehmans collapsed in late 2008. You will find that October, November and December was--
Mr Springborg: So that’s when you first considered privatisation?
Ms BLIGH: Mr Speaker, I have answered this question over and over and over again. Our government faced circumstances that were the worst in 70 years.
Mr Springborg: In October 2008.

Ms BLIGH: After the election we looked at our books. We saw the decline in GST. We made the decision, and there has been nothing from those opposite. They are not upfront with anyone. They have no alternative. They have no vision for the Queensland economy and no plan for the Queensland budget. In fact, every week they come out and say that they want to spend more.
Mr Springborg interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I have asked a number of times. If there is another occasion, I will take action under the standing orders.
Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. Last week those opposite offered to put more money and more debt on the bottom line with no way of funding it.

Mr KILBURN: My question without notice is to the Premier. My electorate has a high proportion of people working in the hospitality and retail industries. Could the Premier update the House on what this government is doing to ensure employees who work on public holidays receive their appropriate entitlements?
Mr Crandon: It’s in the paper, mate!
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Member for Coomera, the Premier has not started yet. I call the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. Public holidays are an important part of the cultural life of Australia. There are some public holidays that have additional significance over others, and I do not think there would be any dispute about the very important significance of public holidays for religious observance at Easter, for remembrance on Anzac Day and for the very important role that Christmas Day plays in the lives of Australian families. It is that time of year when many families who do not get an opportunity to see each other at all during the year will travel to see grandparents--that is, they will go out of their way and spend money to be together. It is, in an increasingly busy world, a very important time for families and a very important reason to have a public holiday.

From time to time, however, public holidays fall at awkward moments, and this year Christmas Day will fall on a Saturday which, under the normal industrial instruments that apply, would mean that workers who are scheduled to work on Christmas Day would not receive the penalties that we would normally associate with a public holiday because the public holiday would be declared on the Monday. I do not believe that the general public expects people to work on Christmas Day for normal rates of pay. In fact, many people would prefer not to work on Christmas Day but in order to hold their job they simply do not have a choice.

Many of these people are people who work in essential services--that is, people who work in our hospitals, firefighters, ambulance officers and police officers. These are people who already sacrifice so much of their family lives with shiftwork for communities. We also know, as the member for Chatsworth just outlined, that there are many in the hospitality and retail sectors who work at numerous Christmas Day functions. Many people nowadays do not want to cook the Christmas dinner themselves. They take their whole family out for someone else to do it--and the washing up as well--and it is those people who need to be protected in these circumstances. I applaud the recommendation of the Attorney-General that we should on this occasion ensure, by declaring an extra public holiday, that both Christmas Day and New Year’s Day will accrue the appropriate penalties.

I do draw attention to the fact that next year we will have a very unusual circumstance when Anzac Day will fall on Easter Monday. I think everybody understands the importance of recognising Anzac Day on the actual day that it falls and we are--I give notice here, although there has not been a final decision--looking at making an additional holiday for the Easter Monday to be recognised at a different time. So we may have an unusual circumstance next year with a five-day Easter break, but I do think it is important that we do allow appropriate time for religious observance at Easter but appropriate time for Anzac Day to be marked with the dignity and opportunity that it warrants as well.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: ‘Walk a day in my shoes’ Program
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SEENEY: My question without notice is to the Premier. Premier, I refer to health workers union boss Gary Bullock’s comments yesterday when he was asked about the Premier’s latest stunt of pretending to be a hospital worker for a night. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... it’s insulting to some of our members that’s for sure.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I ask: will the Premier finally begin to listen and put an end to these ridiculous stunts which the real workers find insulting?
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question because it gives me another opportunity to talk about the value of a program like ‘Walk a day in my shoes’. As I have outlined a number of times, we will always find some knockers and we will always find some cynics. I am sorry that Mr Bullock feels that way. However, I can reassure him and everybody else that there are many unions that are actively working with the government to ensure that those members who will be in workplaces that are represented by unions will be working side by side with union members, that they know who their delegates are and that they will be in a position to talk to them. I can assure the House that many of my members have already had--they are reporting to me--a vast number of people contacting their offices wanting them to walk a day in their shoes.

Despite all of the concerns that one would expect in a large health workplace like the PA Hospital, as I said in my ministerial statement this morning, I thank the staff there for what was a very warm, very sincere and very generous welcome to their workplace. They did not miss the opportunity to talk to me about a range of issues, as one would expect--and good on them! Yes, they talked about some of the difficult issues, but they also wanted to talk about a whole range of things that affect them in their daily lives. They were also very keen for me as Premier to understand what happens in their workplace.

One of the reasons I chose this particular opportunity was that I have worked many jobs in my life. I have been a kitchenhand, I have been a waitress, I have worked in a factory and I have been a cleaner. But I have never had an opportunity to work in a health facility. Health is one of the biggest areas of our budget--it is one of the biggest employers in the state--and to see the reality of high-tech medical care and high-tech nursing, as you would see in the intensive care unit of a hospital like the PA, is nothing short of a revelation and eye-opener. So I thank those staff for sharing their experience and their incredible talent with me so that I have a much better appreciation of what they are doing and the challenges they face.

As I said, you will always find cynics and knockers when people move out to do positive things. In my experience in life--frankly, it is something I tell my children--you learn something when you think about what it might be like to travel in someone else’s shoes but you learn even more when you make the effort to do it. We make no apologies for being out there connecting with workers in their workplace.

On the question of industrial issues, I have to say that I was very disappointed to see the LNP spokesperson on industrial relations, Scott Driscoll, come out against our proposal on public holidays. We know that Scott Driscoll runs the IR policy of the LNP--a repeatedly failed LNP candidate who masquerades as a so-called independent representative of the retailers. In fact, I was pleased to see Commerce Queensland this morning recognising how important it is for workers to be paid properly. It is pity that the LNP and its candidates cannot.

Ms JARRATT: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Can the minister advise the House how Queensland, as Australia’s most decentralised state, stands to benefit from the Gillard government’s newly announced regional health and hospital funding?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. She is one of those members in this House who has repeatedly and consistently provided strong regional representation for the people of her electorate and for the people of regional Queensland.

Members would be aware that, as part of its negotiations after the last election, the Gillard government indicated that it would be placing an additional $1.8 billion into health funding in the regions, and that will directly benefit regional Australia. That is good news for Queensland. On a 20 per cent basis of population share, that funding would be around $360 million. But more than that, Queensland is the only mainland state that has more of its population outside of its capital city than within it--2.7 million people outside of the capital city to compared to two million people in the capital city and six times the size of Victoria. So in this state regional means regional. It does not mean down the road from Melbourne on a tram or a bus on a Saturday afternoon.
