In the past in this state we have had to put up with underinvestment in regional capital and certainly underinvestment in the training of doctors, which is a major issue we have discussed when it comes to GPs, rural practitioners and the like. So we will work very hard with the federal government. I think it is important to acknowledge that Queensland received about 30 per cent of the regional cancer funding. We got more than our share because we have more people in our regions, and that funding is important. It is also important to acknowledge that, for the federal government to come to the party with clean hands, you have to invest yourself. That is why our $7.33 billion program dwarfs the funding provided by the other states, so that we can say to the Commonwealth government, ‘We are doing it ourselves.’

So what are we going to do in this new round besides ask for more capital for our hospitals? The member for Gladstone is certainly looking at me. I know that she is an advocate for her area, as are many other members for their areas. Who would forget the AMA going berserk during the federal election campaign when Tony Abbott promised to take $544 million out of e-health funding? In a state like Queensland and in a nation like Australia, how ridiculous is that? So what about arguing for some infrastructure for our hospitals and, indeed, general practitioners in the bush, to facilitate e-health? Who could forget that Tony Abbott’s response to the regional Independents was $1 billion for Hobart? I tell you what, Hobart is not regional--$1 billion for Hobart. It was like his Mersey General Hospital policy. Julia Gillard said $1.8 billion for regions across Australia--not just for Bob Katter and not just for Rob Oakeshott and not just for other members representing regional areas, but across Australia. That is sensible policy.

When it comes to the federal government committing money for regional health in Australia, we will align the interests of regional Queensland with the interests of the federal government. That is very important. Technology can be our friend. We will also seek a share of that NBN money--$43 billion--to make sure that people in regional and rural Queensland can get the benefit of that money, as they have in the past with our other investments. It is a worthwhile thing to do.
Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Premier. Last week the Premier’s personal champion and white knight, Jim Soorley, told the Courier-Mail --
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my right will cease interjecting.
Mr NICHOLLS: Last week the Premier’s personal champion and white knight, Jim Soorley, told the Courier-Mail --
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Mr Beattie lived off escalating coal royalties while creating a structural deficit within the state budget.
XML.Hansard-Body: Given that the Premier was Treasurer under Peter Beattie, does the Premier accept that Labor created a structural deficit and was Peter Beattie solely to blame?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. We have said on many occasions that the global financial crisis could not have hit Queensland’s budget and the Queensland economy at a worse time. It came at exactly the point where we were reaching a peak in our infrastructure program. If it had hit us three or four years earlier, it would not have had such a devastating impact, simply because we did not have a building program of the size that we had at that point. Why did we have a building program the size that we had at that point? Partly because we had developed a 20-year infrastructure plan and partly because we had an addition to the South East Queensland Infrastructure Plan and Program. We looked right across each of the regions and committed to, and invested in, important infrastructure in major regional centres. I have yet to hear one voice from among those opposite about which one of those projects they believe we should not be committed to and which one of those projects they believe should not go ahead. We know they have a secret plan though, because the shadow Treasurer let the cat out of the bag when he said that they would look to reassess projects. In my experience--
Ms Simpson interjected.

Ms BLIGH:
I note the interjection from the member for Maroochydore. The member for Southern Downs is still saying that there was no global financial crisis, but the member for Maroochydore made the election commitment subject to it. So Arthur or Martha, they do not know what they are talking about, and it is the exactly the same with LNG. You will never get a straight position from them.

As I said, the shadow Treasurer let the cat out of the bag. When we say that there is no economic strategy from the Leader of the Opposition, we are right. We have not seen a single idea, a single alternative, a single strategy. But the shadow Treasurer cannot wait to get his hands on the building program. He is looking across the state--
Ms Simpson: You’re still building a Traveston Dam pipeline to nowhere--half a billion dollars of waste.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member for Maroochydore.

Ms BLIGH: We stand by our building program. We went to the election absolutely committed to it. We said it would be our single biggest priority. We said that jobs were the No. 1 goal of our government and the building program was the single biggest lever that we had to guarantee those jobs. That is exactly what we have done. In subsequent budgets, we have delivered what we said we would deliver.

What we have had this morning is a rehash of questions from an online article written by a journalist last week about an issue that was in the public arena and written about eight our nine months ago. Now we have had the shadow Treasurer talking about other matters that happened last week. This government is focused on the future. We are looking forward to progress LNG. We are looking forward to boost the tourism industry. We are looking forward to protect workers at Christmas time. What do we see from those opposite? They are living in last week, last month and last year.

Mr CHOI: My question without notice is the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development. As employment is a key platform for this government, can the Treasurer update the House on the latest economic data for Queensland?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Capalaba for his question and for his commitment to building jobs, to creating jobs for the people of his electorate, and, indeed, right across Queensland. He does a great job in his role of supporting the trade minister in opening up export opportunities for the people of Queensland to create new jobs, to create the jobs of the future, to create the jobs for the kids finishing school each and every year. To a person, this is a side of politics that supports job creation and the dignity of work. We saw that in the ABS job results last week for the 13th month in a row--13 straight months of job creation, now more than halfway on delivering on our commitment for 100,000 net new jobs over the term of the parliament, less than halfway through our term. That is the commitment that this government took to the last election--to deliver on jobs--and that is exactly what we are doing. We are doing that because we have the plans in place, the policies in place, and we have the fortitude to stick to those plans, to deliver on what we said we would do.
We see opposite a pretence that they have a plan. Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition was asked about his policies and his plans. What did he say? He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Well, we’ve had a number of initiatives--a number. I don’t count them, you know, on--in terms of a massive number, but, sorry, I don’t count them in terms of notating them off. But there are numerous ones and they’re significant.
XML.Hansard-Body: If it were not so serious, it would be funny. If it were not so serious, you could forgive the Leader of the Opposition for that sort of Springborgesque response--channelling the deputy leader from the last election campaign, who just said in here a moment ago that the global financial crisis was not known in October 2008. He must have missed it when the world stopped on 15 September 2008 when Lehman Brothers fell over. It is the anniversary of that event tomorrow. We might bring in a couple of newspaper articles to refresh his memory. He must have missed the comments of the Reserve Bank Governor, Glenn Stevens. What would he know about the economy? He is only the chairperson and the Governor of the Reserve Bank. What did he say in October 2008? Glenn Stevens said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Many have observed that the world faces the most serious international financial crisis since the 1930s.
XML.Hansard-Body: I guess that was a little bit ambiguous. I guess that unless you were reading the details of the financial press, you might not have noticed that the global financial crisis wiped out the world in 2008.

The fact is that the mentor is working. The fact is that we still see a policy-free zone--no policy, no plan, no jobs target. When asked to put up, those opposite shut up. When asked to put forward a policy, they cringe. All they have done is come in here today with a microwave oven parliamentary strategy. All the old favourites are back in the oven and reheated to rip out. Three years on, what is this government doing? Delivering jobs, just like we said we would. Three years on, what are the members of the opposition doing? Sitting on their tails.

Ms SIMPSON: My question is to the Premier. Given that the Premier’s No. 1 economic goal and Labor’s Toward Q2 manifesto was to retain the state’s AAA credit rating, will the Premier explain why the credit rating is not mentioned in her media statement that outlines four economic milestones on her third anniversary, why it does not appear in the Toward Q2 ‘Delivering on strong economy’ update, why it does not appear in the Queensland Economic Review update and why it does not appear in the Toward Q2 annual progress report, which I table. Does the Premier agree that she should also be upfront about Labor losing our once cherished AAA credit rating?
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Ministerial media statement, dated 13 September 2010, by Hon. Anna Bligh titled ‘Premier says future’s bright for Queensland on three year anniversary’.
Tabled paper: Toward Q2 Tomorrow’s Queensland flyer, titled ‘Delivering on strong economy 2009-2010’.
Tabled paper: Queensland Economic Review: Queensland Treasury, May 2010.
Tabled paper: Extract from ‘Toward Q2 Tomorrow’s Queensland--Annual Progress Report 2008-09’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my right will cease interjecting.

Ms BLIGH: I welcome the question from the only member of the opposition who knows that the global financial crisis happened. We know that the member for Maroochydore knows it happened because she made her election commitment subject to it. She issued an election commitment that had an asterisk on it. When you went down to the asterisk it said ‘subject to global financial crisis’. At the very time that the then Leader of the Opposition, the member for Southern Downs, was out telling the world there was no crisis, no recession, no economic downturn, nothing to see here--
Ms Simpson: How many other states have lost their AAA rating? Only Queensland lost its AAA rating.

Ms BLIGH: ‘Nothing to see here,’ said the member for Southern Downs, but the member for Maroochydore came out and belled the cat and said, ‘It’s just a little thing and it is called a global financial crisis.’
Ms Simpson: Why does New South Wales still have its AAA rating? You are the only one who has lost a AAA rating.
Mr SPEAKER: The honourable member for Maroochydore.

Ms BLIGH: The member for Maroochydore has come into this parliament with a startling revelation. She claims that there has been a change in Queensland’s credit rating. Well, wow! She is on the ball! They have got someone with their finger on the pulse over there.
Ms Simpson interjected.

Ms BLIGH: What we know, and what Queenslanders know, is that this government has a clear economic strategy. It is a strategy that will return us to surplus and return us to a AAA credit rating and maintain the building program in the process. The credit rating agencies give us credit for it and acknowledge it. What we have from those opposite is not a clue, not a single plan about the credit rating, not a single policy, not a strategy, not an idea, not a clue.
Ms Simpson interjected.

Ms BLIGH: We have a plan, and we are putting it in place block by block, at the same time as maintaining the biggest building program in the country. The member for Maroochydore squarks about New South Wales. We have, in just our hospital building program, a program that is I think almost three times the building program of the New South Wales government. If the member for Maroochydore wants to identify a hospital upgrade or a hospital rebuild that the LNP believes should not happen, she should stand up and tell Queenslanders. What is your plan? You have no plan.
Ms Simpson interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The honourable member for Maroochydore. You have had a fair go. That is enough.
Mr Lucas interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Deputy Premier.
Ms BLIGH: We will deliver a tertiary hospital on the Sunshine Coast--one that the Leader of the Opposition cannot even commit to.
Mr WATT: My question is for the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. Can the minister inform the House of recent progress on major infrastructure projects?

Mr SCHWARTEN: It is great to have people on this side of politics who understand the importance of building workers’ jobs in this state. I thank the member for the question. Over the last 18 days I have had a bit of a snapshot of what is happening on our projects. The southern Queensland correctional precinct has been turfed.
Mr Johnson interjected.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I note the interjection from the member opposite, who opposed the job in the first place. That is delivering 3,660 jobs. The Gold Coast University Hospital has generated another 10,000 jobs. Pouring of the ground slab has begun on the mental health building there. Those interjecting opposite might find a place there if they keep going. In the Rocky hospital redevelopment, vinyl floor and wall sheeting is underway. Refurbishing of the medical imaging section is also underway. External works in Townsville are delivering 2,360 jobs. The last of the level 3 concrete structures has been completed and the structural steel roof plane in the plant room has been completed. Those are the sorts of projects that are creating jobs and building much needed services in this state.

Over the last 18 days we have seen a number of things happen in Australia. We saw Hoges detained and then sent on his way. Unfortunately we have had tragic deaths in Afghanistan. We have seen the Gillard government appointed in Canberra and the NBN will start as a result of it. On the weekend my wife and I had the very pleasant duty of attending the wedding of the son of the Leader of the House which was absolutely marvellous. But what have we not seen over the last 18 days? We have seen no revelation from the king of reassessment over there about what he is going to reassess. He big-noted himself on Madonna King’s program saying, ‘We are going to reassess this. This is our strategy. This is our plan.’ What has the king of reassessment done? Nothing! Has he done any reassessing? He has done it in his mind. He has done it in the back room. But where has he not done it? He has not done it in this parliament. He has not done it to the builders in Queensland. He has not come out and said honestly, ‘This is what we intend to reassess.’

I note that the member for Maroochydore was going on with her obsession about the hospital on the north coast. Is that being reassessed? They will not commit to it and they will not admit whether they are even reassessing it. I challenged her in the paper to stand up and say, ‘I will fight for this hospital. It is not going to be reassessed.’ What did she do? Squibbed it! Just as all of those who sit opposite have squibbed this issue.

My question to the king of reassessment is: what are you reassessing? When are you going to make it known to the people of Queensland? When are you going to identify the electorates in this parliament that will suffer your reassessment? I know that it touched a raw nerve with the honourable member because she lacked the moral fortitude to stand up to this gentleman over here, the old king over here. You cower at the king’s feet.

Mr McARDLE: My question is to the Minister for Health. With Tweed Heads, Logan, QEII, Wesley, Mater, Ipswich, Toowoomba and Redlands hospitals on bypass or capacity alert at the same time yesterday afternoon, how many patients were languishing in the back of ambulance vehicles and for how long as a consequence of Queensland hospitals again reaching breaking point?

Mr LUCAS: With the largest capital works building program in Australia in health, one of the things that we will not be doing is saying to people who are seeking to go to our emergency departments that we will not build more emergency departments--we will not build them at PA, we will not build them a new hospital at the Gold Coast, we will not build them a new hospital on the Sunshine Coast, we will not build the additional capacity. That is what we are doing. If people drive along Ipswich Road they will see the massive increase in size in the PA Hospital. People will see also the work that we are doing at Logan Hospital.
Ms Bligh: They’re all very excited about that.
Mr LUCAS: I take the Premier’s interjection; they are very excited about that.

We saw in the media this morning the AMA talking about some of the issues regarding presentations to general practice and some of the issues surrounding that. One of those issues of course is the lack of general practitioners. We know that John Howard was responsible for that. Of course, the Rudd and Gillard governments, supported previously by the Beattie government, have massively increased the number of doctors in training.

The other thing that the AMA calls on the Commonwealth government to do is to increase the Medicare rebate, and I support the AMA on that. We do know that there are far too many presentations to hospital emergency departments for lower categories that could be dealt with by GP superclinics or, indeed, by GPs themselves. That is a structural matter that is easily dealt with. We also know that category 1 and emergency cases are always sent to the nearest hospital and our times are well within the national benchmark, which is less than a minute. Of course, there are times when we have severe capacity in relation to various hospitals, and we will seek to deal with that. I should also note that, from the point of view of my colleague the minister for emergency services, our ambulance response times are amongst the best in Australia and, indeed, our highly trained paramedics have the care of those people.

So where would people like to be? They would like to be in the care of one of the fastest arriving ambulances with a top shelf paramedic going to a hospital that provides great service, and all of that happens in Queensland. The one thing that members opposite will do is guarantee, through their reassessment of building programs, that there will not be sufficient resources in the future to provide emergency department relief. Here are the bricks and mortar. What do they want to do? They do not want to sell QR. Instead of the 13,500 doctors, nurses and allied health professionals we have employed, they would rather spend the money on coal train drivers. I tell them now that coal train drivers will not stop hospitals going on bypass. More doctors, more nurses, more resources will, and that is why we are doing this. It is about time that members opposite told the truth and committed to more medical staff instead of committing to ridiculous policies on privatisation which they do not even believe in.

Ms JOHNSTONE: My question is to the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services. Can the minister advise the House on how the efforts of Queensland’s paramedics and ambulance officers were recently recognised?

Mr ROBERTS: I thank the member for the question and for her support of the Queensland Ambulance Service. It gives me an opportunity to talk about some of the achievements of the Queensland Ambulance Service and particularly its staff.

There are around 3,800 staff working in the Queensland Ambulance Service and about 3,200 of those are front-line paramedics. Last week I and other members--and I thank members on both sides of the House--had the opportunity to thank and recognise the Ambulance Service and its staff during Ambulance Week and particularly the Star Care Awards. I note that in the electorate of the member for Townsville advanced care paramedic Bernadette Carnes was named the state’s top paramedic. I pass on my congratulations to her.

The QAS responds to around 750,000 incidents a year. On average, that works out to about one every 42 seconds. So this is one of the biggest ambulance services in the world and, as the Minister for Health pointed out a moment ago, with spectacular performance, particularly with response times.

Last financial year the Ambulance Service responded to 50 per cent of code 1 emergencies within 8.1 minutes. Just to compare that with New South Wales, the year before New South Wales responded to 50 per cent of code 1 emergencies within 10.3 minutes. So that is 8.1 here in Queensland and two years ago in New South Wales, 10.3. That is a spectacular performance and we should take every opportunity to praise our ambos when we can.

The government responds by supporting the Ambulance Service with the resources it needs. In this budget we funded 75 additional ambulance officers and another 160-odd ambulance vehicles but also, importantly and significantly, the capital works program. There was $3.2 million for six new stations and $13.8 million for 14 replacement stations across the state--a major capital works program.

As has been outlined, the shadow Treasurer let the cat out of the bag on ABC Radio a week or so ago saying that the LNP government is going to reassess all of Labor’s capital works programs. Ambulance officers across the state want to know which ambulance stations are going to be cut. We know the member for Moggill and also the member for Indooroopilly are out there undermining two projects, which I am sure will be first on the hit list: the proposed new ambulance station at Pinjarra Hills--that will be gone under the plan of the member for Clayfield--and the strategic land purchase out in the electorate of the member for Indooroopilly. He is out there undermining a good decision of the Queensland Ambulance Service. That will be the next one to go. They are the first two projects that will be easily done for by the member for Clayfield.
The LNP has a track record on this. When it came into government last time, there was an immediate capital works freeze. The words of the member for Clayfield are based on the history of this party--

Mr BLEIJIE: My question is to the Premier. At a community forum I hosted last week with respect to increased water costs in my electorate, approximately 400 residents passed a motion of no confidence in the minister for natural resources. The Premier claims to be listening. Will the Premier now act on the motion of no confidence? Will she accept an invitation from me to attend a similar public forum and listen to the constituents affected by water price hikes?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. I do understand that there are many people in the member’s electorate who are genuinely alarmed by their water bills and I understand why. It is not because of any significant increase in bulk water charges by the state government but because of very significant increases by the relevant council owned water utility. I did hear some of the meeting that was broadcast on ABC Radio and people were genuinely concerned about what the water utility was doing.

I think it is important to go back over a little bit of the history of this. I would like to put on the record a piece of correspondence from the Lord Mayor of Brisbane on behalf of the Council of Mayors. The Lord Mayor of Brisbane chairs the South-East Queensland Council of Mayors. In relation to this issue on the structure of water entities, in May 2009 the Council of Mayors wrote to the Treasurer and the minister for natural resources and had the following to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Councils strongly support water businesses as separate legal entities, commercial in focus, and subject to appropriate asset and economic regulatory frameworks.
Key elements of the proposal are:
three vertically integrated commercially oriented water businesses as separate legal entities with boards nominated by council owners ...
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is exactly what they got. They got exactly what they asked for.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Bleijie: Will you act on the motion of no confidence?
Ms BLIGH: If the member is genuinely concerned about water prices for his constituents, I can only refer him to the Council of Mayors that put in place this process.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Both sides of the House will come to order.
Mr Hobbs interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Warrego!

Ms BLIGH: The simple reality is this: we put in place a 10-year price path on bulk water to minimise the impact on consumers. The council entities have not done this. They have put a price shock into the system and they are making a profit--$94 million worth of profit at the Gold Coast. But a loss for the state government--
Opposition members interjected.
Ms BLIGH: I note them all backing the councils making a profit on water. We will make a loss because we are supporting consumers and minimising the price shocks. What we have seen from councils--
Mr Hobbs interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The member for Warrego will cease interjecting.

Ms BLIGH: Our government takes responsibility for putting in place a water grid that future-proofs us from drought. It is time the mayors of South-East Queensland told the truth and told people that they wanted this water structure, they got it and they are making a profit from it while we make a loss.
Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I would like to recognise in the public gallery councillors from the Brisbane City Council, Councillor Wyndham and Councillor Bourke.

Ms NELSON-CARR: My question is to the Minister for Main Roads. Can the minister please provide an update to the House on Queensland road projects planned and underway now that a federal government has been formed?

Mr WALLACE: The answer is, yes, I can. After a period of election limbo we are back in business, and doesn’t it feel good! We are rolling up our sleeves and picking up our shovels. We are giving the green light to key infrastructure projects and we are delivering benefits to Queensland drivers. Right across the state, we have put the wheels in motion on federally funded roads projects. Over the past five weeks the millions of dollars set aside for Queensland roads this year has been burning a hole in our pockets and we want to get on with the job. West of Brisbane, we are getting on with the badly needed $70 million Blacksoil interchange on the Warrego Highway.
Mr Wendt: Hear, hear!

Mr WALLACE: I take the interjection from the member for Ipswich West, who has been a vocal lobbyist for that particular project. I congratulate him because, with federal Labor, he has delivered that. We are mobilising our surveyors for the $10 million Ipswich Motorway planning study from Darra to Rocklea. In Townsville, in the member for Mundingburra’s area, we are hitting the ground running with $160 million for stage 4 of the Townsville ring-road. The member for Mundingburra will appreciate that. That will finish the vital link for Townsville, our second capital, and it will cater to the needs of that city for the next 30 years.

Thanks to federal Labor, work is well underway on the $115 million Cardwell Range realignment. That is one of the most dangerous sections of the Bruce Highway and, thanks to this Labor government and federal Labor, we are getting on with the job of fixing it. We are giving out mapping tools for the $10 million Mackay ring-road planning study. The member for Mackay and the member for Whitsunday will appreciate that study. They know how important that work is.

We are making progress on the Bruce Highway with $23 million to surface southbound lanes from Maroochydore Road to the Parkland overpass. We have our foot to the pedal on the $1.6 million Nicklin Way and Nerang Street upgrade. We are warming up in the Wide Bay with a $2 million-plus safety project along 50 kilometres of the Bruce Highway between Cooroy and Gympie. In Cairns, we are calling for tenders for the $150 million Bruce Highway upgrade north of Edmonton. I congratulate the member for Cairns and the member for Mulgrave who have been fighting for that project. We are going to tender. I

In Gladstone, we are pushing ahead with another $150 million for the final stages of the port access road. For the Gold Coast, of course, we are working on the M1. I was there last week, looking at works on the M1 at Daisy Hill and Nerang. This is thanks to federal Labor, which has delivered. This is thanks to this state Labor government, which has delivered, with nary a peep from those opposite.

Mr MESSENGER: My question without notice is to the Attorney-General. I preface the question by congratulating him for appealing Patel’s sentence. I refer the Attorney-General to conditions for non-disclosure clauses in his government’s Patel special mediation process, which ensures that victims are liable to pay back compensation if they speak publicly about the amount that is paid to them. I also refer the Attorney-General to the fact that a number of patients have broken his government’s non-disclosure provisions, disclosed the meagre sums paid to them and stated publicly that his government’s compensation was unfair, inadequate and, also, unconscionable. Will the Attorney-General enforce the non-disclosure provisions and take legal action against those Patel victims who complain about the compensation that they have received?

Mr DICK: In responding to the honourable member’s question, it is appropriate to give an overview of where we are with the special process. As the Premier did in a very comprehensive answer in the last sitting week or the sitting week before that, I will indicate what has happened to individuals who have gone through the special process. No Queenslander who was treated by Mr Patel or who otherwise fell within the bounds of the special process was required to go through the special process. There was no obligation on anyone to engage in the process. The special process was a very significant process that this government put into place to provide the smoothest and most efficient way to provide compensation to the victims of Mr Patel. We did that openly and up-front. It was a Labor initiative to smooth the way for compensation. However, those individuals who did not seek to engage in the process were not required to do so. As I understand it, a small number of people sought to pursue damages by way of a common law action in a Queensland court. It was open to them to do so.

The reality is that the overwhelming number of individuals who fell within the eligibility criteria for the special process went down that path. They were also legally represented. They received independent legal advice that was funded by the state government. They were entitled to take advice to accept a settlement or not, as the case may be. There was nothing that this government did to force anyone to resolve anything. Of course, an independent mediator mediated every claim. That was done independently, at arm’s length from government, as happens in so many civil litigation actions in this state where there is an independent mediator. Individuals were quite open to accept a settlement offer. As I understand it, many of those were in excess of what individuals otherwise may have been entitled to under the general law. That is a matter for individuals, it a matter for their independent legal advisers and it is a matter for the independent mediator.

What individuals do subsequent to settlement is a matter for them. Our commitment was to make that process as least traumatic for eligible Queenslanders as possible, to smooth the way to enable them to be compensated. We have almost finished the process. I express my sympathy to individuals and families affected by this sad chapter. We have tried to support them through the special process. It is a matter for individuals as to whom they wish to talk to about matters. Generally, when civil matters are resolved by consent between parties in Queensland, it is done so on a basis where they agree not to disclose the nature of the settlement. That is a matter for individuals. I do not see any benefit in pursuing individuals. If they want to speak publicly about it, it is a matter for them. We are seeking to provide support to them and to close this chapter so that they can continue to move forward in their own lives.

Mr WENDT: My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland. Can the minister inform the House of how the Bligh government continues to engage with landholders on CSG and LNG projects?
Mr SPEAKER: Minister, you have one minute.

Mr MULHERIN: I thank the member for the question. He is very supportive of the government’s policy on the CSG and LNG industries. Over the past couple of weeks, the government has run a number of forums on the CSG and LNG industries in the Surat Basin. I attended two of those forums, in Miles and Toowoomba. From the forums I attended, it was evident that the landholders received a lot of information from government in relation to the legislation process and protocols around the LNG industry. We have a clear vision on the LNG industry. We want to grow it but, as the Premier has said, that cannot be at any cost. Gas companies must comply with the laws and regulations in place and show landholders and the environment the respect they deserve. We are optimistic about the future of the LNG industry. We believe that if we stick to our plan and get it right, we will deliver on the opportunities the industry offers to all of Queensland.
While we have a clear vision, opposition members do not know exactly where they stand on this issue. Last week in Queensland Country Life , the member for Condamine, in his wide hat----

Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.38 am): We have all heard about the Premier’s 16 so-called achievements after three years in office. Some are so vague and immeasurable that the ‘sweet 16’, as they have been tagged, have become the subject of derision, ridicule and contempt even in the Labor Party. One ‘achievement’ is reducing unemployment. On the figures released last week, there are 131,000 unemployed and there were 116,000 unemployed, not three years ago but last year when the Premier made her promise to create 100,000 jobs.

Queenslanders do not think that those so-called achievements are the sweet 16, but they can come up with a list of their own. Here is Queensland’s Labor’s ‘sour 16’. No. 1 is losing Queensland’s AAA credit rating. No. 2 is record state debt--the highest in the entire country. No. 3 is massive structural deficits as Labor spends more than it earns and its spending increases consistently outpace its earning increases. No. 4 is electricity prices--Labor’s privatisation has dramatically increased the power bills of Queenslanders. No. 5 is assets sales--a fire sale of $15 billion worth of assets, despite overwhelming opposition from Queenslanders.
Government members interjected.

Mr LANGBROEK: They do not like to hear it, do they? They had their ‘sweet 16’ yesterday, but they have clearly proven not to be true. No. 6 of the sour 16 is literacy and numeracy. One in four or one in five students in years 3, 5, 7 and 9 are achieving only the bare minimum standard or lower for literacy and numeracy. Shame on the Minister for Education. No. 7 is the Queensland Health payroll. There is $900 million for a system that still cannot pay health workers correctly.

No. 8 is South-East Queensland water price rises. There have been massive price rises to pay for a $2 billion water recycling plant that is idle, a $1.2 billion desalination plant that is a lemon, $800 million on a northern pipeline interconnector--which the member for Maroochydore is always referring to--and the scrapped $500 million Traveston Crossing Dam.

No. 9 is Labor’s fuel tax. Since June 2009, the cost of fuel has risen by 9.1c per litre thanks to Labor’s fuel tax after they promised before the election that they would not touch the subsidy. No. 10 is driver’s licence hikes. The cost of a five-year driver’s licence is set to increase from $73.30 to $152.50. It is a system that is costing millions of dollars. We have 4.5 million Queenslanders in a system that is going to cost them over $100 million for a driver’s licence.

No. 11 is vehicle registration. Our vehicle registration is more expensive than any other state, making Queensland the most expensive state in which to own and run a car. No. 12 is the increase in motorway tolls, crippling some transport intensive businesses. It is only last week that the Treasurer came in here and said that we would have a cap on toll rises.

No. 13 is a health system that is grinding to a halt under the weight of massive management burdens and systems. No. 14 is Cross River Rail--a project first announced as a priority six years ago and announced almost monthly since then, every time the Premier needs a distraction from her toxic, appalling Labor government.

No. 15 is a justice system that does not deliver justice, where criminals get a slap on the wrist instead of hearing the slam of a cell door. No. 16--the most appalling one of the sour 16--is a cabinet full of underperforming, acquiescent carpet strollers with no real-world experience. They have to be sent out to get some--but only for a day.

They are the 16 things that Queenslanders will remember about the past three years--a litany of failure, an appalling record of deceit and dishonesty. Today we heard a ministerial statement from the Treasurer about privatisation in which he could not even utter the word. Under this dishonest Labor government in Queensland, privatisation has become merely a transaction--the next chapter. So divorced have they become from the truth that they can no longer utter the word ‘privatisation’.

It is no wonder, then, that the column writers have seen fit to explore the raft of weaknesses replete with this government. I noted on the weekend the column of that noted historian Ross Fitzgerald. I do not think anyone would claim that he is a great conservative supporter. I do not think people would say that he is one of ours. Let us have a look at what he had to say in the Weekend Australian . He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Bligh government boasts the worst Queensland state ministry since the 1950s.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Fraser: Is this the best you can do? What do you stand for?
Mr LANGBROEK: I think they are great words. The Treasurer clearly does not want to hear them, because he is part of this hopeless state ministry. Let me return to the quote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Bligh government boasts the worst Queensland state ministry since the 1950s. Deputy Premier Paul Lucas has failed as health minister, running a department that can’t even pay health workers properly.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Mr Fitzgerald goes on to state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The bureaucrats rule Treasurer Andrew Fraser--
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Fraser: Why don’t you go and ask them what they think?

Mr LANGBROEK: That is what they say. Because he has never had a real job, he has to have people who have real-world experience who tell him what to do, except when he practises his well-rehearsed answers to questions without notice. What else does Ross Fitzgerald say? He says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Bligh’s departmental head in the Premier’s Department, Ken Smith, is out of his depth and provides no leadership to the bureaucracy.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Mr Fitzgerald further states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Bligh’s ministers are generally young, inexperienced, lazy and incompetent and promoted by Bligh to ensure their support.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Then Mr Fitzgerald states what we all know--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The support of Australian Workers’ Union powerbroker Bill Ludwig is crucial to Bligh’s survival. He is the last person of influence standing in her corner.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Fitzgerald is not alone in his scathing assessment. Steven Wardill of the Courier-Mail also wrote a very insightful piece about the credit of the Labor Party in this place in which a senior Labor insider is quoted as saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The whole reason the state caucus is in such bad condition is due to Peter Beattie, he went out of his way to attract mediocrity.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The source goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Beattie knew he always looked better when surrounded by B-graders.
XML.Hansard-Body: Wasn’t there a minister here once who used to refer to people as B-graders? I wonder who the source was. I see that the member for Chatsworth is here in the chamber. Let us have a look back at the member who came here in 1977 to see if he is the source. Another commentator, Madonna King, also summed up--
Mr Fraser: What is the point of this?

Mr LANGBROEK: It is to point out to the Labor government, of which the Treasurer is an intrinsic part, just how hopeless they are and how they need to be held to account for what they have done when they are trying to make out that they have some sort of proud record. This is what Madonna King said when she summed up Queensland Labor in her column--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In fact, the only thing allowing Anna Bligh to remain as leader of the state’s Labor Party--and the Premier for now--is the lack of any suitable replacement--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: apart from the laughing clown over there. Ms King points out--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That says much about Anna Bligh’s Government and the depth of talent of her ministry, but the search for a replacement has led to some bizarre scenarios being floated.
The best example this week was that MP for Brisbane Central Grace Grace could possibly replace her as leader.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Ms King goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is not journalists peddling a rumour, as the Government would like you to believe; this comes from Anna Bligh’s own MPs.
XML.Hansard-Body: Government members interjected.

Mr LANGBROEK: They do not like it, do they? They give it out here for an hour and they cannot even handle it for 10 minutes. Well, blow me down: the member for Brisbane Central is doing the numbers--something that I informed this House of a fortnight ago. This is what Madonna King goes on to reflect about the Premier’s latest media stunt--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Thursday night at the Princess Alexandra Hospital will not be seen as a new open Premier hell-bent on learning. It’s more likely to be seen by voters as a cheap political stunt, aimed at improving the Premier’s public relations.
XML.Hansard-Body: Union leaders told the Left faction Labor members yesterday that working for a day in a hospital or a hotel is an insult to their members. Of course it is an insult to Queenslanders who have seen all of these stunts before after nearly 20 years of this toxic Labor government.
Mr Ross Fitzgerald summed it up nicely at the beginning of his article on Saturday. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Anna Bligh is only surviving as Queensland Premier because there is no one else willing to lead the ALP into near certain defeat at the next state election due in 2012.
XML.Hansard-Body: I do not take victory for granted and, as leader of the LNP, I will work day and night between now and the next election to prove to Queenslanders that we can get this state back on track. We will work day and night to make Queensland No. 1 again. We will work day and night to set out a plan and a vision for Queensland that will once again lead the country.

Once again we saw this morning from the Premier and the Treasurer lots of overacting and lots of tired regurgitation that ‘yes, we were upfront with Queenslanders last year in the lead-up to the election’ when it was revealed that they did know what the global financial crisis had cost this state. $12 billion is the figure the Treasurer released on the eve of the election. So the Premier did know and will not release today the cabinet document from October 2008 that says that they knew about privatisation and that they had plans about it.
Mr Fraser: Spit it out. Bring it home. Take a walk.

Mr LANGBROEK: The member for Mount Coot-tha is the typical example of the worst of this Labor government--Labor who think they can put people like that in here because they are destined to rule forever. The people of Queensland have different intentions and will prove it at the next election.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP) (11.49 am): Firstly, I would like to acknowledge staff and students from Biggera Waters State School. The school council is here with us today, and I would like to thank them very much for making the effort to come.

Last week at one of my regular mobile offices I met a 55-year-old woman who, for many reasons and personal circumstances, is living in her car. Dianne has a 24-year-old son who is unable to live with her at this time. My office is currently working with her to have this situation addressed.

Meeting people like Dianne who have no place to call home is a reality check on how tough many people are doing it in our communities. The state government has committed to building 4,000 units of social housing under the Nation Building--Economic Stimulus Plan, over 350 of which will be in the Gold Coast region. It is this commitment that will assist high needs clients on the department of housing’s Gold Coast waiting list, including pensioners.

Many community leaders and representatives acknowledge the need for more affordable housing stock on the Gold Coast to help address the issues of growing homelessness and after-housing stress. Even the federal Liberal MP Stuart Robert was quoted in the Gold Coast Sun during the recent federal campaigns that he was deeply concerned about the severe shortage of affordable accommodation for struggling families. He said, ‘We’re starting to see more and more families and even fathers with young children who are homeless.’

Yes, I could not believe that I was reading those words either given that a year earlier he was generating a great divide amongst the Coombabah community, hosting a public rally against another Labor funded social housing project that had not yet been approved. I am pleased that the Liberal federal member has obviously discovered for himself that people in need of housing support are generally good people who need help. He was photographed with a 75-year-old lady apparently desperate for housing support. Whilst this lady does not in fact reside in the federal member’s electorate, seniors and people with disabilities do represent the highest proportion of people on the housing waiting list.

The federal member gets it, but what about the local councillor? A member of the Gold Coast City Council’s Planning Implementation and Assessment and Sustainable City Future Committee, Councillor Grant Pforr, last week claimed in the local paper that he had not been told about four two-bedroom apartments configured as one two-storey building on a 967 square metre site. Had the councillor bothered to check first before fronting up at the site with the media in tow, his concerns would have been allayed by a letter that was sent from the town planner of Project Services within the Department of Public Works to the CEO of the Gold Coast City Council in April of this year that said that the Department of Communities would be proceeding with this project. He would have been advised that the project meets the performance criteria of the planning scheme in relation to density, front setback, privacy and car parking, and that the project is assessed within the regional choice domain of the Gold Coast City Council’s planning scheme and identified as code assessable which means, just like in the case of a private developer wanting to do exactly the same type of building development, there is no requirement for public notification.

There is nothing sneaky about this. The project is within the planning scheme that council developed. So what is wrong with the state government building four two-bedroom units consistent with the planning scheme? The local councillor has, through blatant mistruths to the Coombabah community about his lack of knowledge of the project, ignited a debate about social housing and social housing tenants which I find quite honestly disappointing.

The councillor and some Coombabah residents may be surprised to know that there are already social housing residents living in Coombabah. I have met with a number of Coombabah residents struggling to meet their rent or after-housing expenses who are already on the waiting list or wanting to be. Some of these people live in manufactured home villages, some are families and some are seniors.

When my parents divorced when I was very young my mother was determined to regain her independent life and provide me with the best opportunities afforded to other children my age. Her priority was to find a home. We lived in one of the state’s oldest and most densely populated housing commission blocks ever built. It was Morrill Court in Townsville and it was four blocks of at least 200 units in each block.

I am telling this story to encourage people to be more compassionate, understanding and in some way tolerant of people who need housing support. I ask Councillor Pforr to realise that not everyone who lives in Coombabah can afford their rent. I ask him to explain to people where he would like them to live. He needs to be honest with the residents about his knowledge of this development application. He needs to support people living in his area to find housing.

Mrs KIERNAN (Mount Isa--ALP) (11.53 am): Queensland’s State Emergency Service has a proud history of volunteers who selflessly give their time to support their local communities. The Bligh government is also proud of its role in supporting these SES organisations. This was confirmed in our 2010-11 budget which committed nearly $15 million to the SES. My time as Parliamentary Secretary for Emergency Services will see me continuing the good work of my predecessors in this role of working collaboratively with these services. I will also continue to work closely with the minister responsible, the Hon. Neil Roberts.

The Department of Community Safety and local governments share the responsibility for the management of the SES. I am committed to continuing to work closely with our councils and local communities in a consultative and collaborative way. Apart from visiting the fantastic SES volunteers and EMQ officers in my own electorate of Mount Isa, I have also had the honour of meeting other dedicated SES volunteers in places such as Cairns, Mission Beach and Weipa. I recently attended the commissioning of two new SES buildings in Hughenden and Mission Beach. These great facilities are there to support the fantastic work that the local people do.

Today the SES boasts an active membership of approximately 6,800 volunteers based in 342 groups across the state. The value and dedication of our SES volunteers is clearly demonstrated through their performance of just under 71,000 operational hours since July 2009. This is including the recent February and March south-west Queensland floods and Tropical Cyclone Ului. It is a fact of living in Queensland that we are subject to frequent wild weather events. It is heartening to know that we have the SES which stands ready to assist Queensland communities in times of need.

The Bligh government also has a history of supporting the SES and the good work they do throughout the state. Funding provided in this year’s budget includes over $1.2 million to continue the 2009 election commitment Support our Heroes which will provide an additional 20 new vehicles, four flood boats, two rescue trailers and the delivery of an exercise regime. There is nearly $1.9 million to continue the 2006 election commitment Safeguarding Cyclone Communities which will provide additional replacement flood boats and rescue trailers, personal protective equipment and the stocking of regional disaster stores with items such as tarpaulins and sandbags. Nearly $3.3 million will be used to continue the 2006 election commitment to enhance training for SES volunteers.

In 2009-10, 21 vehicles were delivered to SES groups throughout the state. This includes an additional vehicle which we were able to purchase due to savings being identified. I am quite delighted that a couple of these vehicles were handed over to the great people in Burketown and Karumba in my electorate. This translates to real equipment on the ground where it is most needed.

We have also entered into sponsorship arrangements with companies like the NRMA and the Boating, Camping and Fishing people. We are providing funding across a broad range of areas for the betterment of Queensland communities. We are also planning for the future through providing government funding to Emergency Management Queensland through the Queensland Climate Change Fund. This will allow a continuous close working relationship with local governments and community sector organisations to increase the level of preparedness and resilience to natural disasters in vulnerable communities.

The Disaster Preparedness in Vulnerable Communities program provides more than $7 million over four years. The program includes four individual programs. Keeping Our Mob Climate Safe is one of them. I recently met two people who have been appointed under this program at Mission Beach. They are two of four officers who will be going out and working with our Indigenous communities and councils. I look forward to working with them as well.

Mr SPRINGBORG (Southern Downs--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (11.58 am): Last week the Premier said that she should have been more and could have been more upfront with the people of Queensland on the issue of privatisation. In this parliament today the Premier had the perfect opportunity to be upfront with the people of Queensland on the question of privatisation.

What did we see from the Premier? We saw the Premier fail the fundamental test of her own words. The Premier failed the fundamental test of her own assertions, and again we saw the victory of spin over substance when it comes to the continuing insincerity of this Premier. We also know that, as we saw the early stages of the global financial crisis start to wash across the shores into Australia in September/October of 2008, this government--her government--was already in possession of a cabinet submission which said, ‘Privatise, privatise, privatise’. Yet if one listened to the Premier here this morning in the parliament, she would have us believe that it was not until at least April of 2009 that the government even considered the privatisation of Queensland’s generational assets. This morning the Premier again asserted that only just before the state election--indeed, in about March of 2009--did she say that there could have been an underlying impact on the budget bottom line in Queensland from the so-called global financial crisis and that the government was not considering privatisation. It was not until after the election when--oh, my goodness!--they opened the Treasury safe and realised that all of the money had gone that they considered privatisation.

However, in this place this morning when the Premier was confronted with overwhelming evidence that Treasury had put a proposal to government in October 2008 suggesting that there should be privatisation she was not able to say whether that was right or not. Indeed, she dodged around that particular question. So what we know from this parliament today is that this Labor government--all of the cabinet ministers who sit over there--was considering this privatisation proposal in October 2008. Again, we see a situation of a Premier who believes that she can just talk to Queenslanders--talk at Queenslanders. That is her solution. She believes that the solution to this is to talk at Queenslanders when Queenslanders only want her to open her ears and listen to them. That is why the people of this state feel so deceived by this Premier, who cannot even tell the truth when it comes to the issue of privatisation. The smoking gun was exposed this morning: in October 2008 this government was actively considering privatisation, yet it said that it did not make that decision until six months later. It said that it was not even faced with that particular proposal until six months later. That is another reason no-one in Queensland can trust one iota what this government says.

Another thing that needs to be considered is that Australia has been in two recessions over the last 20 to 30 years--in the 1980s and the 1990s. It did not go into recession in 2008-09, even by the Premier’s own admission. However, during the 1980s and 1990s no Queensland government had to sell generational assets. Governments did not have to sell generational assets in the 1980s recession and did not have to sell generational assets in the 1990s recession. No government sold those generational assets when it came to the Asian economic crisis in the middle of the 1990s. The common denominator here is a Labor government that is fiscally incompetent which brought this on itself and now cannot even be honest.

While on the subject, we have a government that is completely bereft of ideas. It comes into this parliament day after day after day and votes against proposals put forward in private members’ bills before the parliament by the LNP in the most gross act of political petulance, yet comes back into this place and re-enacts those proposals in full or in part as its own. I refer of course to the penalties and sentences amendment bill relating to the Sentencing Advisory Council which the government voted against and brought back as its own. I refer to the serious sexual offenders minimum imprisonment and rehabilitation bill. The government voted against it in 2006 and brought it back in here largely as its own. Then there was the Criminal Code (Assault Causing Death) Amendment Bill 2007. Now the Attorney-General is proposing to do away with the excuse of provocation and the excuse of accident in Queensland, bringing the legislation back into this place largely as his own. Then there was the Telecommunications (Interception) Queensland Bill 2003--

Mr WENDT (Ipswich West--ALP) (12.03 pm): I want to alert the House to a significant announcement made last week concerning improvements to the Warrego Highway, and I know that the honourable member for Toowoomba South and the honourable member for Lockyer will be very keen to know more about this.

As members know, this highway is the main artery for heavy vehicles, residents and tourists travelling from the state’s west into the south-east corner. Last Wednesday morning I had the pleasure of announcing that this state government will spend $40 million to improve safety on the Warrego Highway between Ipswich and Withcott. Even better than that, it is planned that the works will be completed prior to the end of 2011. On the day of the announcement I invited the federal member for Blair, Mr Shayne Neumann, to attend, because he has worked tirelessly to attract federal funding for this important National Highway--and I should say that that is only right, because in reality it is a federally funded road and part of the National Highway system. However, I am happy to advise that Shayne has been very successful to date and instrumental in ensuring that the money for the Ipswich Motorway continues to flow--that is, around $2 billion--and that during the recent election campaign he was able to obtain an election commitment of over $50 million to construct a flyover at the notorious Blacksoil interchange. It is only fair to state that the Queensland government is putting in its pound as well in that it is submitting about $16 million, or about 25 per cent of that project, in addition to the $50 million from the federal government.

I also invited to last week’s announcement my electoral neighbour, Mr Ian Rickuss, the member for Lockyer, and the new LNP federal member for Wright, Mr Scott Buchholz, and it was a pleasure to see how everyone agreed that politics needs to be put aside to ensure that the safety of motorists is identified and actioned as quickly as possible. As I mentioned before, work on the new projects is expected to start early next year and will target a number of trouble spots. As such, this funding will allow the following safety upgrades to be undertaken. These upgrades are at the Crowley Vale Road and Harm Drive intersections at Crowley Vale--that is, the Big Orange intersection outside of Gatton, and I am sure a number of members are aware of that particular area and the recent tragedies that have occurred along there; the Claus Road and Thagoona-Haigslea Road at Haigslea which is just east of the Sundowner Hotel--and a few of us have been there--and which has been in need of treatment for some time; the intersection at Moroney Road at College View, where recent accidents have also occurred on the Warrego; and finally but very significantly the intersection at Tallegalla Road and Lowood-Minden Road, which is commonly known as the Minden crossroads.

In addition to these works, extra funding will be invested in new signage, guardrail installation, removal of roadside obstacles, minor drainage safety works, and line marking and culvert replacement works at various locations between Ipswich and the Toowoomba range. As we all know, the Warrego Highway between Ipswich and Withcott needs urgent attention due to the high volume of traffic that travels this section of road daily, and that is what these funds are all about. The south-west corridor is booming and transport demand on this section of highway has grown by more than a third since 2001, and the honourable member for Toowoomba South can attest to that. Our region needs a safe and reliable road network to cater for increased traffic, and that is why this program of works is so important. We have provided this $40 million of state funding between 2009-10 and 2010-11 and that funding is on top of the $30 million in federal funding between 2008-09 and 2010-11, and that money specifically related to asphalt overlay between the Minden and Tivoli intersection on the Warrego Highway on the eastbound lanes.

Under the $70 million safety improvement program--that is, $40 million from the state and $30 million from the federal government--priority safety works have already been completed at 11 locations. I should point out that we have already improved safety at both the Haigslea-Amberley Road intersection, which is commonly known as the Walloon turnoff, and the Tallegalla Road/Lowood-Minden Road intersection that I spoke about a moment ago, which is commonly called the Minden intersection or Minden crossroads. At that specific intersection a left-hand slip lane was built off the main thoroughfare and has been an outstanding success. The local mayor of the Somerset council is also the local tow truck operator, and they have advised me that we are sending them broke because they used to attend accidents there on a fortnightly, if not weekly, basis and now they have attended only two accidents in the last eight or nine months.

I note that the minister, Craig Wallace, has just returned to the chamber. I should recognise him particularly for these fine works. The money will be used greatly and will enhance the improvements to those roads. I should also pay special thanks to the Main Roads staff--from engineers to traffic controllers to maintenance personnel and others--who do a fantastic job of maintaining and constructing our road networks. I have no doubt that the minister will mention the fact that these roadworks and construction projects are creating jobs right across Queensland, and nowhere more importantly than across the electorates of Ipswich West and Lockyer and right up through to Toowoomba.

Ms SIMPSON (Maroochydore--LNP) (12.09 pm): Labor’s answer to a problem is to throw money at it, to not demand value for money and then to make the people pay for the waste. The transport minister, Rachel Nolan, has failed to prove her claim that a doubling in the cost of a Queensland driver’s licence is value for money. I challenge Minister Nolan to release all the documents about the cost escalation of this bungled project and to be accountable to the parliament and to the people--the people whom the minister is telling to wear this outrageous cost hike. The minister’s claim that the cost hikes are value for money is like telling Queenslanders to eat cake when many of them are struggling to survive. Motorists are saying a resounding no to the hikes, with 75,000 people signing an e-petition to protest the Bligh Labor government’s plan to more than double the cost of a licence over the next five years.

Queensland motorists are the most heavily burdened in Australia since the hikes in registration fees and tolls as well as the petrol tax, and this Labor government is not listening. If transport minister Nolan wants to continue the pretence that the huge cost blow-outs are value for money, I say: let us see the proof. I remind the minister that the Auditor-General in his report to parliament No. 8 warned the following--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... projects can only be considered successful if they deliver intended benefits at an acceptable cost. Therefore, within government, there needs to be a focus on benefits and the active monitoring and reporting of progress towards realising those benefits.
XML.Hansard-Body: I table that excerpt.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Extract from Auditor-General’s report to parliament No. 8 for 2010: Results of audits at 31 May 2010--Financial and compliance audits, pages 17-20.
XML.Hansard-Body: Where is the proof? I have sought information about the reasons for the cost blow-outs under the right-to-information laws and I have been blocked. I am appealing the latest decision. This government is desperate to hide the trail of paper about its financial mismanagement and thumbs its nose at the Auditor-General’s recommendations. But Labor Minister Nolan still has the audacity to tell Queensland motorists, who bear a cost burden greater than the people in any other Australian state, that this latest cost hike is good value.

Let me address first this huge cost blow-out on the project. I table an outline of the escalation in costs, from about $6 million in 2002-03 to an estimated $20 million when the project was restarted in 2006-07, and then a whopping cost escalation in the past few years which has brought the project up to $112 million.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Table titled ‘New Queensland Drivers Licence (NQDL)--Capital Statements Data’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Last year alone the estimated total cost for the new Queensland driver’s licence project blew out by $30 million. The result of this mismanagement is that motorists are being gouged. They are milch cows. The cost of a single year’s licence will rise from $29.35 to $68.50 in 2014-15. For a learner driver the cost rises from $72.60 to $148.35, and the cost for a five-year licence rises from $75.55 to $152.50. This increase is a more than doubling of the cost of a licence in only a few years. I table a list of those costs.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Table detailing various Queensland driver’s licence fees as at 1 July 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: Even with the huge cost blow-out on the original driver’s licence project, the government is still creaming the public. It is draining the money from motorists’ purses. There are just over three million licensed drivers in Queensland. At $152.50 for a five-year licence, the government will reap $477 million over the life of that five-year licence. This is well and truly in excess of the original capital investment of $112 million. We have to ask: where is the money going? It is time this minister and this government were accountable. They are ripping the money out of the pockets of motorists. They are trying to say that it is value for money but they will not come clean with the facts.

Let us look at the claim that the technology is worthwhile. I think the only fraud that is being perpetrated is the fraud of this government. The minister claims that the new card, which includes a chip--and they cannot explain how it will be used--will stop fraud. It appears that the only fraud here is the government. This project is overdesigned for what it will deliver and it is overpriced. The chip was originally supposed to carry the address on the inside. The boffins realised a bit late that the licence could not be read interstate and that there were other problems with other entities not being able to read the address on the inside. So they put the address back on the outside. I asked at the briefing what the chip would do and I was told that it was future-proofing, but for what future it could not be explained. The situation goes from the bizarre to the ridiculous, because people will be able to buy the new five-year high-tech card and if they change their address they will still end up with an address sticker on the back of that high-tech card.

Mr WETTENHALL (Barron River--ALP) (12.14 pm): I would like to draw the attention of the House to a range of ways in which the Bligh government is supporting tourism in tropical North Queensland and also bring to the attention of the House some of the new investments being made in the region by the private sector. Over the past 18 months to two years, the tourism industry throughout Queensland, but particularly in the tropical north, has experienced some of the toughest operating conditions of all time. The vast majority of tourism businesses have traded through these tough times and have done all they can to retain their loyal, dedicated and skilled staff. For that I think they deserve our recognition and thanks.

During this period some businesses have been able to take advantage of the highly competitive conditions in the construction sector to make investment decisions and to reinvest in renewal and refurbishment projects. I also think those investment decisions deserve to be acknowledged and recognised. It was disappointing, then, to read in the Australian Financial Review on 6 September 2010 a report that the newly elected federal Liberal National Party member for Leichhardt, Warren Entsch, has criticised the slow renewal of tourism facilities and resorts which he said had been exacerbated by the short-sightedness of the council and the state government.

Mr Entsch was back in his job only a few days before he was talking negatively about one of the most important industries in his electorate. I think it is a disgrace that Mr Entsch has launched such an ignorant attack on the tourism industry. He wasted no time in shooting off his mouth. He is either ignorant of what both the government and the private sector are doing or he is deliberately misleading his constituents. The new federal parliament has not even sat and Mr Entsch is already talking down the tropical north, talking down the tourism industry and talking down the livelihoods of thousands of people across his region. I am sick of the negativity. We need to be talking up our state, we need to be talking up tourism and we need to be talking up the contributions that particularly the private sector is making in very difficult circumstances.

So I will remind Mr Entsch that the following investments have been made in tourism in the tropical north--many in his electorate. He should be aware of them. There has been a major investment at the Paradise Palms golf resort in Palm Cove in my electorate. There has been a major refurbishment at the Hilton in Cairns. There has been a full refurbishment and global brand refreshment of the Holiday Inn in Cairns. There has been the construction of the Cairns Central Plaza Apartment Hotel. There has been a major refurbishment of the Pullman Reef Hotel and rebranding. There has been a major refurbishment at the Rydges Plaza Hotel at Cairns and minor refurbishments at the Rydges Esplanade Resort at Cairns, the Sabaya and Tradewinds. There has been a combined $20 million refurbishment of the Castaways resort at Dunk Island and at Elandra at Mission Beach.

What an insult to all of the business owners who have made these investment decisions and who, unlike Mr Entsch, have expressed confidence in the future of tourism in the region. Not only have these investments been made; they are paying off. Just today it is reported in the Cairns Post that average hotel room rates in Cairns are on the rise and that hoteliers have welcomed the news. The general manager of the Pullman Reef Hotel Casino, Adrian Williams, is quoted in today’s Cairns Post as saying that the results are ‘consistent with our view we have bottomed out and should now expect to see positive movement in revenue per available room’. Only yesterday leading cruise operators gave the thumbs up to the state government’s $11.2 million cruise terminal redevelopment of the heritage wharves.

Mr Entsch has attempted to undermine the consensus that has been achieved on the need for a new cultural arts precinct, to which this government has committed $40 million towards its construction. I say to Mr Entsch that it is time to think, act and talk positively for the benefit of tourism and our region.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (12.20 pm): As has been noted in this chamber on many occasions, the electorate of Gladstone is growing exponentially and in particular with the prospect of LNG. The vast majority in the electorate welcome the prospect of an LNG industry. However, there are those with concerns about safety, particularly in light of the fact that the LNG plants are proposed to be located in the Gladstone harbour adjacent to urban development. Incidents that have occurred recently in America have caused some disquiet. I will be asking for some information from the relevant departments in relation to any correlation with that incident and potential risks in my electorate.

There is a great need for infrastructure in the lead up to and during the construction of the LNG projects. Several of them look very promising in terms of their realisation. Infrastructure was looked at in a study commissioned by the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning. The document is completed; however, it has not been released. There is some concern in the electorate that it is taking so long for that document to be released. We need infrastructure that supports a community that is growing--such as roads, affordable housing and education facilities--and agencies that support families such as the department of child safety, community health et cetera.

The one issue that is raised with me most often is the Gladstone Hospital. I acknowledge that the Minister for Health has already expressed concern about the Gladstone Hospital and has acknowledged that hospital services need to be examined and treated differently in light of the growth in the region. I look forward to a meeting that is to be organised with the minister and others to discuss that. However, over the last week or so I have had a number of matters raised with me and I feel that it is important, because of the concern in the community, to present those matters to this parliament. On 26 August, the Rural Doctors Association said that the Central Queensland health district is the worst off in the state. Queensland Health has this week been accused of understaffing and underfunding the Gladstone Hospital and the RDA says the degradation of the public health system in the state’s central region is the result of long-term neglect. Only today I had a parent ring me who has a family member working at the hospital. The parent said to me that she had not seen her child this demoralised. She said staff are being laid off. The wards are full, but there are fewer staff available. This parent could not clarify whether it was contract staff who were being laid off or full-time staff, but certainly the understanding locally is that staff are to be reduced. That is ridiculous given the growth in the area.

One patient had to have a colonoscopy and several other treatments and was required to go to Rockhampton. This was a gentleman who is sponsoring a petition that is to be tabled this week in relation to the reintroduction of the intensive care unit. Another woman approached me who also had to have a colonoscopy. She has had them previously at the Gladstone Hospital. She was going public. She had paid for her day surgery. The public doctor had had the conversations with her, as had the anaesthetist. She was booked in to have the procedure when the hospital contacted her to say that her BMI was too high and she would have to go to Rocky, although she said she had lost weight since the last colonoscopy was performed at the Gladstone Hospital. Her point of irritation was that she is going to have the colonoscopy in Gladstone, but instead of having it at the Gladstone Hospital she will have it at the Mater Hospital. The cost of the day bed is significantly higher but it will be performed by the same doctor and by the same anaesthetist.

I believe that the management in Rockhampton, the clinician in charge, as well as the administration manager have a lot to answer for in terms of redirecting medical cases from Gladstone to Rockhampton and also in terms of not properly recruiting and gaining staff for the Gladstone Hospital. It is a growing area. It will be incredibly difficult to get people to relocate to the Gladstone region to work on the LNG plants if the infrastructure is lacking. As I said, the issue raised with me most is the Gladstone Hospital in terms of what the community see as a diminution and a reduction in the services that are available. The staff that work there do a brilliant job. They deserve more respect and they certainly deserve more help.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP)
(12.24 pm): As in many parts of Queensland, families in the Everton electorate spend a lot of time commuting to and from work. Every minute spent travelling, whether in a car or in public transport, is a minute not spent with family members. This is something I feel even more acutely now that I have become a father again.
