This morning’s Australian has named Simon Tutt as about to be exonerated. Maybe he felt like this when he was faced with the pressures and he was not certain what to do. The pressures can be just too great. For all this wonderful work, either nothing works or seems to work and their own lives become so difficult with strained families and relationships that grow distant as they try to please their masters.

Certainly on our side of politics I remember Greg Jackson very fondly. Some may also remember him in the same way. He had many of the fine traces of people who loyally give all of themselves, often to their own peril. Maybe when they have no more to give, their own lives seem worthless and because their own futures are so inextricably linked to their masters, they lose control of their own lives and destiny.

I realise that modern political machines cannot seem to function without such people. It is, indeed, timely that this bill attempts to implement a framework of ethical behaviour, including declaration of interest, codes of conduct and application of the CMC and other judicial instruments. What is tragic is that there are two groups, one supporting the current Labor government of the day and the other spartan supporting the organisation.

Irrespective of all these ridiculous statements by the current government about the best resourced opposition, we have a state Labor government which employed a vast army of journalists, media advisers, hacks and hangers-on. After 12 years of continuous governing and a diminishing ability to employ anyone just to try to plug every leak, the walls are fracturing and morale is failing. Most are wondering what will happen when the music stops, for inevitably it will and their jobs will be gone. For others who feel they might be able to claim Public Service status, their fear is irrelevance, a generation of non-government, and, for some, a Gulag--leftists and communist created gulags. So the thought is all too close to home for these people.

The second bill is the integrity reform bill. It is very difficult not to support anything that purports to be implementing integrity reform in Queensland. This bill is primarily to deliver a single code of conduct for the Public Service. It would be wrong to say that everything the Premier comes into parliament with is just a cynical vote-buying exercise to save her from both political oblivion and public long-lasting acrimony. However, to introduce this bill the day after she was unable to claim the third anniversary as Premier, when she endured group after group challenging her right to serve as leader, sweet 16 is the new jingoistic theme. We are all to believe she has never been kissed before, either.

What is wrong here is the obvious disconnect between the word ‘integrity’ and this current Bligh Labor government. It is very difficult to reform something if you cannot get your own house in order. Everyone has a favourite integrity quote, but the one that embraces all is that integrity is what we do, what we say and what we say we do. On any level the public has ceased just grappling with what went wrong with Labor; they just want to get rid of them for nothing they have done is what they said they would do and Labor has done many more terrible things in Queensland on top of that.

It would be incorrect to say that the state Labor government has not looked at responding to integrity and accountability in Queensland, but the response is marred in looking for ways of escaping the clutches of rules fairly imposed and ignoring the rest of the world on the issue. Labor in Queensland has decided it is so virtuous because they claim year on year that not only did Tony Fitzgerald rid our state of old-world governance, they remain his champions 20 years later. The true situation is really very different. Tony Fitzgerald’s assessment of the current Labor government is summed up in his own words as saying access can now be purchased, patronage is dispensed, mates and supporters are appointed and retired politicians exploit their connections to obtain success fees for deals between business and government. We are not talking about a few ex-Labor mates; there are buildings full of them and a vast amount of state cash being shovelled their way.

For any perceived failing of the National Party in government, at least the bulk of the funds built our roads, hospitals, cities and social infrastructure. All this lot seem to build are monuments to themselves. They eat at trendy restaurants and they travel to far-away places on expense accounts that, in the most recent case, delivered a payroll system that was formerly called Paris--interestingly, it was a European trip--that could not even deliver for our health workers and destroyed the morale of current Health staff. It was implemented as Workbrain under IBM and SAP.

The concern is raised further in this bill because of the lobbyist register and the inconsistent approach being adopted in various ministers’ officers and departments. There are very few changes currently that would seem to reassure anyone that Labor has changed anything other than forcing Terry Mackenroth from his position at the Gold Coast SuperGP. Far too much largesse and excessive slush funds have been taken out at the beginning of major state projects and it has to stop. Labor hacks were masquerading as facilitators in this process. It is not transparent and the lobbyist register will enjoy the LNP’s close scrutiny.

It was ‘last resort Laurie Connell’ in Western Australia who made success fees a fine art. For those who may not know, he collapsed a Labor government, put a Premier and his ministers in jail and died in strange circumstances. The effects of his activities have consequences even today. Have any current Labor members considered any of this when dealing with such people as have been named in parliament today, including Jim Elder, who was named in the Shepherdson inquiry? As usual with anything to do with Labor, the critical information lies in the bill and not in the second reading speech. In this bill there are significant numbers of acts to be amended. Rather than going through one myself--and I think the opposition leader has done that very well--I will constrict myself to the contentious areas and relating those where I have particular interest.

The proposed amendments to the Civil Liability Act 2003 allow for an apology to be made without an apology being able to be regarded as an admission of liability. This is at best looking after the state’s common liability. At worst, it is a ‘get out of jail free’ pass, maladministration, manifest incompetence and recklessness.

The Patel Bundaberg Hospital disaster, as detailed in the Davies inquiry and as continues on today, is testament to what we need to do about how we need to approach people very decently and look after their interests. That is the state’s role. Also I cite the Health payroll crisis, with this dubious program previously named Paris, which was found to be faulty by most overseas companies, was renamed Workbrain, sold to us under IBM and SAP and has basically delivered nothing for our Health staff.

The Public Interest Disclosure Bill is the whistleblower bill. It has been discussed extensively by the opposition leader and I will restrict myself to the issues that I think are salient. The Premier believes the former bill is expanded upon and for the first time in Queensland it will provide protection for disclosures to the media in particular circumstances. The bill is either just backsliding or may be just a little more sinister in delivery because the Public Service Commission is composed of government appointees in the same manner as are the department chief executives. This is beyond that problem of Caesar judging Caesar, which has been raised today. This is not a question of security or anonymity. However, what incentive is there for staff to raise issues of major concern with such a panel? After taking such action, the whistleblower has to take their own action to enforce the protective liability provisions. I think the bill takes two steps sideways rather than going forwards.
In many ways these cognate bills are really quite cynical and sickening. This is exemplified very clearly by the Premier’s statement. In her second reading speech she stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: As the way in which government business is done continues to evolve and change, so, too, must our governance structures evolve and change ... This bill is therefore an important next step in this government’s continued commitment to a contemporary and robust integrity and accountability framework.
XML.Hansard-Body: However, the public does not trust the government. They do not believe the Premier and, whether or not the Labor government believes it, the public was not told about asset sales and does not believe the Premier is truthful. Once lost, trust is not easily recovered.

Last night on the ABC, Australian Story broadcast a wonderful story about Michael Ware, a war correspondent. He made the amazing statement that there is no truth in war, for war is the consequence of loss of trust. If war is also the consequence or the result of failed diplomacy, does this mean that the current Labor government is a failure and its diplomacy with its constituency and the wider populous is also a failure? Is that why the Queensland public took to federal Labor with baseball bats at the last election and, after not getting what it wanted, that is, a change of government, the mood is ill requited? I wonder if what is waiting out there is nothing short of utter annihilation for state Labor? I think that is the case. The polls are getting worse and suggest that that will occur.

No self-induced Labor crisis will save the incumbents or the staff supporting them, for this series of bills is about those staff. Currently, nearly all newspapers in Australia rate the Premier and Treasurer as the worst Queensland leaders ever and they will be reviled forever. Self talk in a protected environment means little. But what of their staff? What of the true believers, cynics, modern leftist revolutionaries, Labor diehards and the many who genuinely believe in the greater good of what they are doing for their masters? Undoubtedly, some are probably still celebrating the near-death experience of a first-term Labor federal government and wondering, ‘What if?’
In Hocus Pocus, Kurt Vonnegut, the deceased American author, wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: During my three years in Vietnam, I certainly heard plenty of last words by dying American footsoldiers. Not one of them, however, had illusions that he had somehow accomplished something worthwhile in the process of making the Supreme Sacrifice.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: In other words, losing their lives. So it will be at the end of the Bligh Labor government, which is a reckless government in decay, made up of B-grade actors who are incapable of delivering anything of substance and, critically, who are illegitimate by virtue of failing to be honest when they stood for re-election. In the end, the foot soldiers wear the consequences of dishonesty. If these bills are to validate them, it is nothing more than hypocrisy. Shakespeare was right on the mark when, in Julius Caesar , he stated that integrity comes from within. He wrote, ‘The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars ...’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (3.22 pm): Today I rise to contribute to the cognate debate on the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2010, the Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010 and the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010. First, I will address the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2010, which proposes to amend legislation to implement a range of integrity and accountability reforms, and other operational improvements, supposedly designed to strengthen Queensland’s integrity and accountability framework. The bill amends numerous other legislation for a particular purpose following the Bligh government’s release of a discussion paper, Integrity and accountability in Queensland , to prompt public discussion on integrity and accountability issues and seek public input on proposals for integrity reform.

The bill amends a series of acts to seek to apply a single code of conduct across the public sector, designed to overcome the scepticism from the public that this government has any integrity left at all. Following consideration of public submissions, on 10 November 2009 the Government released the Response to Integrity and accountability in Queensland . The response committed to a number of integrity and accountability reforms to strengthen Queensland’s integrity framework, including creating statutory obligations for members of parliament and statutory office holders to declare their interests; amending the Civil Liability Act 2003 to allow for apologies by government departments without admission of legal liability; and introducing a single code of conduct for the Public Service, including necessary amendments to the Public Sector Ethics Act 1994.

The Liberal National Party has previously called for an extension of the operation of official misconduct in the wake of the Bundaberg Hospital scandal and the Flavell employment contracts scandal. The Liberal National Party has considered the extension of the role of the Integrity Commissioner so that it covers all parliamentarians. In the wake of recent events with the imprisonment of yet another Labor government minister and the smoke and mirrors that this Labor government has engaged in over recent days, the LNP hopes that those amendments are enacted. The government’s main purpose for rushing through this legislation is to cover its own tracks and to make the general public think that it is serious about cleaning up its own corruption. We have seen this in the past with the Beattie government and now the same stench of corruption permeates through to the very core of the Bligh administration. Queenslanders are not fooled and the polls clearly show that they believe that Premier Bligh and her government are not to be trusted or believed. Nothing short of a royal commission will expose the corruption of this government and Queenslanders deserve nothing less.

The public shows a lack of trust in the government. Recent polls in the Sunday Mail reveal that 65 percent of people believe corruption and cronyism are widespread in the Bligh government. This follows a report by the Crime and Misconduct Commission into police misconduct and a speech by 1980s corruption buster Tony Fitzgerald QC. The Sunday Mail conducted a Galaxy poll that revealed that two-thirds of Queenslanders believe corruption and cronyism is widespread in the Bligh Labor government. The poll revealed anger, contempt and complete dissatisfaction with Premier Anna Bligh and her ministers. Corruption fighter Tony Fitzgerald’s savage attack on Labor’s 12 years in power has resonated with voters, who are obviously fed up with the government and would kick them out now if they could. At her 2009 election campaign launch and victory speech, Ms Bligh called on the public to trust her, but they have turned their backs on her and the government.

We are facing government debt of $85.5 billion. To put that in simple terms, for an average family of four that means a $78,000 debt each, that is, a massive $78,000 debt per person, not per household. It is going to cost Queensland taxpayers $14 million a day, every day, to pay the interest bill on that $85.5 billion of debt. We are the only state in Australia to have lost our AAA credit rating and, having previously been the nation’s economic powerhouse, this government should be embarrassed that we are now on a credit watch with Standard & Poor’s. This is the same government that went into the election stating that the fuel levy would remain in place, but it has not. This is the same government that is busily selling off our assets to try and dig itself out of the black financial hole that it has put this state in.

The Premier has introduced the integrity bill as nothing more than a diversionary tactic so that her government appears to be doing something in response to allegations that the Labor government is guilty of corruption, cronyism and unethical behaviour over the past 11 years. On 29 July 2009, the Premier announced a review of integrity and accountability in Queensland that would focus on a broad range of integrity and accountability issues, including political fundraising, the adequacy of internal misconduct investigation procedures and dealing with pecuniary/conflict of interest matters. The government has previously announced that all government members of parliament will be required to meet annually with the Integrity Commissioner to discuss matters related to their statement of interests in the Register of Members’ Interests.

That brings me to the issue of lobbyists and lobbyist registers, which have been in existence for many years overseas, particularly in Canada and the US. The Western Australian government has had one for quite some time. In the lead-up to the 2007 federal election, with reports of cronyism in WA, Kevin Rudd announced that on winning the election he would commence a lobbyists register for the Prime Minister and Cabinet. All lobbyist groups quickly accepted this as the norm and to this day the lobbyist register works well in Canberra. I have no issue with a lobbyist register or listing current clients. The prohibition of success fees in Queensland is interesting, given that no other state in Australia or the Commonwealth has entered into arrangements of this nature. I would suspect that this provision would only encourage secrecy and not stamp it out.

As a former government and media relations consultant and a nurse for 30 years, my involvement with government relations began in 2000 when, as the general manager of the Wesley Gold Coast Hospital, I commenced the first free screening program for bowel cancer in Australia. My mother was the first person we picked up in the program. I was involved in the national task forces on colon cancer and childhood obesity. I lobbied for that issue pro bono. The same can be said for the nursing education policy written for the Howard government. I have worked closely with federal governments in the Life Saving Drugs Program. That program, started by Dr the Hon. Carmen Lawrence, replaced the Act of Grace, where children with rare and fatal conditions could be treated in Australia instead of being sent overseas. Those conditions affect a very small number of Australians. Conditions such as Gaucher, Fabry and Mucopolvsaccharidosis I, II and IV are so rare that nationally they affect less than 100 patients and, in some cases, less than 15 patients nationwide.

In addition, paroxysmal nocturnal heamoglobinuria is another disease vying for inclusion in this program and affects over 100 young Australians. The Life Saving Drugs Program, started by the Labor government and subsequently supported by the Howard government, has given much needed treatment to many families throughout Australia. It is a tribute to both governments that they recognised the need to support these patients who would otherwise have died.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! Member for Mudgeeraba, I am having trouble following the relevance of the issues you are discussing to the bills. Can you point out to me where they might be?
Ms BATES: I am basically pointing out as a former lobbyist that there was bipartisan support for this particular program and there continues to be bipartisan support.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: It is rather tenuous. I ask you to come back to the clauses of the bill.

Ms BATES:
Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In this place I will continue to fight for health rights and I will continue to fight for better health services for residents in Mudgeeraba, Queensland and Australia, and nothing will deter me from working towards a world-class health system as opposed to that which we have here in Queensland. I also found totally abhorrent comparisons in the past of my lobbying efforts with those of Labor mates who lobbied the Beattie-Bligh Labor government for favours.

The key with this bill is not what is in it but what is not. This bill fails on all accounts to make any real changes to the issues of corruption, cronyism and unethical behaviour in this Labor government. It does nothing to stop ministers misleading the parliament or one of its committees as this legislation was brought in to ensure that former Beattie government ministers who had misled parliament were not jailed. It fails to provide any change to the total lack of ministerial responsibility from this Labor government.

There is nothing in the bill about electoral reform and truth in electoral campaigning which was much talked about in the lead-up to this discussion paper. It has done nothing to stop Labor from accepting political donations from people before the courts on official corruption charges and it does nothing to stop union donations flowing into Labor coffers or, alternatively, does not address the parallel campaigns that unions run on behalf of the Labor government.

The bill fails to hold the Premier and the government to account over their misleading the people of Queensland about asset sales and fuel taxes. The Premier promised reforms and, despite more than 200 submissions to the integrity green paper, we get four amendments, three of which are already being done in practice. This government wants to also determine what occupations you can have before you even get into parliament and when you leave it.

This bill is nothing more than a desperate attempt to save face from a Premier and a Labor government that have had a former minister jailed and another embroiled in a sports rort scandal and a trail of former Labor mates under the microscope for unethical and questionable behaviour in their postpolitical life. This is just more smoke and mirrors from a tired, on-the-nose Labor government trying not to sink in the quicksand that it itself has created.

I now turn the next bill, the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010. The Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill creates a new stand-alone framework for the employment of staff members to support ministers, the Leader of the Opposition and, where necessary, other non-government members of parliament, separate to the Public Service Act 2008.

In the Response to Integrity and accountability in Queensland , released on 10 November 2009, the government committed to a number of integrity and accountability reforms, including introducing new legislation governing the employment of ministerial and electorate office staff. Ministerial and opposition staff are currently employed under the Public Service Act 2008 through the employing authority of the director-general of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet.

In January 2010, the government made a submission to the Crime and Misconduct Commission’s inquiry into the interactions between ministers, ministerial staff and public servants. A number of measures have been implemented in this respect, including amending standard employment contracts and issuing a communique setting out clearly that ministerial staff do not have the power to direct public servants.

The bill implements a stand-alone framework for the employment of ministerial staff, staff of the Leader of the Opposition and staff of other non-government members of parliament. The bill includes a specific provision that ministerial staff are not empowered to direct public servants in their own right, thus acknowledging the limitations on powers of ministerial staff members. Further matters dealt with in the bill include codes of conduct and the provision of statements of interests by staff members, which continue current administrative practice as established under the Ministerial Handbook and Opposition Handbook.

It is interesting to note that in the Sunday Mail last weekend issues relating to the Ministerial Handbook were raised in relation to an incident with ministerial staff at a function outside of the office, including a further function which was held at the casino in Brisbane as an unofficial gathering, attended only by ministerial staff. The article states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Anna Bligh’s army of ministerial advisers has been forced to learn how to behave properly after a harassment claim against a Cabinet Minister’s chief-of-staff at a post-parliament booze-up.

The Sunday Mail can reveal staff in all 18 ministerial offices have undergone anti-discrimination training at taxpayers’ expense only weeks after Main Roads Minister Craig Wallace lost his top confidant after he allegedly acted inappropriately towards a young woman related to a senior Labor MP.

The revelation is the latest to rock the Bligh Government as the Premier endures dissent from her own Labor colleagues over the asset sell-off and woeful opinion polls putting the ALP’s primary vote at a perilous 29 per cent.
It is understood the allegation by the woman related to a drinking session held by Mr Wallace for his staff in the Brisbane CBD after the minister’s recent Budget Estimates hearing.
The party kicked on into the early hours of the next day.

The chief-of-staff later moved to the office of Child Safety Minister ... Directed to attend at the behest of the Premier’s office, instead of doing their normal duties the advisers were taught about sexual harassment, workplace harassment, vicarious liability and the complaints process during the half-day sessions.

Mr Wallace had held the party after his Estimates hearing ... as a thank-you to his ministerial staff after they prepared him for the annual Opposition inquisition about the finances of his department.
But it is believed they were later joined by staff from other offices at the Treasury Hotel and Casino as the festivities stretched into the early morning when the alleged incident took place.
While the Queensland Ministerial Handbook states that some types of complaints can be referred to Queensland Police or the Crime and Misconduct Commission, matters can also be resolved informally.
However the handbook does put a specific onus on “ministers and their senior ministerial staff” in policing harassment because it can constitute official misconduct.
XML.Hansard-Body: This article is particularly interesting given that I have received numerous complaints from the Gold Coast Hospital and Robina campuses regarding bullying and intimidation of staff from Queensland Health by staff from Queensland Health and apparently those principles do not extend to similar complaints by staff in those roles as it now does for ministerial staffers. That 97.7 per cent of all complaints referred to the CMC relating to Queensland Health are then referred back to Queensland Health is preposterous. This is Caesar judging Caesar and, more often than not, those who are charged with investigating these incidents are the very same people who are responsible for the bullying and intimidation in the first place.

The next bill I will discuss is the Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010, which seeks to implement another stage of the integrity reforms and will replace the existing Whistleblowers Protection Act 1994. The integrity response provided in earlier discussions is committed to reforming the Whistleblowers Protection Act 1994 to ensure that Queensland legislation and practices are informed by present-day best practice and are of the highest standard.

I find this laughable when one of Queensland’s largest employers, Queensland Health, does not follow its own practices nor its policies and procedures. Staff who do speak out are victimised and bullied either into submission or completely out of the system. Only last sitting I rose to highlight a disgraceful example of the Bligh government’s toxic culture of bullying and intimidation which continues to permeate the Queensland public hospital system, particularly in relation to victims being blamed and whistleblowers being bullied.

I have been made aware of an allegation of a serious assault of a sexual nature by one Queensland Health employee against another. Both continue to work in the public hospital system. I focused my attention on the atrocious and unfair way Queensland Health has used and abused the performance management policy--its own performance management policy--to systematically humiliate, punish and belittle one of its own employees in the workplace in an effort to avoid dealing with this serious and difficult situation.

Queensland Health’s treatment of this employee is nothing short of negligent when the hierarchy has known of the assault allegation for three months and done nothing. Instead of supporting its employees during vulnerable times, it hangs them out to dry. Irrespective of the outcome of investigations into this claim, Queensland Health does owe a duty of care to its employees to provide a safe workplace. It has an obligation to the employee in this case to take her concerns seriously, to act compassionately without favouritism and to establish a safe and secure working environment.

Instead of supporting employees during vulnerable times, Queensland Health and its managers have acted only to avoid taking action. They have washed their hands and told this employee that it is not their problem and not their fault and even implied that the alleged serious assault ‘was a result of the employee’s own behaviour’. The employee requested secondment to less stressful duties which was coldly rejected by management, who then accused the employee of ‘blackmail’ and said that they should ‘hurry up and get over it’ and should take leave without pay or long service leave.

Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): Order!
Member, I would like you to tell me how the story is relevant. I understand that you are going down the pathway of public interest and disclosure, but I do not know if this is relevant.

Ms BATES: Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I am actually referring to the whistleblowers act. This nurse has gone through all the designated processes, has alerted her line managers to what has been going on and has subsequently now had to lodge a WorkCover claim and a grievance with Queensland Health. If Queensland Health had followed its own policies and procedures, this would not have been necessary.

The lack of support and insensitivity of Queensland Health are atrocious and clearly calculated to make the issue go away. This person has lost their dignity, wages, leave and entitlements. Morale amongst hospital staff is already abysmal, particularly when victims are victimised and whistleblowers are bullied and intimidated. Since highlighting this particular issue and another earlier this month regarding a nurse, Sue Dale, who was bullied and intimated whilst working at the Gold Coast Hospital, the culture has remained the same.

A total of 30 nurses from the Gold Coast have contacted me outlining their concerns and telling me their stories. Many are so fed up that they are happy to go public with their particular issues as they have already been dealt with unfairly by Queensland Health. I urge all nurses to continue to contact me and to continue to have the courage of their convictions, to stand up for their patients and to continue to blow the whistle on the Bligh government and its culture of secrecy, intimidation and bullying.

There is always strength in numbers and nurses standing together on this issue cannot and should not be ignored. This government relies on the fact that nurses will not strike, they seldom work to rule and at all times have the interests of their patients at heart. Nursing is a vocation, not a job. Now we see that many months after the failed pay debacle nurses are now expected to be Florence Nightingale and turn up to work in the knowledge that they will probably not be paid at the end of the fortnight and, if they are, that their pay will be incorrect. The Liberal National Party will not be opposing these cognate bills. However, we will be moving amendments in the consideration in detail stage.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP)
(3.40 pm): These bills are another example of the proud record of Queensland Labor governments in improving the accountability of government. From time to time we see this opposition impugn the actions of this government and accuse it of impropriety and corruption. The speech preceding mine from the member for Mudgeeraba is the latest disgraceful example of this practice by the opposition. Her speech was full of slurs and baseless allegations against people who are unable to defend themselves in this House. Her speech brings shame on her and the LNP.

All I can imagine is that the reason for her speech and the speeches of members before her is a guilty conscience on their part because they are the inheritors of the Bjelke-Petersen legacy of corruption and secret government. There is more than one serving member of the opposition who has identified Joh Bjelke-Petersen as his political hero. Yet those opposite have the hide to come in here and lecture government members again and again about corruption.

Sadly for the opposition the actions of this government and its predecessors prove that this government has done more to uphold and improve the accountability of government than any other in this state. Consider these actions taken by Queensland Labor governments. We have introduced estimate hearings. We ended the gerrymander by which this opposition’s predecessors systematically rorted elections in this state for decades. We created the CMC--a standing royal commission with the powers to investigate misconduct by public servants and politicians alike.

We introduced the first Freedom of Information Act into this state to give Queenslanders access to government information. We must remember that one of the motivations for introducing this act was to break down the atrocious practice of the people of Queensland being unable to access secret Special Branch files put together on them simply because they had the hide to speak up against the government of the day. In this term of government we have strengthened the FOI Act by introducing the new Right to Information Act. We have created a lobbyist register requiring lobbyists to disclose their activities. We have introduced laws to protect whistleblowers.

On any fair and objective measure there can be no doubt that this government and its predecessors have taken the accountability of government incredibly seriously. Far from just giving hollow speeches about it, we have taken action to put these sentiments into practice.

The bills currently being debated take that proud record further. They are the second stage of wide-ranging reforms to strengthen the integrity of government operations in Queensland. The Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill constitutes the first new stand-alone legislation in Queensland governing the employment and conduct of ministerial staff. In doing so, we are setting standards for ministerial staff that lead the nation.

As many members are aware, in addition to my previous jobs in the hospitality and retail industries and as an employment lawyer, for several years I worked as a ministerial adviser and as a public servant. Having sat on both sides of the adviser/public servant divide, I welcome the clarity that this bill provides for ministerial office relationships.

While much maligned, the role of ministerial adviser forms an essential part of the operations of government in the modern day. Without ministerial advisers to request independent policy advice from the Public Service, to provide political advice to ministers and to convey and oversee the fulfilment of requests of a minister, the wheels of government would grind to a standstill. In my experience, ministerial advisers in this government take their roles incredibly seriously and act responsibly in the exercise of their authority. However, it is important to put in place safeguards to ensure that these highly influential roles are always exercised appropriately. That is what this bill does.

Importantly, the bill specifically provides that ministerial staff are not empowered to direct public servants in their own right. Again, in my experience, ministerial staff respect the fact that their job is to represent the views of their minister to public servants, rather than direct public servants to do whatever they--that is, the advisers--want.

When I worked as an adviser I always found that the way to get the best out of public servants was to clearly and politely explain one’s requests by reference to the minister’s views. Equally, as a public servant, one could be confident of one’s actions if one knew that the adviser with whom one was dealing was conveying requests on the basis that they were informed of their minister’s position. I am pleased that this bill clarifies that this is to be the basis of all dealings between ministerial staff and public servants.

The only other amendment I was going to mention is the amendment proposed to the Civil Liability Act. That amendment will allow for governments to make apologies to members of the public without an admission of legal liability. Again, drawing on my own experience in government previously and as someone who often used to sign replies to members of the public who were complaining about the actions of government in some way, it was enormously frustrating that one of the things that we were sometimes advised by well-intentioned public servants was that we should not convey an apology on behalf of the government because that could risk us exposing ourselves to legal liability. I was always very frustrated by that approach because I could clearly see from reading the letters that were sent to the minister that one of the things that the member of the public most wanted was some acknowledgement of fault on behalf of a government official, whether it be a politician or a public servant. The mere expression of an apology would go a long way to repairing whatever damage had been inflicted. I am very pleased that these amendments put the ability of a government to make apologies without an admission of legal liability beyond doubt.

There are various other important amendments contained in these bills, including ones to better protect whistleblowers and to improve government accountability in other ways. In the interests of time, I will leave it to other government members to speak in favour of these amendments. I have no doubt that my fellow government members of this parliament will be able to proudly reflect on the excellent record of this and previous state Labor governments to pursue accountability of government. We have a much stronger record than those on the other side of the House. There is no doubt about that.

Mr EMERSON (Indooroopilly--LNP) (3.46 pm): Queenslanders ask themselves every day whether they can believe anything that this Labor government tells them. When we heard the previous speaker talk about his time as a ministerial adviser one doubts very much the truth involved in his speech. This government has been characterised not just by massive debt and massive deficit but also massive deceit. This is a government that has refined the art of cover-up and has been proved to have had corruption in its ministerial ranks. This is why it is so important to have effective whistleblowing laws.

Those laws need to give confidence to the community. They need to provide appropriate safeguards for those genuine whistleblowers. These whistleblowers often risk their livelihoods and place immense stress on themselves and their families to help expose the failures, the fabrications and the fraud of the government and its departments. Given the track record of this government, can the community have any doubt that Labor would do anything to attempt to protect those who have done wrong and punish those who reveal the wrongdoing.

This year we saw the conviction of former Queensland Health surgeon Jayant Patel for the manslaughter of Queensland Health patients. It was a timely reminder of the value and importance of whistleblowing. Would this tragic failure of administration at the Bundaberg Hospital have been exposed without the courage of whistleblowers like nurse Toni Hoffman?

More than 20 years ago the concerns of honest police triggered the media investigations which led to Queensland’s Fitzgerald inquiry into official corruption. It was as a result of that Fitzgerald inquiry report that Queensland became the first Australian jurisdiction to provide legislative protection to whistleblowers with the Whistleblowers Protection Act 1994. As the recent Whistling While They Work project indicated, the Whistleblowers Protection Act has now been surpassed nationally and internationally in relation to several of the most important features of statutory whistleblowing regimes.

That report found that in both practice and perception there are deficits in the Queensland laws. These include lower overall confidence in relevant legislation amongst public employees than in other jurisdictions, lower overall trust amongst public employees as to how they would expect the management of their agency to respond to an employee report of wrongdoing than in other jurisdictions studied, lower average outcomes in terms of the perceptions of whistleblowers as to how they were treated by the management of their agencies than in New South Wales or Western Australia and lower average comprehensiveness in agency whistleblowing procedures than in the other jurisdictions studied.

This Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010 is in effect a replacement for the Whistleblowers Protection Act 1994. While it is an improvement, it still provides limited protection to those who want to blow the whistle on maladministration and corruption. One of the fundamental flaws of both the whistleblowers act and this bill is that the responsibility for protecting whistleblowers may rest on those persons whose conduct and maladministration is being exposed--that is, the chief executives of government departments. But what if it is not that chief executive but another senior member of the government? There has been an increased politicisation of the Public Service under the Beattie and Bligh governments. Those heads of departments know to whom they owe their jobs. Under that regime, how confident can any whistleblower be that their concerns will be dealt with appropriately? What protection will there be for whistleblowers who go to the media as occurred more than 20 years ago in helping to trigger the Fitzgerald inquiry? Under this bill there are still only limited provisions to enable a whistleblower to complain to a journalist. They have to meet extremely strict and onerous conditions. They first have to ensure that the entity to which the public interest disclosure is made did not invest or deal with the matter or did not recommend any action in relation to the disclosure or did not notify the complainant within six months of the date of disclosure. So more than 180 days after making a complaint, a whistleblower can still not lawfully approach a journalist about the issue. That means for six months the maladministration or corruption may continue with extremely serious consequences. It may also mean that the whistleblower may be under continual and possibly intolerable stress and pressure. It also means that the timeliness of the issue may be lost, and that is exactly what a government that is expert in cover-up and spin would want. While these laws are an improvement, they are still not as effective as they should be in protecting whistleblowers.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP) (3.51 pm): I rise to contribute to the cognate debate on the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill, the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and the Public Interest Disclosure Bill before the House today. For ease of reference and so as not to confuse my learned colleagues opposite, I will speak to each bill separately. I will start with the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill. It is prudent that the issue of political influence over the Public Service is debated in the House today given the recent CMC investigation into an alleged sports rort pork-barrelling by the office of the former sports minister, the member for Sunnybank, in July 2008.

The role of departmental staff is to firstly serve the interests of the public as opposed to the interests of the government. Any advice given or action undertaken by departmental staff should always be impartial and carried out with full objectivity rather than the classic ‘Yes, Minister’ response from the popular television show of the same name. The role of all ministerial staff is to serve their respective minister. Any direction or exercise of power reserved for the minister with respect to his or her department portfolio must be treated with honour and respect for the position that the ministers should always carry. It is not something to be acted upon by a ministerial staffer or adviser who has not been appointed to such a high office of which such reservation is attributed. Clause 15 of the bill seems to be as a direct result of the CMC investigation into the alleged actions of Mr Tutt, yet the clause is contradictory in nature as it is subject to a direction of a ministerial staff member and then in another section that same ministerial staffer can give a direction to departmental staff if they are acting on behalf of a person who may lawfully give a direction. There needs to be a clarification and prescriptive processes for establishing a ministerial staffer’s authority for giving such a directive so that a public servant can make the distinction as to whether the direction is one that the ministerial staffer is able to make in the first instance.

If the government was serious about restoring integrity back into the system, then it could potentially create offences for a ministerial staffer to give a ministerial directive to a Public Service employee. Under this bill, ministerial and opposition staff are recognised as separate to the Public Service, as should be the case. But if one looks more closely at the detail of the bill, there are no changes to the employment conditions of the staff which indicates that this is an act of mere tokenism rather than any restoration of integrity into the current system. The bill states that ministerial staff will be appointed on the recommendation of the Premier and not of the relevant minister. This begs the question of loyalty and accountability of the respective minister’s office. The eminence of factionalism within the Labor Party suggests that the Office of the Premier is using the system to monitor her ministers to ensure that her position as leader of the Labor Party is not undermined by the numbers in the centre and Right factions of the Labor Party. The Premier is running scared that the faction leaders of the Labor Party will replace her as Premier in the same way as the federal leader was replaced.
Mr Watt interjected.

Mr BLEIJIE: I take the interjection from the member for Everton. One certainly does not need to sit in caucus to notice what happens. One only has to pick up any of the newspapers to see some of your own backbenchers telling us all what happens in caucus.

I will give the House a classic example of this Premier taking responsibility of ministerial staff in terms of an issue that I have been dealing with at the Montessori school in Sippy Downs. There has been an issue at that school on which we briefed departmental staff. The adviser to the minister was present. A month later we had not heard anything. We then wrote again to the minister. That ministerial staffer had been sent to another minister’s department. I then had to again bring representatives from the school down to again brief the minister’s department, and now we are on the third or fourth ministerial adviser. It is increasingly hard to deal with the tough and heavy issues in our constituencies when one books an appointment with a minister and spends quite a considerable amount of time briefing the minister’s department and then without any notice there is a new departmental staff officer or policy adviser to the minister who has to be briefed all over again. That issue with regard to Montessori school started several months ago and it is ongoing because we are now on to our third or fourth ministerial adviser whom we are briefing at the moment.

The government’s attempt to enact more integrity and accountability into the current system juxtaposes its longstanding attitude of jobs for its Labor mates and is as a result of the degradation of Public Service impartiality and political neutrality. Clause 17 of the bill applies public sector ethics under the Public Sector Ethics Act 1994 to ministerial and staff members. When applying these ethics, it is important to recognise the political function of these officers and staffers and the adversarial system in which we operate. Given this, the Office of the Premier and the Office of the Leader of the Opposition should be differentiated in terms of a code of conduct and general staff demeanour. Opposition staff are and should be accountable to the Leader of the Opposition, not the Office of the Premier. The Office of the Leader of the Opposition should be accountable to a completely separate office such as the Queensland Parliamentary Service rather than the Premier’s office. There needs to be a clear distinction between the Public Service and ministerial offices and any dealings between the two need to be conducted in a far more transparent manner. The bill before the House does not do that.

This is another example of a government that is all talk and no action. The only substance is the washing powder, and it is on a revolving spin cycle. Queenslanders need to be able to have faith that their Public Service is acting impartially in their collective best interests and not at the behest of a particular political party that is the government of the day. The Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill is another example of this government’s slogan of all talk and no action, and would anyone in Queensland believe that it is the Labor Party introducing bills into this place that contain the word ‘integrity’! Queenslanders would not believe it. Queenslanders understand that any bill introduced into this parliament by the government--the Labor Party--that contains the word ‘integrity’ is of course a way of circumventing the issues facing many Queenslanders at the moment. Again, this government is all talk and no action. It is saying, ‘Look at us, Queensland. We’re doing stuff. We’re introducing bills on integrity and accountability in parliament. We probably don’t believe any of it, but we’re still introducing it anyway. It makes a good headline.’

The bill amends several acts of which I will make mention of but a few. The amendments to the Auditor-General Act 2009 contained in the bill create an obligation for the Auditor-General with respect to making declarations of interest.

The Auditor-General’s declaration of interest will now be subject to overview not only by the Speaker of the parliament but also the Integrity Commissioner. Instead of looking for appropriate ways in which the office of the Integrity Commissioner can be expanded to promote Queensland public sector integrity and ethics, as the Bligh government purports to do, we have here a mere duplication of reporting procedures to multiple officers. A similar amendment is proposed for the Ombudsman Act 2001 with respect to the disclosures of interest of the Ombudsman. These amendments are another example of spin by a government to bring about integrity and accountability to the system, but they are nothing more than a further bureaucratic process that is more costly and far more timely.

The bill also amends the Civil Liability Act 2003 by allowing apologies to be made without being taken as an admission of legal liability. This amendment is a farce for any process of public accountability by the government. The government has a record of going broke on the back of a mining boom, losing its AAA credit rating, having a huge public debt, holding a fire sale of Queensland assets and making one stuff-up after the other. I would like to reiterate the points made by the honourable the Leader of the Opposition in relation to some of the major stuff-ups. One, of course, is the big Traveston Dam debacle. Another is the South East Queensland Water Grid, including billions of dollars wasted on a desalination program and recycled water programs. There is also the Health payroll system, which has still not been fixed, the A1GP debacle that occurred last year, which should have cost the job of the Minister for Sport, and the list goes on. This legislative amendment is designed specifically--
Mr Reeves interjected.

Mr BLEIJIE: I take that interjection. Madam Deputy Speaker, correct me if I am wrong, but we are talking about integrity in the offices. I would have thought that ministerial integrity would form some basis of this debate. This legislative amendment is designed specifically to allow the government to try to cover up its mistakes, of which there are many--too many to detail in 20 minutes--with a simple apology and no particular admission of guilt. This government is not about taking responsibility for its actions and for its mistakes; it is all about trying to save face in reaction to continual poor opinion polls. This amendment does not apply in the case of defamation, an unlawful intentional act or an unlawful sexual assault. Clearly, an apology carries with it some form of implication of guilt and responsibility and is not something that should be trivialised. By introducing this tokenistic amendment of an apology without responsibility, the government is trying to cover its tracks and trivialising the effect of what an apology means.

One major amendment in this bill should have every Queenslander concerned, and that is the amendment to the Government Owned Corporations Act 1993. The bill removes assets of government owned corporations that are being privatised from the jurisdiction of the Crime and Misconduct Commission Act 2001. The question to be asked is: why the amendment? What is the intent behind this amendment? Such an amendment would be required only if the government had something to hide. Obviously, from this amendment the government does. From the outset of the asset sales, the government has deceived the people of Queensland, and hiding this amendment in a bill titled ‘Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill’ is another act of deception.

I put it to this parliament that the members of this state Labor government are certainly the Decepticons of the Transformers’ world--continually trying to transform into something else, presenting a facade of accountability, integrity and honesty. But the result will always be the same. The government members will always be the Decepticons. Including this amendment in the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill does not mean that the amendment will have anything to do with integrity reform at all. In fact, it removes accountability with respect to the sale of the assets. The government is so determined to proceed with the sale of the assets regardless of the views of the public that it is trying to sell this amendment as a part of its so-called integrity reform. Again, that is another rort on the part of the Bligh Labor government. I know that I have used the word ‘spin’ a few times already today. I have said that the only substance in this spin is the washing powder, but it is precisely what it is: spin, spin and spin. When it comes to the polls, I say to all members on the government side of the House who have a margin of possibly seven per cent or less that there is no reverse on this spin-cycle washing machine.

The bill also amends the Public Service Act 2008 by removing the requirement to obtain an agreement by the parties prior to an appeal for it to be decided without a hearing. That means that appeals may be decided without the parties being afforded the full opportunity to be heard. Again, such an amendment should not be included in a bill purporting to be focused on integrity.

The Public Interest Disclosure Bill deals with the public interest disclosure requirements and any information that is brought to the attention of the public sector agency. The amendments require the individual agency to notify the complainant in writing as to what action will be taken. I table for the information of the House two copies of letters from the Ombudsman, Mr David Bevan, with a c.c. copy to the Law, Safety and Justice Committee. I point out to the House that the two letters have been authorised for release by the Law, Safety and Justice Committee and, therefore, do not breach the standing orders.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 24 May 2010, from David Bevan, Queensland Ombudsman, to Ms Margaret Allison, Commission Chief Executive, regarding comments in response to the proposed legislative amendments to the Public Sector Ethics Act 1994 and the reform of the Whistleblowers Protection Act 1994.

Tabled paper: Letter, dated 2 July 2010, from David Bevan, Queensland Ombudsman, to Mr Jeff Loof, Acting Commission Chief Executive, regarding the second consultation draft of the Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: In the letter dated 24 May 2010, where the Ombudsman is talking about the Public Interest Disclosure Bill, I highlight the following--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: If that is the case, as an officer of Parliament, independent of the executive government, I am strongly opposed to any proposal that the Public Service Commission be given jurisdiction to review and monitor the way in which my Office carries out any of its functions, including its function of dealing with PIDs (either individually or generally) that may be made to it under the Public Interest Disclosure Act.

Similarly, I am strongly opposed to the Public Service Commission being given jurisdiction to direct the way in which my Office is to perform its functions under the bill by way of imposing binding standards on my Office... Again, it is an inappropriate interference with the functions of an independent officer of the Parliament.
XML.Hansard-Body: Talk about accountability and integrity! We have these letters from the Queensland Ombudsman. He then goes on further in his letter of 2 July 2010--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: However, as it is clear that the government has not accepted my submissions, I will not reiterate here why I consider my proposal to provide a more effective model.
XML.Hansard-Body: Therefore, the Ombudsman limits his comments to concerns that he raised in his letter of 24 May. I table a copy of the letter and note that the tabling of those letters, as committee correspondence, has been approved by the Law, Safety and Justice Committee.
When it comes to transparency, this government clearly falls short of the mark. An example of this falling short is an amendment that provides that the disclosure to a journalist--
Mr Watt: Are you going to refer to the Premier’s reply? Are you going to be transparent?

Mr BLEIJIE: I take the interjection from the member for Everton and note that the response to which he refers has not been authorised for release. Therefore, under the standing orders I will not speak about it in parliament, because then I would be breaching standing orders. I certainly do not want the member for Everton to accuse me of that because no doubt he would be the first one to pop up from his little chair and squeak the words, ‘You have offended the standing orders. You are referring to parliamentary committee documentation that has not been authorised for release.’

As I said, when it comes to transparency, this government clearly falls short of the mark. An example of this falling short is the amendment that provides that disclosure to a journalist will be legal only if the public sector entity does not notify the complainant within six months of the complaint. A period of six months is far too long. When you consider the issue of the Queensland Health payroll system, six months is too long. In certain cases, such as the Bundaberg Base Hospital situation, six months is too long.

Today, we have heard of instances where whistleblowers have lost their jobs as a result of bringing to the attention of the public the maladministration of this government. It is such a shame that the government is so adamant about saving face and covering up its mistakes and failures that people risk losing their jobs if they speak out against it. The bills that are before the House today as part of the Premier’s so-called integrity reform are, in fact, nothing of the sort. Queenslanders will never forgive this government for the deceitful way in which it went to the election in 2009 with no mention of privatisation and then, once it was elected, it introduced the privatisation of five of Queensland’s largest assets, all in the name of the global financial crisis as if it had happened overnight. Although the Premier claims that her government will listen to the will of the electorate, her continual defiance of the public’s attitude towards asset sales is a true indication of her real position.

In closing, I will paraphrase a true classic from the recent federal election campaign: with a bandaid here and a bit of spin there, more talk, no action, here we go. Look out Queensland, Labor’s a failure with the same old Bligh slide show. On that note, I say thank you.

Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP) (4.09 pm): I rise to speak in relation to the integrity reform bill proposed by this government. Sadly, integrity seems to have been lacking within the Labor government. Last year former royal commissioner Tony Fitzgerald gave an address at Griffith University on the current state of public corruption here in Queensland and took particular aim at the government sitting just across the chamber from where I stand. In part, Mr Fitzgerald said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The current concerns about political and police misconduct are a predictable result of attitudes adopted in Queensland since the mid-1990s ... Greed, power and opportunity in combination provide an almost irresistible temptation for many which can only be countered by the near-certainty of exposure and severe punishment.

Ethics are always tested by incumbency. Secrecy was re-established by sham claims that voluminous documents were ‘cabinet-in-confidence’. Access can now be purchased ... mates and supporters are appointed and retired politicians exploit their connections to obtain ‘success fees’ for deals between business and government.
XML.Hansard-Body: That does sound very familiar. Long before the media investigations into any of this, our side of politics had been calling for a lobbyists register. We said that the government should introduce a Queensland register of lobbyists modelled on federal Labor’s scheme. Last year in Queensland, we saw the lid lifted on the jobs for mates and lobbyists rort. The media forensically dissected just who was who in the zoo. We saw that former Queensland Labor Treasurer Terry Mackenroth and former federal Labor MP Con Sciacca received a success fee of nearly $500,000 for providing advice to the successful Thiess backed Airport Link consortium. Subsequent to the exposure Mr Sciacca resigned from a government board. He resigned after 2 years as chairman of Forestry Plantations Queensland, one of the government owned assets lined up and sold as part of this Labor government’s assets fire sale.
On 6 August 2009 the Premier issued a media release. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Accountability and transparency in public administration is at the heart of robust democracy. As Premier, I believe government has a duty to continually reform and adjust to the evolving expectations of the people they represent.
XML.Hansard-Body: In a state of panic over what was being revealed, the Premier released a public discussion paper. The Premier was cynically pretending that she was unaware of what the community expects from its government when it comes to integrity. But we can go back further in examining what integrity means to this Labor government. In an earlier episode of ‘Underbelly: Labor’ we met the character Gordon Nuttall MP, the once golden haired minister of the Beattie Labor government--a real good old-fashioned brown paper bag crook. In July last year Nuttall was found guilty on 36 charges involving $360,000 of secret corrupt payments during his time as a Queensland Labor government minister. But let us not forget that the Labor government health minister Gordon Nuttall was also up to his neck in the tragic Jayant Patel disgrace. He lied and pretended publicly in this very parliament that he was not aware of the truth about Patel. The Labor government of the day was happy to accommodate Nuttall on that issue. In December 2005, then Premier Peter Beattie told this House--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We are not going to simply have a media feeding frenzy to destroy someone when there is not a basis to do it. If there was a basis to sack Gordon Nuttall I would have sacked him, but there is not.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Even Rob Schwarten got in on the act, jumping to Nuttall’s defence. Let me quote the ‘minister for silver spoons’--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There is not one skerrick of evidence to say that former minister Nuttall deliberately misled that estimates committee. There is no piece of evidence available to this parliament or anywhere else.
XML.Hansard-Body: Minister Schwarten believed that Nuttall was an innocent man. Back in July, instead of facing the media over the Auditor-General’s report into CorpTech’s involvement in the bungled Queensland Health payroll system he was having a five-star lunch with the union heavies, who were no doubt paying. With his department’s integrity under the spotlight, the Premier and Deputy Premier kept the minister away from media questions about CorpTech. I wonder how many nurses had five-star lunches that day.

As mentioned earlier and within this bill, on 6 August 2009 the government released the discussion paper Integrity and accountability in Queensland to prompt public discussion on integrity and accountability issues and seek public input on proposals for integrity reform. Following consideration of public submissions and the advice of a round table of experts, the government released the Response to Integrity and accountability in Queensland on 10 November 2009. The response committed to a number of integrity and accountability reforms to strengthen Queensland’s integrity framework, including: creating statutory obligations for members of parliament and statutory office holders to declare their interests; amending the Civil Liability Act 2003 to allow for apologies by government departments without admission of legal liability; and introducing a single code of conduct for the Public Service, including necessary amendments to the Public Sector Ethics Act 1994.
In relation to the amendments to the Civil Liability Act 2003, proposed new section 72B states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The purpose of this part is to allow a person to make an apology about a matter without the apology being construed or used as an admission of liability in relation to the matter.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Proposed new section 72D states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (1) An apology made by or on behalf of a person in relation to any matter alleged to have been caused by the person--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) does not constitute an express or implied admission of fault or liability by the person in relation to the matter; and
(b) is not relevant to the determination of fault or liability in relation to matter.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (2) Evidence of an apology made by a person is not admissible in any civil proceeding as evidence of the fault or liability of the person in relation to the matter.
XML.Hansard-Body: That seems to me like the government putting yet another restriction upon scrutiny of its liability arising from incidents such as Patel. This part even makes it inadmissible for nurses to present the weak-kneed apologies of the health minister and various Health bureaucrats in any civil action against Queensland Health over the pay debacle.

The problem for this current state Labor government is that it cherry-picks the subjects about which it feels integrity is an issue. However, it is not just about brown paper bags, jobs for the boys and doing business on a wink and a nod with former Labor Party people turned lobbyists. It is also about the integrity of doing the best for the community, doing what it can to help the public get through day-to-day life. But what have we seen from this Labor government in recent years? It tries to pretend that it is none of its doing. We have heard the health minister stand in front of the media when addressing the nurses pay scandal and say, ‘Don’t blame me. I’m just the minister.’ And we have heard Minister Robertson when quizzed on electricity say, ‘It’s not our fault. It’s the independent regulator.’ Now in relation to water bills the same minister says, ‘It’s nothing to do with us. It’s the councils’ fault.’ Yet every one of the monumental debacles happening year after year, day after day is indeed the result of this government’s contempt for the public. It has the gall to talk about integrity. But rest assured that the people of Queensland are waiting with bated breath for the next episode of ‘Underbelly: Labor.’

Ms JARRATT (Whitsunday--ALP)
(4.17 pm): I rise to support the cognate bills before the House and welcome the opportunity to participate in the debate on these landmark bills that continue to give form to the Bligh government’s commitment to integrity and accountability in Queensland. Of course, this is not the first time that such matters have been at the centre of debate in this House. While I would like to say that it has ever been so, that is of course not the case. There was a long, dark period of government under the direction of one Johannes Bjelke-Petersen when corruption thrived and various attempts by the media and the Labor opposition to throw a spotlight on this activity met with arrogant dismissal by the government and, according to Tony Fitzgerald in his introduction to the report on the Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, the community had become indifferent to these allegations.

Indeed, in their great read The Ayes Have It , John Wanna and Tracey Arklay point out that as far back as the early 1980s the Labor opposition had begun to attack the Bjelke-Petersen government over corruption and misconduct issues. The then opposition spokesperson for police and prisons, Kev Hooper, regularly raised allegations relating to drug trafficking, prostitution, illegal gambling and SP bookmaking. History records that even these revelations made within this House failed to move a single member of the National Party or the Liberal Party, either inside or outside of the parliament, let alone the Premier, to raise a finger to genuinely investigate the allegations. Fitzgerald explains that when such issues were raised by the media the police spokesperson routinely ground out stereotyped denials and hit back at critics.

It was not until May 1987, following the ABC’s screening of a documentary The Moonlight State , that a crack appeared in the wall of silence that had been set up by a corrupt government and its cronies within the police force. The rest, as they say, is history, but it does us good to think about how easily corruption can flourish when there is no commitment to integrity or accountability.

Many things have changed since the dark days of Bjelke-Petersen’s reign of corruption, but that does not mean that there is no need to regularly revisit and strengthen the laws and conventions that govern public integrity and accountability. This process is necessary in order to give the public of this state confidence that we will never again spiral down into the abyss of corruption that will forever define the Bjelke-Petersen years.

As a new Premier with a new mandate, Anna Bligh wasted no time in expressing her determination that integrity and accountability would form the cornerstone of her program for reform. On 6 August last year, the Queensland government released a discussion paper titled Integrity and accountability in Queensland around which a robust discussion and consultation program was rolled out. The government’s response paper identified a range of legislative and administrative changes that had regard to four key principles: strong rules, strong culture, strong scrutiny and strong enforcement. We have already seen the first phase of reforms passed by the parliament and enacted to establish more stringent guidelines for the regulation of the lobbying industry. These measures included banning cash for access arrangements and creating a register of lobbyists to be overseen by the Integrity Commissioner.

These latest reforms, which are before the House today, extend the quality of accountability and the demand for integrity to a whole new, never before seen standard. Importantly, the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill institutes a statutory requirement for members of parliament to provide declarations of interest for the Register of Members’ Interests and Register of Related Persons’ Interests. While these have, till now, been requirements under standing orders, these amendments enshrine this standard in legislation. Other amendments go to further strengthening lobbying regulations by requiring that unregistered lobbying activity be reported to the Integrity Commissioner and establishing a new set of warnings and suspensions to deal with breaches of lobbying regulations.

The Public Interest Disclosure Bill delivers on the government’s commitment to reform whistleblowers protection legislation. For the first time in Queensland, whistleblower protection will be extended to disclosure to the media if the matter has been first taken to, but not resolved by, the appropriate public sector entity.

The new Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill lays down a formal legislative framework which recognises the realities of the working relationship that exists between ministers or other office holders, including the opposition office, and their staff. Importantly, it makes clear that, while ministerial officers will interact with the Public Service for a variety of quite legitimate reasons, they may not direct them. In addition, ministerial staff will be required to provide annual declaration of interest statements and abide by a code of conduct.

Being a member of parliament can sometimes feel like one of those dreams--or nightmares--when you suddenly find yourself naked in a public place with all your private bits exposed to the eyes of the world. We are required to be entirely transparent about things that other people would consider to be private affairs. But we are also charged with writing and setting in motion the laws of the state, and there are governments still in this world today that use that power to further personal gain or political advantage.

By raising the standards of accountability for members of this parliament we choose to remove the potential for human weakness and generate public confidence in the integrity of members of this place and those who work with or for us. I commend the bills to the House.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (4.23 pm): There is a lot in these cognate bills that I could speak on today. There is the establishment of yet another paid advisory committee through clause 33 of the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill--another paid committee for Labor mates; there is a new requirement for QAS officers to declare that they have been subject to serious disciplinary action in the past; there is the rather bizarre requirement for the Auditor-General and Ombudsman, the independence and authority of either having rarely been questioned, to now declare their interests with oversight provided by the Integrity Commissioner; and there are the changes to the Civil Liability Act that will enshrine in legislation that saying sorry cannot be taken as an admission of legal liability.

I know the opposition leader and the member for Kawana have both identified a number of questionable cases where such legislation would clearly protect this disastrous Bligh government. Given that my colleagues have covered many of these amendments in detail, let me return more specifically to the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill.

Through a 12-year career in the Commonwealth and Queensland public services, one principle sat front and centre in every action I undertook: that I was to provide frank and fearless advice to the government of the day. That meant that, regardless of my personal views or my personal political persuasions, I worked tirelessly for the government of the day. So for four years I worked for the Howard coalition government in the Commonwealth Department of Defence and for the subsequent eight years, for the Beattie-Bligh government here in Queensland. I know that principle guides many, if not all, of my former Public Service colleagues, as it should. As was written in the Courier-Mail editorial--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: THE essence of good policymaking lies in the relationship between the bureaucracy and the government of the day.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The editorial continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That relationship is always a balancing act.

Bureaucrats need to preserve their independence and capacity to provide frank advice while making sure they are implementing the policies of the government. Ministers and their staff need to ensure their political imperatives are met without compromising the impartial role the Public Service should play in formulating policy.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Let me reiterate that last comment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Ministers and their staff need to ensure their political imperatives are met without compromising the impartial role the Public Service should play in formulating policy.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: There is no question that public administration and government is getting more challenging and complex and keeping that balance is increasingly difficult. However, difficulties should not result in an abdication of those principles.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is clear that not all ministerial staff working for this Bligh Labor government have been able to overcome these difficulties. As outlined in that same editorial--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Crime and Misconduct Commission inquiry into the behaviour of Simon Tutt, former police minister Judy Spence’s chief-of-staff, heard enough evidence to suggest that the dealings some ministerial staff have with public servants and the attitude they display are not only far from ideal but also interfere with good governance.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Such behaviour is not acceptable. Not only is it not acceptable, it is deplorable and must not be allowed to continue.
