The fact that a senior public servant, Deputy Director-General Craig Mathieson, whom I happen to know from my own Public Service career in the north coast region, felt sufficiently pressured by the then minister for police’s office that he increased the proposed grant in question by $200,000 is indicative of a sickening change--
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr HOOLIHAN: I rise to a point of order. In relation to the report that has been mentioned, there is an article in today’s newspaper. But that says that it is a draft report and it is a leaked report. I would suggest that the member is treading on very dangerous ground in dealing with that report until the report is, in fact, tabled in this House.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): Order! I agree and I ask the member to move on.

Mr POWELL: It is a sickening change in the dealings between a once independent Public Service and the political beings of the minister’s office. There must be a renewed effort to establish ground rules so that all parties know where they stand. The editorial continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is a bigger deal than ensuring a degree of courteousness and professionalism.
XML.Hansard-Body: If staffers believe they can instruct public servants at will or, worse, claim they are acting on their minister’s behalf when they are not, then it is plain they need to be pulled into line. If they believe they are able to act this way with senior public servants, then the integrity of public administration is in deep trouble.

I appreciate that clause 15 of this bill endeavours to do this. However, I am not sure it will achieve its intended objective. Rather, it may confuse the matter even further. As the opposition leader highlighted, in an attempt to overcome the Tutt situation of a ministerial adviser giving a direction to a public servant, this bill provides that a public servant cannot be subjected to a direction of a ministerial staff member. Yet clause 15(2) goes on to provide that the same ministerial staff member can give a direction to a public servant if he is acting on behalf of a person who may lawfully give a direction. As stipulated by the opposition leader, what public servant, faced with a direction from a ministerial staff member, is going to ask that staff member whether he or she is acting on behalf of the minister in giving such a direction? Only a public servant who has no interest in a long-term career would be so bold as to ask such a question of a ministerial staff member and seek to establish whether that ministerial staff member is, indeed, properly authorised by the minister.

The same concern was also highlighted by the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee. Section 4(3) (c) of the Legislative Standards Act provides that whether legislation has sufficient regard to rights and liberties of individuals depends on whether, for example, the legislation allows the delegation of administrative power only in appropriate cases and to appropriate persons. Whilst the explanatory notes attempt to justify the breach of fundamental legislative principles contained in clause 15, the committee remains concerned, stating--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Delegation of administrative power regarding the management of the department to a “staff member” may be a delegation in an inappropriate case or to an inappropriate person.
XML.Hansard-Body: The committee was so concerned that they invited the Premier to provide information regarding the consistency of clause 15 with section 4(3) (c) of the Legislative Standards Act and how the proposed provision would work in practice, including whether the delegation of administrative power needs to be in writing. I note that the Premier has replied to the committee’s concerns, but has done little more than rehash the explanatory notes. As for the practical implementation of the clause, the Premier writes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A key function of Ministerial staff is to communicate with public servants about Ministerial views or decisions. While it would not be practicable for formal authorisations or written delegations to be made by Ministers for every communication entered into between Ministerial staff and public service employees, the extent of authority and the types of work to be performed by individual staff members would be determined in accordance with contracts of employment and day-to-day work management processes. As staff members would not be delegated any formal authority over the management of a department it is therefore not considered that the Bill allows any inappropriate delegation of administrative power.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I am sorry, but I am still not clear how a public servant will know, as clause 15(2) states, that the same ministerial staff member can give a direction if he is acting on behalf of a person who may lawfully give a direction.
XML.Hansard-Body: Therefore, I close by reiterating the calls of the Integrity Commissioner, Dr Solomon, who said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is the place to spell out that advisers cannot direct public servants in their own right and cannot use their minister’s name if they do not have the minister’s specific approval.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This is too important an arena for us to be unclear in our legislation. If our intent is to legislate what has been established by convention over many years, then let us get it right the first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (4.31 pm): I rise to participate in the debate on the three bills currently before the House: the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010, the Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010 and the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2010. The Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010 is overdue. I congratulate the minister on introducing this bill and I certainly intend to support it. I believe it clarifies the roles and responsibilities of staff, whether they be employed by a government minister, an opposition member of parliament or a member of the crossbenches. I intend to put some questions to the minister during the committee stage of the debate in relation to the employment of staff. I will leave that to the consideration-in-detail stage of the debate.

In relation to the Public Interest Disclosure Bill and the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, I certainly support the proposal to enable a minister of the government to make an apology without the apology being used as an admission of liability. My experience has been that there are many unfortunate situations where things occur and an apology is certainly justified and warranted, but for a range of legal reasons it is not provided. Often the family directly affected is asking simply for an apology. Therefore, I congratulate the government on this initiative. I will endeavour to support that component in those two bills. However, I will reserve my decision on how I propose to vote on the bills until after I hear how the Premier responds to the matters raised by other members of the House and those raised in my contribution.

I am aware of how quite a few middle management staff in the Queensland Public Service operate. Recently, I had occasion to study the Queensland government code of conduct. My understanding is that the government of the day made a decision and the middle management staff were very zealous, committed and passionate in making sure that the government’s intention was achieved. Some members of the junior staff contacted me and that filtered back to middle management. I will not mention the department involved, but the department officers will know about whom I am talking. Lo and behold, the middle management quoted the code of conduct to the junior staff, indicating that it was totally inappropriate for the staff to share their concerns about what was happening in the department. Therefore, I am aware of the current code of conduct and the way it has been used to put pressure on staff not to share with members of parliament the concerns that they genuinely and rightly have.

I recall an occasion under a former government when a former Minister for Health attended a public meeting at Nambour Hospital and, basically, read the riot act to staff. He said, ‘How dare you share your concerns with members of parliament.’ His words were, ‘Get on board or get off the ship.’ That minister is no longer with us. You could have heard a pin drop in that meeting of dedicated and committed nurses and health workers at Nambour Hospital. It was disappointing that the media was not there. We were expecting our new Health Minister--it was the former member of parliament who is now in jail--to come to Nambour to say, ‘The government is here to work with you, to share the load and to try to respond to the great pressures our hospital staff are facing’, but instead he read them the riot act. Basically, he said, ‘Stop talking and stop complaining.’ I raised this issue with the minister and said, ‘With respect, Minister, the staff who have been sharing concerns with me have not been trying to tip a bucket on the government, but are simply trying to share their anxiety and their concerns about the level of health care of the people they are entrusted with caring for.’ Unfortunately, it did not go anywhere.

I am aware of other state government departments that, over the years, have used a range of strategies to put significant pressure on junior staff to prevent, hinder or stop them from talking about their genuine concerns with members of the opposition and members of the crossbenches. The bills before the House talk about freedom and flexibility to share concerns with the media. Clauses 12 and 13 of the Public Interest Disclosure Bill contain significant amendments. The government goes out of its way to say how a member of the Public Service is able to share their concerns about maladministration and official misconduct with members of parliament. Clause 45 is headed, ‘Reasonable management action not prevented’. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Nothing in this part is intended to prevent a manager from taking reasonable management action in relation to an employee who has made a public interest disclosure.

However, a manager may take reasonable management action in relation to an employee who has made a public interest disclosure only if the manager’s reason for taking the action does not include the fact that the person has made a public interest disclosure.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The clause then defines ‘manager’ and ‘reasonable management action’. I quote that clause because I believe, effectively, it is a way out for middle management bureaucrats who want to get their way for a range of reasons. They will be able to use that clause to put significant pressure on staff who would otherwise like to share their genuine concerns with a member of parliament.
XML.Hansard-Body: I understand there are significant challenges and real difficulties in getting the evidence that is needed to prove that a manager has abused their position. If this bill becomes law, such a manager could use proposed section 45 to try to intimidate, manipulate or pressure a junior staff member. The reality is that most middle and senior managers are very intelligent and competent people, otherwise they would not hold those positions. They have achieved those positions in the Public Service because of a demonstrated ability to get results. Therefore, at this stage I flag to all members that I will introduce an amendment to this bill to delete clause 45. I believe most public servants are good law-abiding people. They want to see good outcomes for the various departments they work in. I believe this clause is simply an easy way out for those competent intelligent middle management and senior management people to use their position of influence to get rid of or put influence on the very people that the Public Interest Disclosure Bill is intended to protect and give freedom to.

Another concern I have in relation to these two bills is that I believe they are simply building a bigger bureaucracy in our Queensland Public Service. They are building a massive bureaucracy, and I really wonder whether that is necessary. We talk about the whistleblower legislation. I have concerns with these remaining two bills. I am aware of how public servants are able to manipulate and influence junior staff so that they do not share their genuine concerns with members of parliament. I believe that we should be directly encouraging public servants to share their genuine concerns with members of parliament, irrespective of whether they are members of the government, opposition or crossbenches. We have all been elected to represent our constituents in Queensland to the best of our ability. I genuinely believe that removing clause 45 will put significant pressure on middle management to curtail their potential to use that clause to bully, if I can use that word, members of the Public Service who want to share genuine concerns with members of parliament. I resume my seat and wait to hear the Premier’s reply. I look forward to these three bills proceeding to the committee stage.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (4.40 pm): I rise to join the debate on the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010, the Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010 and the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2010. These bills were introduced on 3 August by the Premier and Minister for the Arts as the second stage of the Bligh Labor government’s suite of legislative reform announced in the November 2009 Response to Integrity and accountability in Queensland . Before lunch today I listened as the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Surfers Paradise, began his debate on these bills. From the moment he got to his feet and uttered some home truths about this shabby Labor government, the heckling and harassment from government members was unleashed--just like a pack of wild animals. They can dish it up but they cannot take it.

Journalist Ruth Limkin wrote an article for the Courier-Mail in July 2009 that explained that by googling the word ‘integrity’ you find 66,500,000 results. There is apparently no shortage of integrity online, but, unfortunately, it is lacking from this Labor government. In an admission of its failings, in August 2009 the government released a discussion paper, Integrity and accountability in Queensland . The idea of government reform sparked a sizeable response, with 240 submissions officially accepted from a variety of stakeholders. Members of the public, legal professionals, professors, numerous organisations, the Clerk of the Parliament, the Crime and Misconduct Commission and even the Queensland branch of the Australian Labor Party were among those whose contributions to the highly contentious topics of accountability and integrity were chosen for public consumption on the Premier’s website. The Clerk of the Queensland Parliament, who is held in high regard, made the following opening comment in his submission--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: If we are to learn anything from our 150-year history as a colony and state, it is that an absence of scrutiny, accountability and transparency will lead, inevitably, to an absence of proper administration.
XML.Hansard-Body: He argues that the current system fails to meet the needs of the state, especially since the abolition of the Legislative Council in 1922. No wonder the Clerk and others were concerned. A brief glance at Premier Bligh’s history reveals a series of appalling examples of what the Premier considers to be an open, transparent and accountable government. Here are just a few.

In January 2006, then Acting Premier Bligh announced that the Labor government would introduce laws to make it legal for her and other ministers to deliberately tell untruths to parliamentary committees. In January 2008, Premier Bligh appointed confessed electoral cheat Mike Kaiser as her chief of staff. Mr Kaiser had previously been forced to resign from parliament in disgrace. He has now left the Premier’s employ with a promise of more money and her blessing to work with NBN Co. In January 2009, it was revealed that members of the Queensland Labor Party were pocketing hundreds of thousands of dollars in so-called ‘success fees’ for winning government contracts. Ms Bligh had sat around the cabinet table approving projects that incurred success fees. Among the recipients was her former Labor cabinet colleague Terry Mackenroth, along with former federal Labor MP Con Sciacca. In July 2009, it was revealed that the Bligh government had illegally accepted a $225,000 election donation from the powerful union the CFMEU.

In September 2009, the LNP released an issues paper, Integrity and accountability in Queensland: a blueprint to end Bligh Labor’s corruption and cronyism . This was followed by a private member’s bill, the Criminal Code (Honesty and Integrity in Parliament) Amendment Bill 2009. It is because of an unwavering and genuine commitment to restoring integrity to parliament that the opposition continues to call for the end of sloppy, underhand practices in this House. Over 20 members of the LNP stood up to support this bill, but the government’s contribution to that debate was pathetic. A total of five Labor members chose to speak against it and the rest voted it down.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ryan): Order! Member for Currumbin, the Speaker has on a number of occasions mentioned that there are various reasons that members of this House may speak or not speak on a bill. I think you should avoid those matters and proceed with your speech.
Mrs STUCKEY: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will make sure that I do not name anybody who chooses not to speak on a bill.

Mr HOOLIHAN:
Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise to a point of order. I submit that the Speaker’s ruling was not a matter of naming persons; it was a matter of standing orders preventing any reflection.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Member for Keppel, there is no point of order. The member for Currumbin has the call.

Mrs STUCKEY: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think it would be very useful if the member provided what he was talking about. I am sure that when the next election comes around constituents will be reminded of who supported various policies. If Queenslanders want a true revelation of what members of this Bligh government think about providing integrity and accountability to the people of Queensland, then it is important for my constituents to look at the speaking list and see who spoke on this bill.

The first stage of the Bligh government’s reform was introduced in November 2009 under the auspices of the Integrity Bill 2009, which, among other things, created the stand-alone Office of the Integrity Commissioner, banned the payment of success fees and created a register for lobbyists. As I mentioned in my speech on the Integrity Bill 2009, the first stage of supposed reform did little to offer any substantial changes to prevent corruption, cronyism and unethical behaviour of ministers of government and in elections. Not surprisingly then, these bills before the House today, which together introduce a host of reforms and amendments to about a dozen acts of parliament, have been tossed together in this cognate debate, reducing honourable members’ time to address them individually. Nevertheless, the opposition this morning agreed to pursue this approach.

Objectives of each of the bills are as follows. The Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010 will create a new stand-alone framework for the employment of staff members to support ministers, the Leader of the Opposition and, where necessary, other non-government members of parliament. This framework will act separately to the Public Service Act 2008. This bill provides a specific communique that ministerial staff do not have the power to direct public servants, an action promised by the government in its January 2010 submission to the CMC inquiry into the issue of interaction between ministers, ministerial staff and public servants.

Notably, the CMC’s inquiry was initiated in response to allegations of misconduct involving former ministerial adviser Simon Tutt to then police minister Judy Spence in the sports rort claim involving $4.2 million of taxpayers’ money. It is a concern of the LNP that this bill does not go far enough to clarify and may even increase the uncertainty of the roles of ministerial staff. As it stands, this bill does little to reflect the reality of established practices and relationships between ministerial staff and public servants. Even more alarmingly, it fails to eliminate the ingrained culture of abuse of power that led to a public inquiry into the behaviour of Tutt and his fellow ministerial staff.

If it truly is the government’s intention to prevent ministerial staff from giving directions to public servants, then this should be a concrete provision in the bill, but sadly it is not. Confusion prevails with the provision that a public servant cannot be subject to a direction from a ministerial staff member, unless they are acting on behalf of a person who may lawfully give a direction. For example, a minister will still be allowed to give direction to the chief executive of their department.

Furthermore, it is outrageous that this bill places direct responsibility for the appointment of opposition staff with the director-general of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet. As the member for Surfers Paradise stated earlier, the opposition is in no way part of the government. It is a fundamental element of the Queensland parliament, and control of staff should be placed with the Queensland Parliamentary Service--an impartial body, unlike the government’s chief executive--to ensure fair and unbiased decisions are made. I note that a number of LNP members have raised these concerns.

The Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010 will, in effect, replace the Whistleblowers Protection Act 1994. According to the Premier’s second reading speech, this bill builds upon the framework established under the existing Whistleblowers Protection Act and maintains the protections and rights of disclosers. It could be argued this bill is simply putting a new name to an old face.

The fundamental problems that exist with the current Whistleblowers Protection Act have managed to weasel their way into this replacement bill. It would seem the Bligh government has made no significant attempt to initiate substantial reform. Namely, the responsibility for protecting whistleblowers is placed upon the very persons who are often the subject of contravening activities.

This bill does permit public servants to leak their concerns to journalists in certain circumstances. However, these circumstances are an avenue of last resort where attempts to have the matter resolved internally have failed. In reality, this means a whistleblower can go to the media only after the required six months for response has expired, leaving any value to their claims stale, dated and, quite possibly, no longer in the public interest. This is a classic example of Labor camouflage and subterfuge, designed to deter the very people to whom it is meant to provide avenues of help.

The culture of fear created by this government extends beyond the Public Service. Perceived or otherwise, there is a very real fear factor amongst many people who have complaints with the BSA. Only last night I had a gentleman on the phone who contacted me on behalf of another couple who were too terrified to call me directly because they were worried that if the BSA found out that they were contacting me they would somehow be persecuted. I received a submission yesterday to my discussion paper from a couple who wanted to contribute and share their own experiences. This morning I received an anxious email from this couple begging me not to reveal their identity as they feared that the BSA would find out and punish them. It is really sad when situations like this abound and governments become extremely defensive about these behaviours. Consumer protection is everybody’s business as is child protection.

Now I will make a few comments regarding the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2010 that proposes amendments to a number of acts including the Ambulance Service Act 1991, the Auditor-General Act 2009, the Civil Liability Act 2003, the Fire and Rescue Service Act 1990, the Government Owned Corporations Act 1993, the Integrity Act 2009, the Ombudsman Act 2001, the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001, the Public Sector Ethics Act 1994, the Public Service Act 2008, the Public Service Regulation 2008 and the Right to Information Act 2009.

It is really astonishing to see the lengths this government will go to to remove itself from liability as a result of its poor decisions, inaction and lack of governance. The proposed amendments to the Civil Liability Act 2003 to allow government departments to apologise without admission of legal liability will shamefully assist the government in admitting to the enormous array of faults and maladministration which have led to some of Queensland’s worst public crises.

Need I remind the House of the incompetent governance and subsequent denials by the members for Lytton and Rockhampton that resulted in thousands of Queensland Health workers denied pay or experiencing deficient pay cycles for the past six months. Queensland was in the news nationally for all the wrong reasons, as this Health payroll fiasco exploded and the Premier had to undertake damage control by putting an urgent halt to all human resource and payroll programs across her government departments. While she overruled the Minister for Public Works and stripped him of his power in this area, she refused to hold him accountable for his negligent leadership which allowed this awful situation to unfold. Just where is the accountability here?

Six months on and the situation is still not resolved, with countless alterations needing to be made to health workers’ pays each fortnight. Since September last year the opposition repeatedly alerted Queenslanders of the impending failures of this payroll system. Countless people’s lives have been upturned needlessly by the incompetence of this Bligh government and its ministers. They will not forget when it is time to cast their vote at the polls.

But now the government’s answer to all of this is to again flex its power muscle to avoid fallout, just as it did in 2006 when it recalled the parliament to remove the offence of telling complete and utter untruths in the Legislative Assembly from the Criminal Code to protect the unforgivable and illegal acts of a former minister--a mate whom many who are still elected members praised for his good character.

Tony Fitzgerald’s damning comments on the dangerous direction the Beattie and Bligh Labor governments were taking our great state of Queensland in July 2009 have in some way brought us to this debate today. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Access can now be purchased, patronage is dispensed, mates and supporters are appointed and retired politicians exploit their connections to obtain success fees for deals between business and government.
XML.Hansard-Body: The timing of this shameful indictment from such a respected individual would certainly suggest it was the embarrassing truth that forced the government to address its shortcomings in the area of integrity and accountability.

In summary, the LNP accept that some of the amendments within these three bills that we are debating here today are a step forward and an improvement on some aspects of current legislation. Unfortunately though, as members have heard from my LNP colleagues, the Bligh government is using this opportunity to create a fanciful delusion that it is serious about bringing integrity to the operation of Queensland’s government. The people of Queensland are not fools and they know a stunt when they see one. They have lost all confidence in the Bligh government and who could blame them. The LNP, on the other hand, is determined to return accountability and integrity to Queenslanders.

Mr HOOLIHAN (Keppel--ALP)
(4.56 pm): We are dealing with three bills in a cognate debate--the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill, the Public Interest Disclosure Bill and the Integrity Reform Miscellaneous Amendments Bill. For the benefit of members of this House, I would like to outline some things from the past that certain speakers seem to have overlooked.

Once upon a time in a galaxy very close to the state in which we presently stand there was a dark side. It was a dark side known as the National Party. All of the opposition speakers seem to have forgotten names like Austin, Lane and Harvey or Terry Lewis or the arch conspirator of the lot who ended up having to have a juror suborned so that he could get the charge thrown out. We come in here and we hear all of these comments about integrity. I do not believe that most of the speakers from the opposition so far could even spell the word.
Mrs Sullivan: Some of them weren’t even born.
Mr HOOLIHAN: I take that interjection. That is pinching my speech. These people come in and reiterate so much tripe that they believe is contributing to integrity matters.

We had the example in this House this morning of the member for Toowoomba South demanding that the Attorney-General take action against a magistrate for a decision that was reached in Toowoomba. How about this for imposing integrity on the courts? We had the Fitzgerald inquiry. The member for Currumbin can waffle on about what Tony Fitzgerald said in July 2009, but what about the reports that Tony Fitzgerald wrote in 1989 that gave us the original CJC?

Then we had the disgusting and quite outlandish approach of the Borbidge government when it appointed the Connolly-Ryan inquiry to nobble the CMC. They blew it. They did not have any sort of integrity laws. There were none. I worked in the Magistrates Court at that time and I can give members instances of where phone calls came to the magistrate stating that they had to take certain action.

I knew where they came from and I knew what they were told because I saw the end result. Even the member for Glass House, who mentioned that he had worked for 12 years under the Howard government and the Beattie-Bligh government, is not old enough to have worked under the Bjelke-Petersen government. However, some of the people who were involved with that era are still in this House. Some of them became ministers in the Borbidge government, and I refer to the disgraceful episode in terms of the Mundingburra by-election and an MOU with a certain union. Shock, horror! Should I say it was the Queensland Police Union? That was once again an endeavour to put pressure on the Police Service to act in accordance with what the government of the day wanted. Terry Lewis went to jail for that lack of integrity.

These three bills are part of the suite of legislation which arose from the Response to Integrity and accountability in Queensland . The Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill will provide a framework for employment of ministerial staff outside the Public Service so that the actual obligations and requirements of ministerial staff are set out quite differently and in quite separate roles to public servants. As we heard in the minister’s second reading speech, those staff are now employed under the Public Service Act but that does not recognise the distinct roles that they play from the rest of the Public Service. The new regime will separate them from the Public Service and the bill makes provision for an annual declaration of interest, codes of conduct for ministerial staff, the continuation of the current application of the Crime and Misconduct Commission, the Ombudsman and offences under the Criminal Code.

While dealing with offences under the Criminal Code, it is about time that those people who supposedly have some knowledge of the law and who believe that they can come into this House and slip in under the radar and become the government of Queensland, not knowing anything at all about legislation, should very quickly change the comment about the right to tell untruths to a parliamentary committee. Anyone who thinks that they can come into this House and do that has this House to answer to--no-one else. If someone misleads this House, it should be this House that imposes the penalty on the person who does that. This is one of the only jurisdictions in the Western world that imposed a criminal liability on a member of parliament. If one looks at the Criminal Code published by Sir Reginald Carter, they will see the basis on which that was put in. It was put in when the Criminal Code was written by Sir Samuel Walker Griffith because of his ongoing fight with a member of the legislature at that time who just happens to be a distant relative of mine. I will not go any further with that, but Sir Thomas McIlwraith was my great-great uncle and that was the basis for it because he had made some outlandish arrangements with the Queensland National Bank during the 1890s.

This really is one of the bills that are part of the government’s commitment to ensure appropriate frameworks are in place to guide the interactions between ministerial staff and Public Service employees. This afternoon I had the great enjoyment of being able to watch proceedings and I found that I had a much more enlightening afternoon when I watched certain of the opposition members with the volume turned down. That told me as much as what I would have found out in here. We heard from the ‘Radio WBTE’ from Kawana--WBTE, applying the American radio system, is wet behind the ears. He is not even old enough to remember Joh Bjelke-Petersen’s name, let alone walk in here and propose to talk about the integrity of members of parliament and how this will be imposed on public servants.

I turn now to the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill which will introduce a revised set of ethics and principles to form part of the Public Sector Ethics Act. That will deal with integrity and accountability, promoting public good, commitment to the system of government, and accountability and transparency. The one thing that will come out of this--and I heard the member for Nicklin mention this--is that there is a revised model for Public Service appeals, and that also relates to the Public Interest Disclosure Bill which I will deal with separately. It creates a statutory position of appeals officer and extends disciplinary provisions to all Public Service employees. There will be new obligations for certain statutory office holders to declare their interests to their ministers and the Integrity Commissioner. Who in this House would argue with that? When dealing with public money and when dealing with public confidence, which member is going to walk into this House and object to that? Hopefully no-one. The bill also introduces into the Parliament of Queensland Act a statutory requirement for members of the House to provide declarations of interest for themselves and related persons. The procedural requirements in standing orders will remain.

Comment was also made about amendment of the Civil Liability Act to allow apologies to be made without being taken as an admission of legal liability. That is already in place in a number of areas of the law. What is wrong with saying, ‘I’m sorry that this occurred’, or it may well be, ‘I’m sorry that this occurred within my department and we will ensure that it doesn’t happen again by the introduction of A, B and C as rules to abide by’? This will allow any government--not just a Labor government but any government--or any other person to acknowledge mistakes where their actions may have caused harm.

The Public Interest Disclosure Bill is a slightly different kettle of fish. Public interest disclosures have for a long time come under what was known as the whistleblowers act and people were terrified of making any sort of disclosure. This act gives them a framework to do that. The member for Nicklin mentioned his proposal to delete proposed clause 45 of the bill, but he did not read far enough, because there are sufficient safeguards and sufficient background actions allowed in that, if any action is taken in relation to reasonable management, there is still a right of appeal in order to review what has been done by a public officer.

As I said, these three bills form part of the suite of bills which will replace some old acts and enhance integrity requirements so that the people of Queensland are quite at ease with what is done in their name by members of parliament and by public servants. In terms of some of the arguments that have been raised, those people who want to raise those arguments should go back, as I said at the start, and remember those names I mentioned--Harvey, Lane, Austin, Lewis and Bjelke-Petersen. They gave us the Fitzgerald inquiry. This state has come many miles since Fitzgerald brought down his report and hopefully with the introduction of these bills we will travel a lot further. I commend the bills to the House.

Mrs MENKENS (Burdekin--LNP) (5.09 pm): These bills that we are debating this afternoon strike at the very heart of this government--a government that has been in power for too long and that has lost touch with the honesty and integrity that is required of it. It is disappointing that these bills are being debated cognately, because that does not give members enough time to really discuss them and analyse how much and how important they are.
Government members interjected.

Mrs MENKENS: It is still disappointing that they have been put together to be debated cognately. The bills that we are debating are the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010, the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2010 and the Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010. The Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010 sets up a new stand-alone framework for the employment of staff members to support ministers, the Leader of the Opposition and, where necessary, other non-government members of parliament separate from the Public Service Act 2008. Whilst there has been wide consultation, with over 200 submissions accepted to the Integrity and accountability in Queensland discussion paper, which was released in August 2009, there remain entrenched fundamental concerns about the outcome.

In relation to the employment of ministerial staff members, the Premier is the person who is charged with appointing all ministerial staff. That is the reality, as the chief executive of the Premier’s department appoints these staff members on the recommendation of the Premier. The minister for whom they will work is not part of this process. That then means that the employees remain beholden to the Premier, who has the overt factional control of all ministerial staff. As such, the Premier cannot be distanced from shouldering the responsibility for the actions of the full complement of ministerial staff.

This control by the Premier endures in relation to staff members subject to direction. Ministerial staff members are subject to directions from the Premier as well as the member for whom they are employed. Therefore, these staff are in the tenuous position of effectively having two masters. There is the potential for conflict with this arrangement relating to directions from the Premier and the employing member. The reality may be that this process could become untenable. Other staff members are merely responsible to direction from their employing member or senior staff. So there remains a concern in this overall area of direction and the resolution of conflict.

The area of employment of staff members by the Leader of the Opposition reflects the current position of contracts for opposition staff being signed by the director-general of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet. Again, there is a close linkage with the Premier in this process. The director-general of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet is a personal appointee of the Premier and the possibility for political interference is considerable. One could push the case for opposition office affairs being removed from this government control through the personal Public Service appointee of the Premier. Instead, this appointment could be controlled through an independent body such as the Queensland Parliamentary Service.

One of the critical aspects of this bill relates to staff members not being empowered to direct Public Service employees. This area can be directly attributed to trying to remedy the blatant actions of Simon Tutt. Should we need to be reminded, this incident relates to a ministerial staffer giving a direction to a public servant. Although this amendment seeks to ban the practice, it does not make the giving of such a direction by the staff member an offence. As this case is so fresh in the memory of the state government, these flagrant and self-effacing actions should be made an offence.

Clause 15(2) provides a convenient out whereby a staff member directs a public servant on behalf of a person who may give a direction, for instance a minister. An undue amount of pressure can then be placed on a public servant should they refuse to carry out the directions of a staff member on the premise that they are acting for a minister. Again, the inextricable linkage to the Premier comes into question in relation to the code of conduct and its consultation, review and compliance. This is particularly relevant in regard to interference and influence by the director-general of the Premier’s department. The director-general is personally appointed by and is responsible to the Premier for the activities of the opposition office. The code of conduct for opposition staff should be approved by the Leader of the Opposition. With regard to the area of compliance with the code of conduct, responsibility should rest with the Leader of the Opposition or a third-party agency such as the Queensland Parliamentary Service.

With regard to the consultation about and the review of the code of conduct, the chief executive of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet is required to consult with the Leader of the Opposition. There is a concern that there is no obligation on the chief executive to comply with any request from the Leader of the Opposition. The linkage of chief executive to the government cannot be underestimated in relation to being independent and it does not sit well.

The Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2010 contains a range of amendments to several acts in an effort to espouse the so-called virtues of this integrity reform package. In relation to the amendments that are made to the Ambulance Service Act 1991, there is the addition of a new section requiring any potential employee to disclose any serious disciplinary action that they may have been involved in in the past. There is also a rewrite in relation to the obligation of the Auditor-General making a declaration of interest. This amendment will diminish the historical independence and impartiality of the position of Auditor-General and the Auditor-General’s responsibility to parliament on a holistic basis.

With regard to the amendment to the Civil Liability Act 2003, there will be the insertion of a new part 1A that allows for an apology to be made without it being able to be argued to be an admission of liability by the party making the apology. This new provision will not apply in the case of defamation, an unlawful intentional act or unlawful sexual assault. This new part is sure to be used by the government in relation to its well-publicised service delivery failures and public administration issues. The government will now have a vehicle to repent for the wide-ranging failures that it has orchestrated and presided over.

In relation to the amendments that are made to the Government Owned Corporations Act 1993, one amendment raises questions and concerns. This amendment relates to the removal of assets of GOCs that are being privatised from the jurisdiction of the CMC act. A cloud hangs over this amendment. What is the driver for this amendment? Privatisation and asset sales have infuriated Queenslanders and this covert action will be questioned in terms of why it is required. This is a government and a Premier that talk big about accountability. They talk about openness and integrity, but the community certainly does not believe that anymore. The community has totally lost faith in this government to tell the truth.

Before the last election the Premier and the Treasurer hoodwinked the people of Queensland over the sale of Queensland’s assets and the public will not forget that. The people in my area saw the breakdown of the negotiations between Queensland Rail and the Queensland government over the construction of the northern missing link rail connection. There are just so many contractors who were dudded by this government with broken contracts and the let-down of expectations over this project. Many of those business owners face huge economic losses arising from this breakdown of negotiations and some have been unable to recover. Now, of course, this coal transport infrastructure is on the market along with the coal-loading facilities at Abbot Point. These facilities are major wealth generators for Queensland. Did the Premier tell us about that before the last election? Absolutely not.

Recently I spoke to the RTBU leaders in Townsville. Certainly, it was a revelation of the enormous anger that is felt right across the sector about this government letting down the community and, more than anything, letting down their very supporters. Of course, the local members in Townsville--the member for Mundingburra, Lindy Nelson-Carr, and the member for Townsville, Mandy Johnstone--have got themselves in a bit of hot water for speaking the truth, for publicly calling for a rethink on the privatisation issue. It was a brave move on their part and I say good on them for doing it. But sadly, they reverted to form once they got back in the parliament and they are again echoing the government’s line. The public really expects much more from its elected members than what it has been subjected to from the Labor government incumbency--a tired, worn-out government that has been in power for too long.

Queensland has been subjected to a litany of disgraceful issues that this government has tried to cover up, and the public has rightly had enough. We have just listened to a huge tirade from the member for Keppel, and I also note the comments by the member for Whitsunday about the anticorruption royal commission and Judge Tony Fitzgerald’s findings and comments made 20 years ago. However, both of those members omitted the views that were expressed by that same man recently in what he says will be his last political commentary. His comments then referred to the current Labor government and they were not complimentary. Mr Fitzgerald said that the prevailing political culture is amoral, anarchic, controlled by money and lacking in ethics, oversight and accountability. He said that too many politicians are motivated by power rather than public interest and that there is too much government by executive. In short, Mr Fitzgerald says our democracy is not broken but bent.

His introduction stated that the community is ill-served by this escalating transfer of power from the public to the dominant political parties and the parties’ disinterest in ethical constraints and resistance to oversight and accountability, even by independent anti-corruption bodies. Without satisfactory legal and ethical fetters the political process, like all human constructs, can be and is manipulated and exploited to advance personal and group interests. A political class has evolved which is interested in little but the acquisition and exercise of power. I must say this is a terrible indictment on this government. I would tactfully remind the member for Keppel and the member for Whitsunday that people in glass houses are in no position to throw stones.
Mr HOOLIHAN: I rise to a point of order. I find that comment offensive and I would ask that it be withdrawn.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: The member finds the words offensive. I ask that you withdraw.

Mrs MENKENS: Mr Deputy Speaker, I withdraw. In relation to the amendment of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 there is a new part, Register of Interests. This turns into statutory form the provisions of standing orders in relation to statements of interest. New members are to supply such statements within one month of taking a seat; also to supply a statement for a related person. Failure to supply will be contempt. All changes must be reported in a month. Failure to notify is contempt. All statements are to be put in the form provided for under standing orders. Giving a knowingly false or misleading statement is contempt and ‘interests’ for the purpose of the statement is to be given a wide meaning.

These obligations offer no flexibility in relation to time lines and any slight errors made by members would see them potentially referred to a parliamentary committee for contempt. It would also appear that the role of the Speaker to exercise a value judgement prior to reference to the committee is not an option. There is also an amendment that excludes local government. This amendment will see that a member of parliament cannot transact business with a state entity but may do so with a local government. The rationale behind allowing a member of parliament to have an active business relationship with a level of government that they could possibly influence seems flawed.

The Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010 has the objective of implementing the next stage of the integrity reforms and will replace the existing Whistleblowers Protection Act 1994. This is a critical bill to empower insiders--well, supposedly to empower insiders--to expose corruption and maladministration in government and its agencies and to advance the reporting and investigation of these alleged concerns. In reality it is these insiders who become the first to become aware of wrongdoing and can often be crushed by the wrongdoing they see. There must be a process that is sensitive to allow the insider to fully detail the allegations as they see it to ensure a full investigation is undertaken if it is deemed warranted. It is also noted that the disclosure can only legally be made to a journalist if the original body complained to did not notify the complainant within six months. This appears to be an inordinately long period and there should be a case to reduce this. A complainant should be able to approach a journalist if not notified within one month that the complaint is being investigated.

The section in relation to protection needs to be robust. There needs to be no overt or implied pressure or reprisals on employees who are making bona fide disclosure. It is very disappointing to see the level of fear that we are seeing right across the Public Service in so many departments. They are seeing what is happening but they are too frightened for the sake of their job to actually make disclosure.

The content of these bills does have major relevance to government but certainly it can be questioned whether the mechanisms within these bills are the best possible. I note the comments made in relation to these bills by the Leader of the Opposition and I support his position in this cognate debate.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind)
(5.24 pm): I rise to contribute briefly to the cognate debate on the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010, Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 2010 and the Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010. This is a cognate debate, as many members have made comment on. From the start I would like to reiterate the position that I adopted this morning, along with the other Independents, that we do not believe that this should be a cognate debate. Every piece of legislation in this cognate debate should be considered on its own merits. This cognate debate involves three important pieces of legislation with many clauses and divisions all squeezed into one rushed debate and pushed through this chamber. This style of cognate debate would not be happening in the federal parliament where the Independents hold the balance of power. I doubt very much that Independents would put up with a situation where, with minimal consultation, such significant bills are rushed through parliament.

If, after the next state election, I am lucky enough to be returned to this place and I am part of a group of Independents who hold the balance of power, which all the political experts seem to be predicting is going to happen, if this type of political stunt is pulled I will be voting against this cognate legislation just on the principle that it is cognate legislation and it is being rushed through parliament and therefore by its very nature there is less scrutiny and transparency. The Independents could act as the de facto upper house. Especially in a unicameral parliament there needs to be more scrutiny of legislation. We have heard many times how legislation gets to this House. Well, quite frankly, by the time the legislation reaches this chamber the debate is done and dusted. No matter how good a speech we make in this place, it does not matter what we say, the government will use its numbers to force the issue. Effectively what we have in the Queensland parliament is an elected dictatorship.

What will happen if the numbers are more balanced within this chamber is that there will be greater consultation on legislation before it even reaches this chamber. That will be a good thing for the people of Queensland, the mums and dads, and especially the workers for the Queensland government who have so much at stake with these three bills.

Member after member of the LNP stood to their feet and made very articulate speeches, the majority of which have actually punched holes in and torn this government’s cognate debate to shreds. The member for Surfers Paradise, who has the benefit of a very well resourced office of highly paid and intelligent researchers, said this was an attempt by the government to cloak itself in righteous garb. I agree with him. He said the bill is a reaction to an embarrassing incident. I agree with him. It is action, not words, that shows how a government works. ‘Why is the government pursuing ambulance officers after they have left the service?’, were the sorts of comments made by the member for Surfers Paradise. Then at the end of his speech he said something that absolutely nearly knocked me off my chair. I may have got it wrong and I am prepared to be corrected, but he said that he and the LNP would support this legislation. That was after he delivered a magnificent speech that ripped this legislation to shreds. How can an opposition that has comprehensively established an argument to oppose this legislation then indicate that it will fail to oppose the legislation when it is time to come to a vote?

The member for Mudgeeraba urged nurses to have the courage of their convictions and go to her with public interest disclosures. How can nurses have the courage of their convictions and make public interest disclosures to the LNP when members of the LNP fail to show they have the courage of their convictions in this place?

The member for Kawana cried, ‘Spin, spin, spin!’ Yet this morning he was happy to cuddle up with Labor and vote with them when they were allowing this bill to be passed through this chamber as a cognate debate. In disrespecting this chamber and the rules of this chamber and using this chamber as a plaything, as they did this morning when the LNP had an opportunity to take a stand against the Labor Party, are they worried about the government sending out a few press releases saying that the opposition opposed three dodgy bills that were rushed through this parliament? If we have the arguments in this chamber then surely we can prosecute those arguments out in our own electorates, out before our people and before the journalists who ring us and say, ‘Why did you vote this particular way?’ Surely if we have strong words in here, those strong words should follow us out into the community and we should be proud to stand up for those views that we articulate in here.

Many people in this debate have referred to Toni Hoffman and the great work that she has done and the sacrifice she has made. She deserves every accolade, every medal, every word of praise because she risked everything. This government still treats her in an appalling way. Every Labor member of this chamber should hang their head in shame for the way that she has been left now. I have brought to this chamber many times, repeated times, the circumstances in which this brave whistleblower has found herself after undergoing the ordeal of two royal commissions and a significant criminal trial. Yet this government still prefers to ignore the plight of Toni Hoffman. Today might be a good day to send a message to all the Labor members here, who all have their heads bowed, as they should, that it is time now to bring some justice to Toni Hoffman, to care for her. Why did she have to use all her recreational leave to give evidence or to prepare to give evidence to the two royal commissions and to the criminal trials? We have an opportunity right now. Instead of listening to history lessons from those opposite about the bad old days, how about dealing with the circumstances of the bad old days that are facing us right now? Right now there is a whistleblower who has been shoddily looked after, poorly treated, and we can remedy that situation from now if we have the support of those members opposite.

I remember the day when Toni Hoffman walked into my office. I remember the difficulty I had also with the political party providing the opportunity to make her voice heard in this chamber, and credit must go where credit is due. If it had not been for the member for Toowoomba South, who supported me then in that party room, then I doubt very much that Toni Hoffman’s voice would have been heard in this chamber. We would have been a far poorer Queensland for that. I can honestly say this now: if Toni Hoffman had approached the LNP now or the ALP--God forbid--she would have Buckley’s chance of having her voice heard in here. How can we trust an opposition that does not have the courage of its convictions about a simple matter of voting for or against a bill to actually put itself on the line and make that whistleblower’s voice heard in this chamber? That is what I would like an answer to today.

Toni Hoffman talked to me about the threats that she and the other nurses at the Bundaberg Base Hospital received from the manager of the Bundaberg Base Hospital in the case that they approached me, a member of parliament. The threat was, ‘If you see Rob Messenger, you will be thrown in jail.’ I hope that there is provision in this legislation, which I am not going to support, that stops managers and high-level public servants--actually, I would describe some of them as mercenaries.

Some of the managers, especially of the hospitals, have no connection at all with the community. They do not care what the community says or does. All they care about is receiving their very good pay cheque, coming in under budget and following orders that come from a centralised bureaucracy, obviously in Charlotte Street. They are guns for hire; they are mercenary guns for hire. I have seen so many come and go at the Bundaberg Base Hospital it is not funny. They come in, they carry out the orders, they mouth the platitudes and they cover up. For example, they have covered up the superbug outbreak that has been present at this hospital for a year or more, the dental crisis where 268 people were exposed to unclean dental equipment, the whistleblowers--and I will talk about them in a minute--such as Christine Cameron and the over 100 incident reports she submitted that received no feedback.

Those people need to be held to account. Those mercenary public servants need to understand that if they ignore whistleblowers there will be a penalty to pay. I am glad to see that some of the lessons we have seen from the royal commission are that the likes of Leck and Keating could be pursued by the CMC if they carried out those actions; we have been successful in having that changed. I do have concerns about the Public Interest Disclosure Bill. There are some structural flaws in this bill as well.

We have heard from many speakers about the limits that this legislation places on whistleblowers and their ability to approach the media. The reality is that if the media had not spoken to the whistleblower after her voice was heard in this chamber then we would not have had a royal commission because this government went into cover-up mode immediately. As soon as Toni Hoffman’s voice was heard in here, within a matter of days we all know that someone ordered one of those mercenary public servants to buy Patel a business class air ticket and fly him to America where he escaped. Then the machinery of government kicked in. The ministers visited and said to the gathered public servants, ‘Which part of “there will be no investigation” don’t you understand?’ It was taken seriously until Hedley Thomas took the time to speak with the whistleblower, understand that what she and others were saying was truthful, did a little Google search and some fine investigative journalism and found out the real situation and the horrific history of Patel in America and wrote that media article--it was probably a bit like the Four Corners program. It took a media organisation to break a massive story that then shamed this government into acting, and this government came kicking and screaming to a royal commission. It did not want a royal commission. It was only, I believe, the ability of the CMC to refuse to investigate the allegations saying, ‘We don’t have the resources,’ that left this government with no other option but to hold a royal commission.

Have we learnt the lessons of the whistleblowers, in this particular case, of the royal commission into Queensland Health? No, we have not. We still have a bloated bureaucracy. Unfortunately, we have an opposition that is unwilling to attack that bloated bureaucracy. They are very fearful. We found out in the royal commission that, out of the 65,000 employees in Queensland Health, 80 per cent were non-clinical and 20 per cent were clinical. That is not to say that the entire 80 per cent of non-clinical staff were administrative staff and wasted effort. However, it showed that there was an imbalance within Queensland Health.

If we want to save money, pay our bills and pay off our loans, we will have to finally attack properly the issue of government waste. We are going to have to work out exactly how much is being wasted and cut out that waste. We owe it to our children and our grandchildren. We owe it to the whistleblowers for the lessons we should learn from them. We have found out that there are massive inefficiencies in Queensland Health. Why would an anaesthetist who works in the private system for one day a week and the public system for four days a week perform more operations in the private system than in the public system? Those are the questions that we are going to have to answer honestly and address purposefully if we are going to get this state back on track.

Before in this place I have raised the issues concerning another whistleblower from the Bundaberg Base Hospital and, once again, the government is trying to cover up those issues. Her name is Christine Cameron. She was a nurse who worked in the accident and emergency department of the hospital. She made around 100 reports of very serious incidents that affected the wellbeing of staff and patients, but she has never received a reply to those reports. I took her to the CMC and we made declarations before the CMC. As the Public Interest Disclosure Bill will allow, the CMC passed those complaints on to the department of Queensland Health, which investigated the claims and allegations through its ethical standards unit. Eighteen months later we are still waiting on the report from the ethical standards unit. It appears that this government is hiding that report. An interim report that came out was basically made up of mistruths. Suddenly, the report went from being the responsibility of the ethical standards unit to that of a manager and then back to the ethical standards unit. We saw this stupid dance where it went back and forth, and we did not quite know who was responsible for writing the report. Needless to say, there is one fact out there. That report has not been written and Christine Cameron, the people of the Burnett and I are still waiting on it. Christine Cameron was responsible for forcing this government to build a new emergency department, which provides six new beds. She deserves credit. I know from experience that this lady is another whistleblower who has risked everything and cannot go back to her profession. She cannot stand the sight of the Bundaberg Base Hospital. She breaks down at the sight of the hospital. She cannot nurse again. She has been completely destroyed by the process that this government has put her through.

The provisions in the bill that limit who a whistleblower can speak to, especially in the media, are very serious. They should not be there. It will diminish our ability to uncover corruption, to identify waste and to protect the children, women, disabled people and Indigenous people who have been left unprotected by this government. Because this bill has been made cognate and because these three very important bills are being rushed through this parliament without proper scrutiny, I will be opposing them. I reiterate that if we find ourselves in the position where a group of Independents hold the balance of power, I expect any future government to give reasonable and fair warning and allow fair community consultation. That has not happened with this cognate debate. It has been a tricky political stunt and I oppose it.

Mr MALONE (Mirani--LNP) (5.44 pm): I rise to speak briefly on the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill, the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and the Public Interest Disclosure Bill. I congratulate the Leader of the Opposition for the great speech that he made in the parliament today. He covered all the issues exceptionally well. I will speak only briefly on the bills and mainly limit my comments to the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill with reference to the Ambulance Service Act 1991 and the disclosure necessary for recruits who come on board the QAS.

During my time as shadow Minister for Emergency Services, I have had the misfortune of becoming aware of what happens to people who run foul of the operations of QAS and the middle and upper management of that organisation. They have been pursued through the CMC and, ultimately, through the integrity commission board of QAS. Even if they are cleared by the CMC, they will still be pursued by the QAS. In a lot of cases, those paramedics and employees of QAS are put through absolute hell by this government and previous Labor governments. Frankly, I see this legislation as giving the government greater opportunity to pursue people once they have made a declaration. I believe everybody should be treated equally. When a cadet joins the QAS, or anyone else enters employment within government, I believe they should be treated equally and fairly. However, I have seen family units break down, divorces occur and suicides happen because of the bullying and harassment within emergency services. I have raised my concerns about this in relation to the Ambulance Service Act, and obviously firefighters are affected as well. In relation to rural fire brigades and so on, middle and upper management appear to have a view that volunteers are just unpaid staff who can take orders as if they were paid staff. That is not acceptable. Volunteers give of their free time. They help people who are in distress. They fight fires or perform emergency services work. They may work on the side of the road with the SES. All of the volunteers who do such work save this government and the taxpayers of Queensland quite a considerable amount of money, yet they are bullied and abused in this manner. Therefore, ‘integrity’ is not a word I would use lightly in connection with the government.

I was reluctant to speak on these bills, until I heard the member for Keppel make some comments earlier in the House in relation to some Liberal and National parties’ pre-1989 members who faced certain charges and some of whom went to jail. They were caught up in a situation that none of us would ever want to be caught up in. They were signing off on documents that were appropriate at the time, but then pre-dated legislation was pushed through the parliament by the Goss government--in fact, they were Henry VIII clauses--and those members were caught up in a situation whereby the documentation they had supplied was no longer relevant or was not regarded as sufficient. I would hate any member of parliament to have to go through that again.

If we want to talk about integrity, let us talk about some of the members of the Labor Party who have also been members of this House. Let us talk about Keith Wright, Bill D’Arcy and Gordon Nuttall. Unfortunately, the government of the day sat with Bill D’Arcy while he was a convicted criminal because they did not have the numbers in the House. Is that integrity? If members opposite are going to throw stones, they should make sure that they aim properly. If we are talking about integrity, we could talk about Paul Lucas, Jim Elder, Grant Musgrove and Mike Kaiser. Do I need to go on? I find it unbelievable that an educated member of this parliament would be stupid enough to raise the issue, particularly when his side of the House is so out of step with integrity. As I said, I was reluctant to speak on these bills, but I was amazed that a member of the parliament would make those claims. If we look back at history, the charges that were laid against the members of the Liberal and National parties were quite minor in comparison to those laid against Keith Wright, Bill D’Arcy and Gordon Nuttall. I did not want to speak at any length on these bills, but it is very important to correct the record. Those members opposite should hang their heads in shame.

Hon. DM WELLS (Murrumba--ALP) (5.49 pm): Madam Deputy Speaker, may I commence by paying tribute to the Public Service of Queensland, the loyal civil servants who serve the people, irrespective of which government is in power, and who do so diligently and so well. I have had the privilege of working with the Public Service of Queensland in the capacity of a minister, in the capacity of a government backbencher and in the capacity of an opposition member. In all of those circumstances I have found that they were diligent, they were committed to serving the mandate of the government of the day and they were absolutely meticulous in their duty. I have seen them go far beyond the extra mile in order to serve. I have seen them work back until midnight in order to get a job done. I have seen them give away their weekends in order to get a job done. I have rarely seen a public servant who even showed the slightest moment of hesitation or the slightest complaint about doing their duty to the public. Overwhelmingly, the Public Service of Queensland has done us proud and has delivered the consequences of our democratic system. I think that we ought to pay them such a tribute.

I was somewhat surprised therefore when I heard the Leader of the Opposition say that the purpose of the legislation was the ‘bureaucracy is held in such poor regard by the general community’. It is not held in poor regard by the general community. The public servants of Queensland are widely respected. The Leader of the Opposition also said that an LNP government will not be providing extra processes for ‘yet more bureaucrats’. The anti-Public Service bent of honourable members on the other side of the House needs to be known more widely, I think. The Public Service is the instrument by which the mandate that the people give to the elected government is delivered, and our Public Service does it well and they do it proud.

This is a piece of legislation that has a number of consequences. It brings together a single code for public servants, a single ethical code. It establishes a basis of principles for departmental statements of objectives. It provides a statutory basis for our pecuniary interest register. It brings other officers into the integrity framework including officers who report directly to the parliament. I would like to mention some of those in a moment. But I interrupt what I was saying because I want to nail a misstatement. I want to nail a disingenuity that came from honourable members on the other side of the House. Perhaps it need be mentioned only once, but it should be mentioned.

Honourable members referred to the removal by this parliament some time ago of a section of the Criminal Code that made it a criminal offence not triable in the courts to lie to a parliamentary committee. I remind honourable members that the proposition that the government made it open to members to lie to parliament is itself a lie. To lie to parliament is a contempt of the House with severe consequences.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms van Litsenburg): Order! Would the member retract that unparliamentary statement?
Mr WELLS: Madam Deputy Speaker, I did not actually say that any of them told a lie. I said that the proposition--
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Would the member retract that statement?

Mr WELLS: I retract, Madam Deputy Speaker, and I say instead that I remind honourable members that the proposition that the government made it open to members to lie to the parliament is itself a deliberate and disingenuous misstatement of fact. To lie to parliament is a contempt--
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! The word ‘lie’ is unparliamentary. Would you please retract it and not use it again?

Mr WELLS: Yes, Madam Deputy Speaker. I retract the use of the term and I substitute instead the terms deliberate, wilful, gross, misstatement of fact done with disingenuity and dishonesty. To lie to parliament is a contempt of the House and it has severe consequences. A minister who lies to the House is actually required to resign--
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! The word ‘lie’ is unparliamentary. Please do not use it again. Withdraw it.

Mr WELLS: Yes, Madam Deputy Speaker. I withdraw it. A member who is proved to be a liar has to face his or her constituents. So the proposition that the government made it possible to lie to the House is simply not true.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Would you retract the word ‘liar’?

Mr WELLS: I retract. The misleading, the disingenuousness and the falsity of the proposition that the government made it possible for MPs to tell untruths to parliament is a proposition that is inimical to democracy. The old law did not just potentially criminalise MPs but also potentially criminalised journalists, public servants and indeed any member of the public ever called before a parliamentary committee. A corrupt government would be able to use a provision like the old section 57 of the code to silence dissent and suppress free speech by threatening to bring a person who makes assertions it particularly did not want to hear to trial in a criminal court. A corrupt government would be able to stack a court to ensure a conviction. How odd it is therefore that the same opposition that says it wants to bring back criminal court processes for things said under parliamentary privilege told us today that it had reservations about putting the requirement for pecuniary interest declarations into legislation because people do make mistakes. That is somewhat inconsistent one might think, but then there are cheap votes to be won by falsely asserting that this government made it permissible to tell to the parliament something which was untrue.

I would now like to refer to some remarks made by the honourable member for Kawana. He, in the course of his remarks, tabled some correspondence from the Ombudsman which he had clearance from the committee of this House to make use of in this debate. He did not table the response to that correspondence of the Premier which I think completes the picture. The proposition that the Ombudsman was asserting--and one has to take due cognisance of the Ombudsman’s thoughts on this subject--was that it was improper, in his view, to extend the scrutiny of the Public Service Commission to the management of the Ombudsman’s office, and the reason for that was that the Ombudsman’s office reports to a committee of this parliament. It is a creature of the parliament, not a creature of the executive. Therefore, the Ombudsman argued that it was not appropriate for the Public Service Commission to have overall scrutiny of the Ombudsman’s office. On the basis of his argument, one would have to agree that it would not be appropriate for the executive arm of government to have overall scrutiny of the Ombudsman’s office. But that is not what was actually at stake and that is not what the legislation proposes to do. I table the letter from the honourable Premier in respect of this matter to the parliamentary committee so that the documentary record is complete for the benefit of the public.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 8 September 2010, from Hon. Anna Bligh MP, Premier to Ms Barbara Stone MP, Chair of the Law, Justice and Safety Committee, in relation to the Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: I note that it points out that this legislation does not give the Public Service Commission the power to review or monitor the way in which the commissioner--that is, the Ombudsman--exercises functions under the Ombudsman Act. The letter goes on to say that the functions of the oversight agency will only apply to the corporate responsibilities of the Ombudsman in relation to employees of the office. In other words, it is only about management.

The extension of the ambit of the Public Service Commission to look at the Ombudsman’s office and to look indeed at any agent of the government broadly speaking which reports to this parliament applies only to the management functions and the HR functions of that office. It does not relate at all to the independent decision-making power of the Ombudsman. The Ombudsman’s decision-making power of course should be exercised independently. This legislation does not give the Ombudsman the power to second guess, to scrutinise or to call to account the exercise of that discretion. What this legislation does, however, is address any management issue that might arise.

There was never--the last time I asked the question; and I did ask the question--any public interest disclosure within the Ombudsman’s office. While the issue is theoretical it is nevertheless a point which the Ombudsman might well properly make. But the answer to it is that it relates only to management.
