While it is appropriate to congratulate the Ombudsman on being zealous to preserve the independence of statutory office holders who report to the parliament, at the same time it is important for this parliament to note that the independence, the discretion and the capacity to do their statutory tasks is not inhibited, not even to a slight degree, by this piece of legislation.

This is a benign piece of legislation. This is a piece of legislation that we would expect to see in the kind of free, open and democratic society that Queensland is. This piece of legislation is a tribute not only to our public servants but also to the minister--that is, the Premier--who introduced the legislation. It is a statement of our democracy.

This legislation is not necessary because of any fault that we find with the Public Service or the public sector generally. This legislation is necessary because the public needs to know how open and transparent this government and this parliament is. The public needs to know about the pecuniary interest register that honourable members have to fill in. They need to know that statutory office holders in terms of their personnel management function do have oversight from an agency that maintains consistent provisions across departments. We would not want a statutory office, however independent it might be in the fearless exercise of its function, to be investigating its own public interest disclosures, were there any, because we would not want Caesar to be investigating Caesar. This is an important piece of legislation. It is a significant advance in Queensland’s democracy. I recommend it to the House.

Mr CRANDON (Coomera--LNP) (6.04 pm): The cognate debate incorporates debate on the Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2010, the Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010 and the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. The Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010 is necessary and is brought about because a ministerial adviser overstepped the mark and directed others to divert funds meant for use by a particular organisation. This the classic master-servant relationship where the master has all the power. He wields the power and directs the public servant to do as he or she is told. It is high time that the necessary legislation be put in place.

I have to ask whether this sort of bullying is rampant not only within ministerial offices but within departments. We have heard numerous examples brought to light by opposition members. Here is another example. A Department of Transport and Main Roads employee who fell ill had some 15 years of exemplary service. The mental health illness was partly brought about by the workload among other things. The health issues are well documented over an extended period of time by no fewer than four separate health professionals, including two psychiatrists. There are psychiatric reports as long as your arm. As well, there were workload issues brought on by workplace harassment and bullying. Combine all this with sexual harassment allegations. Amongst all of this there was a severe lack of communication from the department.

Due to the mental health issues, the employee found it difficult to give evidence. Indeed it appears that it was on the employee’s psychiatrists advice that to do so could be detrimental to the employee’s health. Eventually the case was finalised and it was found that there was no case to answer. There was no case to answer even though there were sexual harassment, bullying, workload issues et cetera. What do members think happened? The case was closed? No, not at all.

The department is considering charging the employee with making vexatious claims and for misconduct. Here we have an individual suffering mental health issues who could not properly give evidence. That was part of the reason for the decision that there was no case to answer. Now that person has been told that the department may pursue a case against them. It is going on and on. This person is being persecuted.

Where is the common sense in this case? It is obvious to everyone that this person is suffering mental health problems. This person needs to focus on their recovery. I call on the minister to use his discretion in this matter and call the attack dogs off. This person needs to focus on their recovery. This person is being persecuted.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! Member for Coomera, whilst there may well be some basis for this, I would prefer that you refer to bill so that you can set a proper basis for this argument. Otherwise please get on with debating the bill.

Mr CRANDON: I will finish my comments with this. This person is being persecuted by a system that appears to have given no consideration to the mental health of the individual. The minister has it in his power to stop this persecution.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (6.07 pm): I rise to speak to the cognate bills. They are three very important bills, hence the division this morning in relation to debating the three of them cognately. All of them deal with very important issues not only for the running of the parliament and government departments but also from the perspective of the community.

I did not hear all of the debate because our committee sat in the early part of the afternoon. From the rest of debate that I have listened to one would be forgiven for thinking it was a competition between the ALP and the LNP to determine who had the most crooks. We had lists of Austin, Lane and Lewis and then Wright, D’Arcy and Nuttall. I am not referring to those six people when I say this. It is possible for people in a position, in a job, to make mistakes. If those mistakes are intentional then that is where illegality, fraudulence and those sorts of accusations come to the fore. I think the community showed in the federal election that it is sick and tired of the major parties, instead of dealing with the issues, taking pot shots at one another and trying to justify their actions on the basis of wrongdoing on one side whilst the people making those accusations possibly live in glass houses.

All of us are capable of making a genuine mistake. The Public Interest Disclosure Bill and the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill are there to manage people who might try to do the wrong thing intentionally. The Ministerial and Other Office Holder Staff Bill 2010 is a bill to separate the appointment of ministerial staff from the Public Service Act into its own act. I thank the minister for the briefing that we received. Leighton, Nick, Christine, Cecilia, Donna and Karen gave us a great deal of their time and certainly were able to answer most of the questions asked.

The fact is that the Labor Party gained office in 1989. I have only been involved in this parliament since 1995, but my observation prior to that and certainly my observation since then is that senior staff, including directors-general of departments, have been politicised. It started in 1989, and when Rob Borbidge took office in 1995 my office received correspondence alleging that Borbidge was appointing directors-general on a politically biased basis. I looked into that process, and that is when I determined that he had not started it; it had been growing as far as senior ministerial staff and senior governmental officers were concerned. Therefore, I can understand why the opposition has raised concerns about directors-general being able to appoint opposition staff as opposed to the Public Service, which generically has been apolitical.

At the briefing it was indicated that in practice the arrangements will be much the same. However, if there is any concern about the independence of appointments then certainly that needs to be clarified and corrected. It is important for ministerial staff not to be able to give direction to departmental staff, unless of course they have the direct authority from the minister. But let us be honest: the reality is that many ministerial staff will carry out their duties--and I am not talking about ministerial staff now; I am talking generically--with an inferred authority because they get used to acting in that way. In past history it was always said that the Public Service was apolitical. There may be one or two directors-general who can claim that they have been in the Public Service in those senior positions across both sides of government, but they are very few and far between now. Therefore, those senior political appointments are politically based as opposed to independently based.

There have been a number of concerns raised in relation to the Public Interest Disclosure Bill. It is critically important that people working in the Public Service have an ability to take their concerns, if they have an honest belief that there is wrongdoing, to people outside of the Public Service. The most strident example of the lack of ability for a department internally to deal with regular complaints is the Patel issue. One or two of the staff--I do not think it was only Nurse Hoffman, but she perhaps was the main one--regularly took their concerns to their higher management and those concerns were blocked within the immediate hospital structure. The Public Interest Disclosure Bill or whistleblowers legislation is intended to be a safety valve, if you like, for those people who work within the Public Service in particular to be able to make a public interest disclosure.

There are only a few other issues that I want to raise with regard to this bill. As has been mentioned by other speakers, I am concerned about the protection from liability in that a person who has been involved in or who supervised an activity--an action--is able to make an apology to an affected party without attracting liability. In some instances that is excellent because, as the member for Nicklin said--it may have been someone else--often people who are disadvantaged or offended by a process only want an apology. However, in many instances that apology should be inclusive of reparation, whether that is financial or physical reparation. I am concerned that the lack of liability that will attach to an apology, whilst good in some instances, could mean that there will be a rash of apologies because people will think, ‘It’s not going to cost us anything because there’s no liability,’ and it will be possible for serial offenders to hide behind that ‘I’m sorry’ and not actually address the actions that have attracted the need for the apology. If there is a systemic problem then the problem should be fixed, not a series of apologies to a series of people because of the same lack of action, wrong action or hyperaction.

The member for Nicklin raised concerns about clause 45 of the Public Interest Disclosure Bill which provides that reasonable management action is not prevented in relation to a whistleblower, and I would share his concerns. Humans are wonderful beings and can do tremendous good; however, we can also be tremendously devious. One of the most difficult things to identify and prove is that a manager, given that they are in a disproportionate position of power--they are senior and have more authority over, usually, the whistleblower--if they are so disposed, will be able to use what they call ‘reasonable management action’ and disadvantage a whistleblower and be able to justify it. Regardless of whether clause 45 is in or out of the bill, if a manager does take reasonable management action then the whistleblower themselves would be less likely to cause or question that action if indeed it is reasonable. I also note that the member for Nicklin will be moving an amendment in relation to that matter.

Other speakers have talked about departments where they have had direct experience of employees articulating concerns to elected members and to others and subsequently being read the riot act, where they are reminded in very forceful terms of the code of conduct. Most often it is in the department of health, but it does happen in other departments.

When I was mayor of Calliope council I had a staff member come to speak to me in relation to a private matter. It was to do with a footpath in front of their place. They had asked for remediation of that footpath. It had not happened appropriately and then it had not happened at all. They came and spoke to me and I spoke to the appropriate person in the council to request that that be inspected. The employee was then approached by a senior manager and told that they had done the wrong thing by speaking to me. It is my firm view that, even if you work for government, you do not give up your democratic right to justice or an opportunity to be heard. However, I think in many instances people who work within councils or government departments have those fundamental rights eroded because they are told that they cannot speak out.

In one instance I had an employee of a government department speak to me. She had been told by her departmental seniors that she was going to be terminated as she was seen to be unfit for the job because of a response to a specific situation. She had six to nine months of grief from her immediate senior and yet for that same situation she had received at least two citations from the director-general level of the department. So on the one hand she was being told within her local management area that she was unfit for the position based on this incident, yet in the macro sense she was told that she had responded very competently and that the people who were affected whom she dealt with were incredibly complimentary about what she did. Indeed, she was instrumental in saving a life.

So from my perspective, it is critically important that workers within the government sector and within the council sector--where this bill will have reach--have to go through the chain of command within reason but, where that fails, they must be able to pursue their grievances externally as a democratic right and opportunity.

The Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill extends the opportunity for a person to have disciplinary proceedings to continue even if that person resigns from the department. I believe that is reasonable, provided the issue is serious enough for those proceedings to continue. This bill contains the apology without legal liability.

From the community’s point of view, whether these bills pass unchanged or not, it is our responsibility, as members of this chamber and for people in every workplace, to as much as possible act in good faith and act honestly in the carriage of our responsibilities. There will be people who will fail and that is where the legislation is needed. But certainly, the legislation should not be drafted in a way that will disadvantage people who work in good faith and who want an opportunity to correct a wrong externally if they cannot get it sorted out internally. It would be a tragedy to see this state in any way undermine or compromise the ability of those employees to do that.

Mr SPRINGBORG (Southern Downs--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (6.21 pm): In rising to speak in this cognate debate and in perusing the intent of these bills, I think it is fair to say that whilst the intent of what is put before this parliament is generally appropriate, one has to wonder about the motivation. I think the motivation has probably grown out of the predicament that this government has found itself in since the last state election. There has been a hue and cry across Queensland about the deception and the dishonesty at the last state election and a whole range of more recent situations where high-profile members of the government--from a parliamentary perspective and also from a senior staff perspective--and former members of this House have found themselves in a position of being compromised, in a position of facing charges, in some cases criminal charges and being incarcerated, and in other cases being accused of inappropriately using their power and influence in the case of staff and, in the case of former members of this House, lobbying to gain some sort of significant financial benefit based on their previous knowledge or through the position that they have within the hierarchy of the government in Queensland. So whilst there is some indication that there may be some benefit from certain provisions in these bills that are being debated cognately, I think the intent is something that is a little more questionable.

None of this means absolutely anything unless the government is prepared to live by the spirit of this legislation, which will undoubtedly pass through this parliament tonight or tomorrow. If you are fundamentally good and you fundamentally know the right thing, then you are going to fundamentally do the right thing. If you fundamentally have a predisposition towards not doing the right thing and you take every opportunity to advance your own position, whether that be financially or through a position of power, then it does not matter the amount of legislation, the amount of regulation, the amount of codes of ethics, the amount of codes of conduct, or the conflict of interest disclosures, you are still going to fundamentally try to find a way of doing the wrong thing.

I ask members to keep in mind that in recent times in this parliament we have seen a whole new range of accountability measures put in place. Some years ago we saw an Integrity Commissioner put in place apparently to address issues where members were struggling with situations of compromise or concern about conflict in relation to their role as an MP or their role as a member of the executive and what is expected of them. Despite the Integrity Commissioner being put in place, we have seen at least one minister--and probably two ministers--go to jail in Queensland and we have also seen a situation where the actions of other senior members of government staff have been brought into question. So I am not necessarily sure that this legislation is going to bring about this wonderful reform, this great new day in the sun that the government says it is going to bring about.
In 2009 Tony Fitzgerald said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Reform is always difficult. Vested interests whose activities might be adversely affected inevitably oppose reform strenuously.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He went on to make the following very concerning statement--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Misleading or deceptive conduct is barred in commerce, but secrecy and misinformation...are routinely employed by politicians.
XML.Hansard-Body: I do not think that that is something that we should be wearing with any badge of pride in this place. I think the most concerning thing is that Tony Fitzgerald made these comments almost 20 years after the landmark Fitzgerald reform process, the report which he brought down which the former Premier Mike Ahern said would be implemented lock, stock and barrel. Indeed, the early stage of that legislative reform was put in place by the Cooper administration insofar as the then CJC Act and the Electoral and Administrative Reform Commission were established. The various arms and tentacles of the reform went on from there and were implemented by the Goss government in its first term. Very worryingly, I think that in recent times a fair bit of that reform has variously been wound back, stymied or in some way blocked by this government in particular.

I have listened with interest to some of the assertions made by honourable members opposite about how good the Labor Party has been with regard to integrity and what this legislation is all about. But I have noticed that one thing that is fundamentally missing from their narrative is the word ‘honesty’. Dishonesty is the whole reason that this government finds itself in this predicament at the moment, because it fundamentally and comprehensively misled the people of Queensland at the last state election, particularly on the issue of the sale of generational assets and also on the issue of the retention of the Fuel Subsidy Scheme in Queensland. That is a sin beyond which I think it will be very difficult for this government to recover.

I have also heard members opposite talk about the Labor government and the abolition of the so-called gerrymander. That process started with the establishment of EARC in 1989, but I will review the issue of this so-called gerrymander, which had its genesis back in Labor’s days of the 1940s and the 1950s. On not one single occasion from 1957 to 1989 did Labor in Queensland achieve more than 50 per cent plus one of the vote. On the first occasion that it did so in 1989, it actually won the election. Then we had the EARC reform process and we went to the election in 1992 under the so-called new uncorruptible electoral boundaries in Queensland, which were put in place as a consequence of the EARC process. It is very interesting to note that, with the redistribution, the vote for the Labor Party in the 1992 election was 48.73 per cent. In 1989 it was 50.32 per cent. In 1989 the vote for the National Party was 24.09 per cent. In 1992 it was 23.71 per cent. In 1989 the vote for the Liberal Party was 23.5 per cent. In 1992 it was 20.44 per cent. All of those political parties achieved a vote within about one per cent or just over what they achieved in 1989 and guess what? The Labor Party won exactly the same number of seats as it won in 1989, the National Party won one fewer and the Liberal won one more.

But what happened in 1995? The Goss Labor government won 46.7 per cent of the vote and won a majority in this parliament. Indeed, based on the figures at the last state election, the LNP in Queensland has to win 54 per cent of the vote in order to just win a majority in this parliament, but Labor can maintain power with 47 per cent of the vote. That is an issue that fundamentally needs to be addressed. With the way that the boundaries have been drawn, we have a one vote, one value gerrymander in Queensland. After the last state election in South Australia, that parliament was prepared to see whether the Electoral Commission should be trying to address the issue so that the votes received on a two-party preferred basis were reflected in the number of seats that were actually delivered to the parties at that particular poll. I think it is something that fundamentally needs to be looked at here. It is about time that those people who want to comment on this issue, those people who want to rewrite history, fundamentally look at what really happened between 1957 and 1989 vis-à-vis the Labor Party and the conservatives at the time and what has happened subsequent to that period. I think that a scrutiny of what happened during that time would reveal that there is something fundamentally wrong with the Queensland electoral system at the moment.

XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2)
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 18 August (see p. 2689), on motion of Mr Hinchliffe--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr GIBSON (Gympie--LNP)
(7.31 pm): It has been said that a wife who loses her husband is called a widow, a husband who loses his wife is known as a widower and a child who loses their parent is referred to as an orphan, but there is no word for a parent who loses a child. That is how awful the loss is. In 2008-09 eight children aged between one and four drowned in backyard swimming pools in Queensland. It would be simplistic to compare this number to the number of backyard pools in Queensland, which is estimated at over 300,000, because for every tragic drowning or near drowning event the impact extends beyond the immediate family and into our communities.

Queenslanders enjoy an enviable lifestyle. We identify with images of the surf and the sea. We take pride in our athletes who compete in swimming events. Our climate lends itself to backyard pools and owning a pool is a source of enjoyment for many families. Unfortunately, too often this idealistic image is shattered as we hear reports of a tragic drowning. In some cases it is revealed that the backyard pool failed to meet basic safety standards. Indeed, media reports just last week indicated that a staggering 80 per cent of pools in the Sunshine Coast Regional Council area failed council safety inspection at their first attempt. This figure is disturbing. It appears that far too many pool owners have become complacent and either accidentally or deliberately ignore pool safety laws. These owners take the chance that they will not be caught out by council inspectors, but in doing so they are playing Russian roulette with our children’s safety.

The Swimming Pool Safety Improvement Strategy has enjoyed bipartisan support because the issue of pool safety is an important one. The Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) will continue to enjoy that bipartisan support from the LNP. As is often the case, a fresh set of eyes can see areas of improvement and it is with that spirit that the LNP will be proposing amendments and raising concerns with a view to taking good and important legislation and making it better.

The policy objectives of the bill’s pool safety reforms are to help reduce the incidence of pool related immersion injuries and deaths for a very vulnerable section of our community, children under five. It is envisaged that this would be achieved by introducing the requirement for pool fences to be regularly inspected by competent and qualified pool safety inspectors. This is in part achieved by enabling legislation found in the Building and Other Legislation Bill that was introduced this year. This bill enabled the establishment of the Pool Safety Council, which is responsible for overseeing the operation of the pool safety inspector licensing system, including the approval of training courses.

I would say to those members of the Pool Safety Council and the minister that any training course must be conducted by a registered training organisation and the course must comprise of modules that meet nationally recognised competencies. Failure to do so will erode public confidence in our pool safety inspectors. When the person turns up to undertake the inspection work, Queenslanders need to know that they have been properly trained and that the organisation that trained them met the Australian Quality Training Framework standards. They have to have confidence that the training they received met the national qualifications and they need to know that it is a nationally recognised training level. Registered training organisations have a requirement to face audits to ensure that they are delivering quality training and assessment. If we get it right at the beginning, if we ensure that those organisations that are providing the training are indeed RTOs, we can have confidence that what we are setting up today will serve us well into the future.

Failure to adhere to nationally recognised competencies and to only reference them will result in qualifications that are at risk of becoming identified as something akin to a corn-flakes-packet licensing option with no credibility. That is something that we cannot afford to have in our community. I would urge the Pool Safety Council and the minister not to take shortcuts in this area. Indeed, we can draw upon the federal Labor experience with the Home Insulation Program. That program was rushed out for political expediency. Training was compromised and, tragically, not only were the lives of homeowners and installers put at risk but also lives were lost. We must not allow this to occur with the training of pool safety inspectors. We must not set it up to fail by compromising the high standard of training. I note that the minister in his summing-up on the Building and Other Legislation Bill (No. 1) said that the high quality of pool safety training courses is absolute. I would hope that that line would be honoured by the minister and future ministers to follow.

Whilst the bill does not detail a commencement date, the Premier is on the record as indicating a start date for stage 2 of 1 December 2010. It is appropriate that this is when we should start the focus because, obviously, we are moving into our summer season and many Queenslanders will be dusting off their swimmers and getting into their backyard pools. However, we have seen some impacts upon this timeline. Of concern is the formation of the Pool Safety Council. Despite the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) passing in May, we are advised that, indeed, the first meeting of the council was only last week. Four months have passed. The Pool Safety Council has a responsibility to approve the training program and to ensure that the training of individuals is to an appropriate standard before they are licensed. It is of concern to the LNP.

It would be optimistic to expect licences to be issued before October at the earliest. That gives us only two months to undertake the necessary inspections and to ensure that we are ready for an implementation date of 1 December. There is concern that there will not be a sufficient number of properly qualified pool safety inspectors in place to cope with the influx of applications before 1 December and in the weeks immediately following as we come up to that busy time of year with holidays and families taking time away from their home only to come back later in January but wanting to have their pools certified.

It is clear that this government and the minister could have and should have done more to prepare Queenslanders so that the pool safety certificates could be issued before 1 December 2010. What we now need to ensure is that proper resources are committed by this government so that we do not see the program fall over on its first day. It will be an issue of resourcing. It will be an issue of commitment. It will be an issue of finding the right public servants to champion this to ensure that the job is done in a timely manner.

On the issue of the pool safety certificates, it is good to see that the minister has learnt from the debacle that was the sustainability declarations. I commend the minister for getting the font right and for making the certificates easy to use. It highlights for all of us in this chamber that we should not simply parrot the lines that are given to us. When the sustainability declaration was introduced, Labor MPs embarrassed themselves. They stood up saying that there was no fault with this declaration, that the documentation was fine. Clearly, they were wrong. Three versions later, we now have a sustainability declaration that, whilst I do not support it, I accept is a much better version than was introduced to this parliament in the very first place.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Tragically, many of these drowning incidents occur shortly after families with young children move into new and unfamiliar environments. This is why the state government has proposed that pool owners who want to sell or lease a property will first need to obtain a pool safety certificate. We want to ensure that residential pools are safe before a new family moves in.
XML.Hansard-Body: These were the minister’s words from his second reading speech in the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill No. 1. He clearly said they are seeking pool safety certificates ‘before a new family moves in’. The minister was right then. He was spot on. The research clearly shows that in those first six months when families are in a new environment they are at the greatest risk. I would hazard to say that in those first three months the risk is probably at its greatest. Indeed, having been in the Army and moved quite a few times with my family, I know that in those initial weeks, when people are unpacking boxes and trying to find where the various cupboards are, that is the time when they are most unfamiliar with their new home. It is with that concern in mind that the LNP will be moving amendments to ensure that a contract to sell a property with a pool is conditional on the issue of a pool safety certificate and that we do not set this legislation up to fail by providing a 90-day window for the purchaser to make the pool compliant. Those 90 days could be 90 days of danger for any family. Why the minister has backtracked from his original position is of great concern.

We know that these initial days are the most critical and the effect of the amendment we are putting forward will be to make it safe for families when they move in. This amendment is supported by the LGAQ. It is supported by the Swimming Pool & Spa Association of Queensland. Even the REIQ was not opposed in our discussion and even made the suggestion that, in order to cut red tape, a single disclosure regime could be put in place not only for the pool safety certificate but also the current requirements that exist for the earth safety switch and smoke alarms, which must be declared before the time of sale. Clearly, there is support, but there is even greater support as I am advised that the minister’s own Pool Safety Council in its very first meeting directed the chair to write to the minister indicating that the Pool Safety Council is not supportive of the 90-day period that has been placed in this bill. It wishes to see, as we do, as all Queenslanders do, a bill that is watertight, a bill that is right, a bill that will deliver safety for our children in Queensland. I would encourage the minister and all members in this chamber to support these amendments. They are not designed for anything other than to ensure our children are safe.

If the minister does not intend to support these amendments, he must provide to this House reasons why he has backed down from his original position. He must tell this House who has lobbied him to change from his original position because the major stakeholders are, indeed, supportive. Wandering through the Stranger’s Dining Room this evening, I had the opportunity to meet with Mr Plint from Hannah’s Foundation. He indicated to me that he personally is also supportive of this amendment. Here is an individual who has taken a tragedy in his life and turned it into a cause that he champions. This amendment is something that will make good legislation better.

I am sure that, despite the best efforts and desires of all in this chamber, this bill will not stop tragic pool drownings. Unfortunately, no legislation that we pass can stop them permanently. Supervision of children by responsible adults is essential. Indeed, in many child drowning incidents, supervision was deemed to be inadequate or nonexistent. Coronial data reveals that in many instances when toddlers drowned the responsible adult was not even aware that the toddler was in danger. The Queensland Injury Surveillance Unit observed that there were few reports of toddlers drowning when they were being directly supervised within the pool enclosure. Clearly, supervision is the best form of defence. Secondly, it is entirely appropriate that we focus on ensuring pool enclosures are up to the appropriate standard. But if we come back to the issue of supervision, that then requires us to ensure that the community is aware. I would call on the minister and this state government to undertake a major education and awareness program--and to properly fund it--within the community to educate all about the dangers of our swimming pools and how they can safely enjoy them within their own backyard. It is the small things that we do that will ensure our children are able to appreciate the great lifestyle that we have in Queensland without being placed at risk.

We have seen many wonderful community initiatives over the years that have worked fantastically at raising awareness. Laurie Lawrence’s Kids Alive--Do the Five is one that comes to mind and was well supported by the Howard federal government in ensuring that it was funded appropriately. As I mentioned earlier, the Plint family’s Hannah’s Foundation is one that works tirelessly to ensure that not only legislation but also education is appropriate. We need to ensure that our state government also undertakes its responsibility, takes its fair share and does its part of the heavy lifting when it comes to protecting our children by funding major education and awareness programs.

I would now like to touch on the issue of enforcement by councils. Our local councils will, in many cases, remain the default inspectors of our swimming pools. There is a responsibility for them to keep up to date the swimming pool register that was debated in the earlier Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. Whilst local governments have indicated to me that the government has promised they will not be left with the enforcement of this regime and the enforcement costs, I must admit I am hesitant to agree with this assessment. The question has to be asked: who else will take on the responsibility? Clearly, the state government does not have a structure to be able to act as a fallback for pool inspections. Do we expect that to fall upon real estate agents? It is hardly within the job description of the average suburban realtor. We need to ensure that if we expect our local governments to do this work we also provide them with the additional resourcing, otherwise we will find ourselves in the situation in which we found ourselves in 1991. When the new pool laws were brought in at that time--incredibly radical--there was a heightened awareness and the public expected and, indeed, acted to make sure that their pools were compliant to the standard of the day because they expected that they would be inspected. This did not occur to the level that they anticipated and over the years we found the community becoming more and more complacent when it came to pool safety.

With regard to local government within our state, we also have to be cognisant of the fact that we have many remote area councils. Enforcement is particularly an issue for our remote and regional councils within Queensland. There is a concern that this legislation has been largely written with the larger coastal councils in mind, many of which have established pool safety regimes. Clearly, this is not the case for all councils, particularly in our regional areas. These councils have small workforces which face many challenges, not the least of which is distance. Whilst I recognise there is a provision in this bill for remote inspections to be done by a form of correspondence, there are dangers with this, forcing inspectors to be reliant upon information that is provided externally. I am sure we have all had the experience of looking for a property and seeing a photograph of that property in a magazine. Invariably, for many of us, when we actually turned up to the street address the house that was in front of us did not always look like what was in the glossy brochure. It is of concern that the information can be presented in such a way that may hide serious flaws within the pool fencing.

We need to look at how we can empower and resource remote and regional councils so that they too can step up to the challenge. In remote and regional areas the training of appropriate inspectors, both on council staff and in the private sector, can be an added burden. Clearly there is not the concentration of population in remote areas, making the economy of scale more difficult. This is likely to increase the costs of compliance within regional Queensland. Again, we need to look at ensuring that our cousins in regional and remote areas are not left carrying a burden greater than that faced within the south-east corner.

I note the change in the maximum depth of wading pools from 450 millimetres to 300 millimetres, which brings Queensland in line with broader national guidelines for wading pools and temporary inflatable pools. Over many summers when my kids were young they certainly enjoyed slashing around in such pools. I am concerned about the enforcement requirements surrounding such pools. It is fairly likely that the majority of Queenslanders have one of those pools, perhaps tucked away under the house or up in the roof, that probably has a depth greater than 300 millimetres. This comes back to the issue of education. We can be fairly confident that when the temperature rises on a summer weekend and kids ask their parents for an opportunity to cool down, those pools will be taken out, inflated and used in the back yard. However, that is the time that council inspectors are least likely to be patrolling, acting on complaints or enforcing pool regulations. This will be a very difficult requirement to enforce. One Saturday morning a family decides to inflate the wading pool and the kids play in it. On the Sunday afternoon, the pool is drained and deflated. The council has no evidence of the risk that those children were exposed to. I ask the minister in his response to address how he feels this difficult area of the legislation will be managed.

The issue of rental properties is a particularly difficult area. From reading the bill it appears that the owners of rental properties will be responsible for the fencing of pools. There are obvious difficulties in relation to liability if a renter chooses to use a removable pool. In that case, who is responsible for the fencing? Will it rest with the lessor or should that responsibility be moved to the lessee? By their nature such pools are not fixtures, but fences generally are. That issue needs to be addressed.

I am concerned about the impact of the announced 1 December commencement date on rentals. This comes back to the issue of the time line. We are looking at a very condensed couple of months in which to get this scheme up and running. Any leases for houses with pools will need to comply with this legislation from the commencement date. This will impact on leases that are a renewal of previous agreements. From our reading of the bill, there is no leeway for the owner or the renter in terms of the commencement date. Many owners are likely to be unaware of this requirement until they try to renew the lease and then they may find that they are faced with a substantial cost to upgrade pool fencing. That is not to say that they should not upgrade the pool fences, but we need to ensure that the fences are upgraded. We do not want a situation where the landlord chooses, because of cost, to simply place a padlock on the gate of a pool fence that is not compliant and assume that he or she can get away with that. We need to ensure that there is appropriate time to bring those pool fences up to the required standard. In addition, we do not want landlords to terminate leases because they cannot afford to fix a fence, resulting in an increase in the number of people looking for rental accommodation within Queensland.

The bill contains a component that relates to repairs by inspectors. Three areas are of concern. The first is the potential for a conflict of interest. It is acknowledged that options exist for small repairs. For example, an inspector may identify that the only problem with the pool fence is a $50 latch that could be replaced very easily. There would be no great conflict of interest in the inspector, at that point, offering to replace the latch immediately. However, because of the BSA’s requirement that work valued at less than $3,300 can be undertaken by an unlicensed person, there is a concern if the work becomes more involved. In the example I have given where the inspector replaces the latch, he may then discover that the footings of the fence have eroded or that the panels need to be replaced. We could have a situation where inspectors conduct work and then have to inspect their own work. Clearly, that would not be a desirable outcome. We seek the minister’s advice as to how the practicalities of this bill will prevent those conflicts from occurring.

I note that in much of the material that has gone forward the government indicates that the cost of an inspection would be in the vicinity of $90. I am sceptical that we would see the cost remain at that level. The very nature of the training required and the equipment necessary to ensure that an inspection is done to a proper standard--for example, pressure testing of the actual pool fencing or the equipment necessary to test whether electrical equipment located within three metres of a pool fence is appropriately earthed--may force that price to climb. Already families are facing incredible pressures because of the failed policies of this government when it comes to issues like water, registration and electricity costs. The last thing that we need to do is increase the burden on the Queensland family household budget.

It is said that when a parent dies you lose your past, but when a child dies you lose your future. I am sure that it is the genuine hope of all those within the House that this bill goes a long way to preserving the future of Queensland by improving pool safety.

I now turn to the other components of the bill. The bill recognises the American Staffordshire Terrier as an independent breed. We have no concerns with that part of the bill. We have no concerns with the implications that come from the recognition of the American Staffordshire Terrier as a separate breed.

The bill refers to the redevelopment by the Royal National Agricultural and Industrial Association, the RNA, of the Ekka site. I cannot help but reflect that with the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1), other members and myself raised concerns during the briefing that occurred before the debate, during the second reading debate and briefly during the consideration of the clauses before the guillotine was applied to the debate. The component of the bill relating to the RNA goes to the essence of the failings of this long-term Labor government. The parliament is here to debate and to improve upon legislation. If in May of this year the government had listened to the concerns that were raised in the briefings and in the parliament by other LNP members and myself, we could have agreed to an amendment to ensure the RNA’s interests and the interests of the people of Queensland were protected. Clearly that was not the case. As a result of the arrogance of this long-term Labor government and the blindness of this minister in refusing to listen, four months have been unnecessarily wasted. Of course, the LNP supports these amendments because we raised the concerns in the first place.

The Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is part of the plan that is supported by the LNP. We commend all those who have worked on the drafting of this legislation to ensure that we can put forward a pool safety regime for Queenslanders that is safe and that ensures when our children are at their most vulnerable they are protected. I put it to the minister that the amendments that will be circulated are designed to make good legislation better. They are designed to ensure that at the most critical time when families are in the unfamiliar environment of a new home they are indeed protected by ensuring that the onus rests upon the seller. This is not a new concept. It is one that we have seen with earthed safety switches and with regard to smoke alarms and it is one that the minister himself proposed in his second reading speech for the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1). We supported the minister then, we support his original position now, and we call upon him to support this amendment so that we can make our pools safe for families from the moment they move in. I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (8.01 pm): I rise to join the debate on the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2010, which was introduced into the House on 18 August by the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning. In doing so, I echo the sentiments of the shadow minister, the honourable member for Gympie. As members have heard, the LNP are offering bipartisan support for this legislation and will be moving some amendments that will offer further improvement to this legislation.

This bill will implement the second stage of the government’s swimming pool safety improvement strategy following the completion of a comprehensive review of Queensland swimming pool safety laws in September 2009. A committee was established on 14 December 2008 to provide a report to government recommending improvements to pool safety laws. Membership of this committee included representatives from the Department of Infrastructure and Planning, the Local Government Association of Queensland, Kidsafe Australia, Queensland Master Builders and the Swimming Pool and Spa Association of Queensland.

After the review report, which contained 22 recommendations, was released in April 2009, the government sought public comments and held a series of forums across the state. The first stage of the swimming pool safety improvement strategy, which began on 1 December 2009, introduced a new safety standard for all new residential pools. All swimming pools built on or after that date must now undergo mandatory final inspections and display CPR signage. Stage 2 proposes to extend uniform safety standards to all existing pools across the state originally intended to be in place by the end of 2010. The first phase of stage 2 was enacted in May with the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Act 2010. This act established the legislative framework to support a new class of licensed pool safety inspectors, created the independent body the Pool Safety Council and established a state based swimming pool register.

The bill before the House today is the second phase of stage 2 and proposes amendments to the Building Act 1975 to extend pool safety laws to include pools at hotels, motels, other residential buildings, caretaker residences, caravan parks and indoor pools; to introduce a system for mandatory pool safety inspections at the point of sale and lease of properties with pools; to reduce the maximum depth of portable pools not requiring fencing from 450 millimetres to 300 millimetres--I might add here that children can still perish in one foot of water; to remove existing local government exemptions other than for those with a disability; to introduce a physical impracticality exemption to be administered by the chief executive; to require mandatory reporting to Queensland Health by public and private hospitals and the Queensland Ambulance Service of immersion incidents involving children; and to provide health professionals with the opportunity to voluntarily report pool immersion incidents.

The bill also amends the Animal Management (Cats and Dogs) Act 2008 to provide legislative clarity that Amstaffs and American pit bull terriers are not the same breed of dog following a recent court decision involving a Gold Coast case. Amendments are also proposed to the Royal National Agricultural and Industrial Association of Queensland Act 1971 and the Sustainable Planning Act 2009. The focus of my contribution this evening will be on the aspects of the bill relating to swimming pool safety.

My colleagues and I fear that we will be back here within a year debating another change to this legislation to rectify the mistakes made by this incompetent Labor government. Again, it would seem that the drafting of critically important legislation has been rushed through without taking on board the wisdom of key industry stakeholders even though there was ample opportunity. Are we headed for a repeat of the pink batts, green loans or sustainability declaration form debacles? All three initiatives were poorly thought through, shabbily planned and appallingly implemented--all three abject Labor government failures, trumpeted as groundbreaking schemes yet failing disastrously due to sloppy planning, inept governance and true-to-form Labor government incompetence.

According to the explanatory notes, the objective of the government’s pool safety reform is ‘to help reduce the incidence of pool related immersion injuries and death’ particularly for children under five. Unreservedly, the LNP supports stronger measures for pool-fencing laws, provided that they are fair and workable and that they afford the protection for which they are designed. As I have stated when addressing previous legislation on this subject, I have witnessed the tragic after-effects in my role as a paediatric nurse, and therefore it is my strongest belief that there can be no legislation or regulation implemented by government that dilutes the responsibility of parents and guardians to supervise their children in and around the pool or, for that matter, any body of water. Sadly, the majority of cases of immersions and drownings under five are preventable.

It is critically important that the message of swim safety advocate and Currumbin local Laurie Lawrence continues to hold precedence in early childhood--fence the pool, shut the gate, teach your kids to swim, supervise and learn to resuscitate. These five simple principles have, without doubt, saved countless lives over the 22 years that Laurie has been promoting the swim safety message to all Australians.

The swimming pool safety improvement strategy will replace 12 existing pool barrier standards with a single standard that applies to all regulated pools. This was a key recommendation of the review report presented to the government as a result of confusion from differing standards for pools built at different times. Compliance will be required at the point of sale or lease or within five years, whichever occurs first, for properties with non-shared pools. However, specific provisions have been provided for shared pools. Shared pools associated with short-term accommodation will be given a six-month phase-in period, while all other shared pools will be given two years.

I would question the government’s motives of paramount child safety in light of the number of concessions that have been included in this legislation that favour the tourism industry. The explanatory notes state that this provision is a concession to this important industry, which may face difficulties reaching compliance at the start of the busy summer period--another example of poor planning and coordination by the Bligh government.

Incentive schemes have also been offered in this legislation, encouraging operators to ‘get in early’ in exchange for a two-year certificate instead of one year. Other shared pool owners will be given a two-year phase-in period, placing questions over why the safety of some shared pools is less urgent than others, and less urgent again for non-shared pools. Where is the uniformity in that?

Members of key industry bodies are discouraged by the government’s last-minute decision to include a 90-day allowance with the point of sale and lease provisions within this bill. Where a seller has not secured a pool safety certificate prior to settlement, the onus is then placed on the purchaser to comply within 90 days. This is contrary to other mandatory point-of-sale obligations that must be borne by the seller, such as the installation of smoke alarms. This was pointed out by the honourable member for Gympie.

When considering child safety as the paramount objective of these changes, the consequences of legislating for a potentially dangerous situation to remain for as long as three months must be addressed. Research indicates ‘the risk of drowning is highest during the first six months’ in a new property--a direct quote from the minister’s second reading speech. What the minister failed to mention, however, was that his government’s policy will leave this hazard wide open. Who will take responsibility for a child who drowns in that 90-day period because of inadequate pool fencing? This is why the LNP will be putting forward an amendment.

I turn now to the provisions in the bill regarding exemptions. A stated aim of this legislation is to remove existing local government exemptions other than exemptions for persons with a disability. Whilst I understand the complexities encountered by many people with disabilities, having a disability does not preclude a person from having children in the home. Surely children of disabled persons should have adequate safety precautions in place as those with able parents and carers. Disability exemptions will continue to be decided by local councils. I note that the exemption is to remain with the person and not the property which offers reassurance to the individual concerned should they move to another residence. New occupiers will need to adjust the property to meet full safety requirements.

I also want to note the inclusion of impractical and somewhat contradictory compliance exemptions that will allow for a pool owner to apply to the chief executive for an exemption in the case of physical movement of a building or wall being required for the construction of a fence or the removal of any protected vegetation under an act or local law. I do not doubt the impossibility of certain circumstances to erect a pool fence or similar safety device, but if the safety of children is the overriding principle why is the government prepared to relax laws for a protected species of plant?

Having the distressing experience of nursing paediatric immersion patients I welcome the provisions in this bill enforcing mandatory reporting by hospitals of pool immersion incidents involving children. Reported data will undoubtedly enable a greater factual base to direct future policy for improving safety standards and procedures. Bath immersions, as a result of children being left unattended, should also be reported. Voluntary reporting by health professionals is also encouraged by protection from disciplinary action under this bill.

Of particular concern when considering the scope of this legislation is the considerable uncertainty as to the number of swimming pools in Queensland. In his second reading speech the minister alludes to some 325,000 pools existing in Queensland. However, SPASA, the peak industry body, suggests the figure is closer to 900,000 swimming pools across Queensland. If the minister has worked out his time lines on the figures he quotes then he has miscalculated greatly.

This gross inaccuracy could present some issues with the implementation and operation of the state based swimming pool register which was established in the previous legislation passed in May. To date, the minister still has not been forthcoming as to exactly how this will work. Perhaps he will enlighten us in his reply.

The following concerns were raised in a recent meeting with industry stakeholders on this legislation. Training and qualification requirements have still not been revealed even though the legislation is upon us. There is no requirement for prerequisite building or similar experience to become a licensed pool fence inspector. The costs of the training course and inspections look likely to be greater than the government’s modest estimates which will undoubtedly be passed on to the consumer. The special provision that on-site inspections are not required for pools in remote areas of the state is of concern. Also there were concerns that the department will approve course providers other than registered training organisations, as we saw with the ill-fated pink batts and green loan schemes. The 90-day period for compliance at the point of sale or lease defies the major purpose of the legislation which is to position child safety as the paramount objective as child drownings are more likely to occur in a new and unfamiliar dwelling. The requirements for fencing portable pools filled above the new 300 millimetre maximum depth cannot be adequately enforced. As I said, these were issues raised by industry experts, not by me.

It would seem from this extensive list of issues that Labor has not thought through this properly and obviously has not taken on board validated information from respected industry stakeholders. Of most concern is that there are no clear definite guidelines. This legislation reads, as is so often the case from the Bligh government, as a rudimentary draft, a naive work in progress, despite Bligh announcing new laws were on the way back in December 2008.

Such elementary planning is unacceptable for such far-reaching legislation that will affect so many people, particularly on the Gold Coast where my electorate is based. It is also imperative that legislation of this nature, with its mandatory requirements that have hefty financial consequences, be economical. Prohibitive costs to homeowners and the bodies corporate are an inevitable outcome of these stringent proposed safety measures, especially at a time when people on the Gold Coast and in my Currumbin electorate are really hurting from the spiralling costs of living under this Labor government. Fuel prices, electricity prices, water prices are all on a staggering unstoppable ascent with no reprieve in sight. Without question, the hip pockets of swimming pool owners are going to hit hard by the provisions of this legislation.

According to the explanatory notes, pool upgrades are expected to cost $95 million and pool safety inspections $80 million over the first 10 years. It can only be assumed that these are completely unfounded estimates given there is no certainty as to how many pools exist in Queensland and the extent to which some homeowners will need to go to comply with these new standards.

As many pools on the Gold Coast have been designed with lake, canal or beach views in mind--and perhaps hinterland views, as is my case--it is understandable that some pool owners would be seeking a transparent glass or perspex fence that would not obstruct their views rather than the cheaper aluminium alternative. Costs could be in the vicinity of $20,000 which is a hefty impost, particularly for homeowners whose exemptions will be removed abruptly by this legislation.

Due regard must be given to the effect these unprecedented compliance costs will have on the average household. In addition, checks need to be in place to ensure that prices do not suddenly go through the roof and cause a plethora of rogue operators to appear. According to the explanatory notes, the administration costs of the established Pool Safety Council are expected to reach $19.7 million over 10 years to administer the pool safety inspection and licensing system. Once again, if this figure has been calculated on the minister’s estimates then it is way off the mark and would be almost triple this amount.

Alarmingly these costs are to be recovered in part by fees and charges levied on pool owners. I hope there will not be additional charges above and beyond the already imposing costs to meet compliance that pool owners will be forced to fork out for the administration of this government implemented independent council. I would ask if the minister would clarify which costs are being referred to here.

Of critical importance to the success of this safety reform is education--a sentiment that was shared by the review committee. Widespread awareness of the changes must be made a funding priority by the department and this government. In his second reading speech the minister referred to ‘developing a targeted education and awareness campaign’. I would ask the minister if he is able to inform the House of the progress of this campaign and the costs associated with it.

I again raise concerns from the debate of the previous legislation back in May that were brought to my attention by a private certifier. This experienced individual held reservations that the number of qualified inspectors will be far short of that needed to adequately and thoroughly inspect the existing number and future growth of pools in Queensland that this legislation will affect.

Given the number of pools across the state and the gross miscalculation being used by the minister, there are concerns about the volume of work that will be initiated by the mandatory point of sale and lease provisions proposed in the bill and having an adequate number of trained, qualified and licensed inspectors in time for the commencement of these provisions. These concerns have been compounded by our meeting with industry stakeholders who shared these exact reservations. It is now believed that the government’s own deadline of 1 December this year may not be met because, put simply, it is just not ready.

Tasked with approving training qualifications and eligible course providers, it is deeply concerning to learn that the Pool Safety Council established by the act in May only met for the first time a couple of weeks ago, which is completely unsatisfactory considering the closeness to the proposed commencement date. At this late stage the minister has not revealed what training modules will be required for licensing pool safety inspectors.

There are fears--and I mean genuine fears--that the implementation of nationally recognised training modules will be bypassed in the name of political expediency as the minister rushes to meet his self-imposed December deadline. In his rush to play catch-up the minister must be very careful that he does not compromise the efficacy of this legislation by approving short cuts to training that would permit substandard qualifications for people to become inspectors as this would present an unacceptable risk to the safety of children.

I ask whether the minister is prepared to take responsibility for a child who drowns as a result of a poorly trained inspector, one allowed to operate due to inferior standards set by his department. Already residents in my electorate have raised their concerns about a sudden proliferation of swimming pool inspectors converging on the suburbs, knocking on doors and ringing telephones signing people up for contracts and doing deals. Add to that inflated prices by pool fencing companies that will pop up overnight like mushrooms and a recipe for disaster looms for consumers. In summary, the LNP is supportive of legislation for tougher pool safety laws to protect the safety of young children as the primary aim. However, as I have made unequivocally clear, we are not supportive of this Labor government’s haste in introducing poorly drafted critically important swimming pool reform legislation. We are also not supportive of the fact that so much has been left unresolved, not allowing for a true indication of how these measures will be implemented. Unfortunately, this wait-and-see attitude simply does not cut it when the safety of Queensland’s children is at stake. I really hope that the minister is able to allay these fears in his reply.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (8.20 pm): The Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is a unique bill that has application to pool owners for mandatory pool safety inspections, dog owners who do not want to have their dogs classified as pit bull terriers and a safety net for the RNA in Brisbane. There are problems with regard to two areas of the bill. It goes without saying that the RNA changes seem appropriate for an institution that has lasted 140 years. The statistics on both immersion injuries and drownings of children in swimming pools are well known. Tragically, whilst not all of the 50-plus immersion injuries annually in Queensland lead to death, the consequences for the family, the child and the community are horrendous. It all happens so quickly, so silently and so close to care. Pools continue to be built at a massive frequency. It is currently estimated that one in three new dwellings in South-East Queensland has a pool installed, yet we swim less, have smaller families and both parents are often working full time. With an average cost of between $12,000 and $20,000, homeowners are building pools at the same rate as their massive media rooms. Fortunately, pool fencing legislation is mandatory but is constantly challenged. I make my own comments with regard to media rooms. I do not think they are necessary.
Ms Grace interjected.

Dr DOUGLAS: As the minister pointed out in his second reading speech, these new laws applying to new pools commenced in December 2009 after extensive consultation. In single families I think a media room is probably appropriate, member for Brisbane Central, but in larger families I wonder if TVs are used as child-care methods.

Stage 2 affects existing pools and the intention is to ensure both compliance with fencing laws and mandatory inspections at point of sale or lease. As has been noted, the Building Act 1975 facilitates a new pool safety inspector licensing system and Pool Safety Council to assume control of the licensing system. There is a legitimate concern that the laws are being implemented without enough training of inspectors, and the fact that there may not be enough of the inspectors on the ground could be an issue. For property owners who are selling this is an extra compliance cost and for those leasing with either a renewal or a new lease it is another cost. The challenge for local councils is to get it done and get paid for doing so. An owner may want a reasonable cost and some certainty both in terms of timeliness and certification of the issue of their certificates and many fear the transfer of liability, especially from public risk back to the owners.

I believe in pool fencing regulation and the need to make it mandatory. My real concerns stem from a number of legal cases, particularly on the Gold Coast, where the Supreme Court has upheld that owners who have taken all and many steps to make their pools safe or similar were still found to be liable in complex, truncated, technical cases over everything from inadequate signage to inadequate adult supervision and, in one awful case, blame a very doubtful technical failure of fencing close to a canal as the reason for a disaster that occurred. There are a few recent well-publicised cases, but there will be more with the advent of more homes having tanks installed where we are likely to see problems similar to pools given that most of these tanks have no security fencing and have mains power points attached to pumps located close to the tanks and open tops that will allow children entry. The minister has detailed closely how the system will work and how councils will manage the pool safety inspectors and issues of complaints. It is disconcerting that there has been no regulation requiring notification to owners regarding entry to properties. The issue of appointments and permission to be on private property will have to be clarified. I believe this has been raised by the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee. It is worth noting that these inspectors will be able to carry out minor repairs which seems to add a layer of common sense to these regulations, and the minister is to be congratulated on taking those steps.

There will be a state based pool register created and maintained. All pool owners will be compelled to register, with a new offence provision for those who do not do so. I am a pool owner and, like many other pool owners, have great interest in how this proceeds. Like most, safety remains a burning concern for us all--everything from the quality of water, efficient filtration, adequate total perimeter child-proof fencing with reliable child-safe locking gate systems and high pool visibility from the most utilised aspect of the house. We must leave no stone unturned in the pursuit of what constitutes the ideal pool design, pool fencing and certification with known proven safe methods. What remains at issue is how to cater for both the rogue and those who become neglectful. A pool does require some skill to maintain beyond being built and delivered. For many, maintenance is done by external qualified pool maintenance staff and pool franchisees. But for many that is not so. Most owners learn from the school of hard knocks. Pool water testing is random, infrequent and in Queensland heat usually leads to an unsatisfactory result. Fully automatic does not necessarily mean that the owners or lessees of those properties do not need to check a pool constantly, and pool water is potentially harmful, especially after summer rain. The Gold Coast of course gets seasonal rain as well, particularly at the end of September as summer comes. It also gets seasonal rain in late January. These are times of the year when holidays are occurring and children are around.

Pool fences, panels, locks, magnets, key locks and missing rivets all need to be checked on a routine basis. The majority of pools are salt water and there is a significant corrosion factor that needs to be considered as a safety issue, and it needs to be raised as a particular issue because it is an increasing problem in South-East Queensland that saltwater pools are not being maintained as regularly as they should. All pool parts--fences, gates and external furnishings--have a high-wear factor. They can become dangerous. For those reasons, licensing is necessary and needs to be repeated. Most homeowners stay an average of seven years in their own home and lessees five years. Therefore, this regulation will probably give rise to a check time frame that should address most of those issues.

I remain concerned about the issue of children drowning or suffering immersion injuries in friends’ or neighbourhood pools, especially when those neighbours or friends may not be home. For those reasons, in the absence of mandatory front and rear fencing, I believe that all pool fencing should be a total perimeter 1.2-metre minimum with a 100 maximum bottom-to-ground space and a similar bar-to-bar width. No glass or fencing should be permitted to be frosted facing the dwelling because the pool should be totally visible at all times. All edges should be blunted and rolled to eliminate cuts to children. All gates under current rules should have an adequate safety lock. This is essential. There does appear to be an area of general concern--that is, those homes that are reliant on self-closing locks or glass doors where the pool immediately adjoins the home. This is not raised in the bill but is a particular problem throughout the state. I would have to say that this is an older home problem, but it does occur in newer homes as well because people want their pools to abut the rear decks of their homes. It is timely that this anomaly is discussed in terms of dwellings having a safety door. Currently, premises are allowed to have a self-closing sliding door. That needs to be excluded. Additionally, all dwellings where pools have adjoining common areas or waterways must be completely fenced on all four sides.

I accept that there are valid reasons for every situation, just as long as there are gates that can be closed with child safety locks where this cannot be achieved. All power should have safety cut-out switches to the main power board. Pool lighting and pool spas should require further review, because I think these issues have not been adequately discussed. As I said, wear and tear remains a considerable issue and I think that currently it is an issue that is not adequately addressed in any bill that is facing us. With the numbers of pools that have high utilisation because they are shared, particularly where there are numbers of units, and also the increasing use of saltwater pools, I think wear and tear is an issue. The evidence supporting pool safety fencing is now irrefutable. When combined with teaching all children to swim at an early age, CPR training and a healthy respect for water, collectively we will reduce child immersion fatalities and injuries. I believe that we will also reduce the death rate.

I like the new rules regarding wading pools, particularly the maximum depth being reduced to 300 millimetres from 450 millimetres. The likelihood of drowning is said to be reduced by a very high margin--I believe it is three times per 150 millimetres. I am not sure whether going below a depth of 300 millimetres reduces the likelihood further. Fish ponds, both internal and external, and external and internal water features are increasingly common in homes that are being built in South-East Queensland. I believe that they should be rated as wading pools and that they should have the same rules apply to them. Currently, fish ponds and water features are largely uncovered. I believe that there should be discussion about covering them with mesh or glass. It would seem erroneous not to draw fish ponds and water features into this current rule. It is a worrying trend, particular on the Gold Coast, that homes with fish ponds and water features are being built for sale. I remain of the opinion that all public areas that retain water, particularly those that have depths of greater than 200 millimetres, require perimeter shielding, particularly if the entry point is reasonably accessible by any human being, particularly a child.

The dog issue remains in part an issue of debate, DNA, desire and ‘damned if you do and damned if you don’t’. There appears to be a near universal view that an American pit bull terrier is a dangerous breed of dog. It is an unpredictable dog. It is bred as a fighting dog. It is unlawful to have the breed here and, as such, the breed is unsuitable for domestic, urban, semiurban and particularly rural environments. We have enough problems with wild dogs as their effect on our agricultural industry is significant. If there is a mechanism that clarifies the Staffordshire breed as a safe dog then so be it. Any breed causing any problem requires further review. Certainly in my electorate there have been significant problems with dogs attacking people. To tell you the truth, I think that any dog that deems itself a problem we would be better off without.
Mr Rickuss interjected.
Dr DOUGLAS: I am actually a dog lover. I think dogs need to be supported. I think they are great for families and they are also great company for people in their older years.

I move on to the issue of the RNA, which is a much loved institution in Queensland that occupies a special place in the state’s history. As many people know, the RNA has extensive freehold and leasehold land at the base of Spring Hill and adjoining the Valley. The site contains a number of historical buildings, including the John McDonald Stand and a number of facades, including the sample bag pavilion. The RNA is expertly run by John Tunny and the chair, Vivian Edwards, who is a neurologist practising in Ipswich and also in Brisbane. The RNA stages many events annually, but the Ekka is the key event that has universal acceptance throughout Brisbane and the state. In fact, many people seem to remember going to the Ekka for their whole lives.

The development of theme parks, particularly Movie World and Dreamworld, and the corporatisation of agriculture seems to have affected the RNA significantly. The difficulty that the RNA experiences is the one-off cost of holding such events. Maybe the reality is that the Ekka could change and the land may have to be sold. This is disappointing but, like everything, it remains a possibility. The government is attempting to set conditions upon which that might occur. I find that rather worrying on a number of levels. Like everybody, I certainly do not want to see things that have remained such an institution for a long time change, but I think we have to have faith in the management, and the board has to manage the RNA as it sees fit. Of course, the RNA sits on largely private property and the management of the RNA is trying to manage it the best way it can.
