I think realistically the bill is attempting to do many things and maybe to hamstring them is not the right way to do it.

There are many ways of looking at the RNA, and probably this is so because the Royal National Association reflects many different things to many different people. As I have said, for country people the RNA delivers a method of displaying their stock and produce. For some, the RNA presents a chance to compete and be rewarded in the market for doing so. It gives these people a social outlet, both the show itself and the many events during show week. For city people, the RNA provides them with the chance to see aspects of country life, especially small animals for children and a vast array of all sorts of things that reflect life itself and, certainly, a lot of our history. The fireworks in the night-time almost mark the end of winter. The RNA employs many people and it provides a big cash impetus for our community. Every province, state or nation has some form of vehicle by which they can display themselves to others and their own public. The Ekka is Queensland’s and, probably moreover, it is South-East Queensland’s. Therefore, the RNA is rightfully not anyone’s property but everyone’s property. The future of any of the RNA--either bits of it or as a whole--should be widely discussed.

The government correctly put the Inner City Bypass in a tunnel under sideshow alley years ago and it remains reluctant to be prescriptive with what the board of the RNA plans for its own future. The Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital, being so close, benefits by virtue of the public space provided by the RNA and so does an increasingly dense inner-city urban population. I think we need to leave the RNA site as it is.

As has been stated, the LNP is putting forward amendments to this bill. Rather than government members saying that there should be no amendment, I put it to members that there are many solutions to serious problems and that they should remember that every life saved is a child’s and a family’s life that is changed for the better forever. No-one should ever think they have all the answers. Governments are often the last to find enlightenment.

In my own electorate over past years there have been terrible tragedies arising out of pool drownings. These are not statistics to champion. I really want something better for all. If a drowning is preventable--as most are--then the efforts must be targeted at achieving a zero result. It is true that 40 per cent of the state’s 300,000 pools are indeed unsafe and that they would fail a routine safety check. This bill offers every child and their family a positive step in safety and an opportunity to alter that awful grief of families who may well have a child suffer from such a terrible tragedy. This statistic of 23 children drowning in three years is one that we should say is in the past. If compliant pool fencing is the answer, so be it.

Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (8.38 pm): I rise to contribute to the debate on the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2010. This is a positive bill with good outcomes for the community and it will be good to see it passed before the swimming season starts. This bill focuses on reducing the number of immersion accidents and deaths of young children aged under five years. In a community that has become busier, it is vital that each home has the protection that is needed to ensure that young children are safe in those few minutes where a vigilant parent is distracted. This legislation relates to stage 2 of the swimming pools strategy and it is important in my electorate of Redcliffe because there is an increasing number of pools but also many canal homes built in the 1980s under earlier pool legislation. This part of the legislation harmonises all regulations into one set of standards.

I am going to focus on the role of local government and inspectors in ensuring a timely and effective implementation program. I am aware that much emphasis has been placed on ensuring that services will be readily available when required to meet pool owner demand. This is particularly important as the primary method of determining a pool’s compliance with the new standard is through pool safety inspectors. As demand is expected to increase following the commencement of this legislation, in order to provide a necessary fail-safe this bill provides that local governments are required to offer a pool safety inspection service on request. In this way, regardless of where a pool is located in Queensland, the pool owner will have adequate access to pool safety inspection services. This will be of particular benefit to pool owners in rural and regional areas where it may be more difficult to obtain private pool safety inspection services. Because of this fail-safe function, local governments are integral to the pool inspection process and I would like to acknowledge this fact today. However, the government is also conscious of the fact that pool safety systems should not simply place a large burden on local governments. As such, we have taken concrete and positive steps towards streamlining the responsibilities of local government.

The role of identifying noncompliant pools will shift to the chief executive as the keeper of the state-wide pool register. Local governments will benefit from improved data collection and reporting practices. Armed with this information they will be empowered to focus their resources, allowing them to conduct their traditional pool safety responsibilities with greater effectiveness. It will also allow local governments to undertake their enforcement responsibilities with greater efficiency in relation to high-risk pools, particularly those in which an immersion incident has occurred.

The bill recognises the particular challenges involved in providing services to remote areas. To meet these challenges the bill provides that certain inspections may be conducted remotely. If a pool is located in a remote area as declared by a resolution from the local government, an inspector may then inspect the pool using any documents or technology they deem fit. If using these methods they can satisfy themselves that the pool complies, then they may issue a pool safety certificate. This provision empowers both private and local government inspectors and is an innovative solution designed to ensure that pool inspection businesses can provide appropriate service levels to remote areas. The bill will ensure that the innocent pool owners are not taken advantage of by inappropriate practices.

The passage of this bill will allow sufficient time for the government to deliver a comprehensive marketing and communications campaign that will inform pool owners of their obligations. The campaign will make it clear that pool owners must only employ licensed pool inspectors. I would like to take this opportunity to assure all members that pool safety inspectors must be licensed. To obtain this licence pool safety inspectors must undergo a training course that has been approved by the Pool Safety Council. It is through these licences that owners will be able to access the services of legitimate pool safety inspectors.

I am aware that the department has made significant progress in terms of pool safety inspector training, with work having already begun on pool safety inspector training courses. It is also encouraging to note that a number of expressions of interest and requests for information from people interested in training to become legitimate pool safety inspectors have been received. With all of its members appointed, the Pool Safety Council will convene its first meeting later this month. One of the most important items on the council’s agenda will be to discuss the progression of the training course and possibly, if circumstances permit, a review of the course materials. These training courses are part of a comprehensive strategy designed to ensure that at the commencement of this bill there are enough pool inspectors to meet consumer demand.

Modelling shows that as the new pool safety system is expected to encourage a $45 million investment in the pool safety industry, the equivalent of 100 to 200 full-time pool safety inspector jobs will be created. However, given that many building professionals will be encouraged to add pool inspections to their existing repertoire, Treasury anticipates that there will also be between 600 and 1,000 part-time inspectors. This will provide jobs for up to 200 people as we come out of the global financial crisis. This legislation is in line with the Bligh government’s Toward Q2 plan to build a strong economy and a strong community.

Given that a spike in demand is expected shortly after the commencement of this legislation, a conscious effort has been made to ensure that consumer demand may be successfully met. Building certifiers have been empowered for one year from the commencement of this bill to grant pool safety certificates. After this year they will be required to have a pool safety inspector licence if they wish to continue inspecting pools. In this way they will be subject to the same legislative requirements as other pool safety inspectors and subject to the same code of conduct. It is also important to know that when a building certifier signs off on a newly developed property as compliant with building standards this will be considered adequate confirmation of the pool’s compliance and a pool safety certificate can be deemed to be in effect for its usual duration--that is, one year for shared pools and two years for non-shared pools.

In addition to the pioneering reforms that promote the safety of Queensland children, this bill also amends the Animal Management (Cats and Dogs) Act 2008 to provide clarity and certainty to nearly 4,000 American Staffordshire terrier--or Amstaff--owners in Queensland. I know that Minister Boyle took a personal interest in this matter and I am pleased that this bill will categorically distinguish Amstaffs from American pit bull terriers which are considered restricted dogs. This will clarify a recent Supreme Court decision which ruled that the two breeds were the same. Without amendments amstaffs might be subject to the same stringent keeping requirements associated with other restricted dogs at an estimated cost to owners of $5,000. The amendments clarify this government’s unbroken intention that as a rule American Staffordshire terriers do not trigger the same requirements. Of course judgements about the danger posed by a dog must be made on a case-by-case basis. Should a dog show menacing or aggressive behaviour, local governments are still empowered to declare the dog as menacing and enforce appropriate safety precautions.

Finally, the government recognises that the identification of dog breeds can be quite difficult so we have implemented a number of certification tools for breed identification to assist dog owners and local governments. The bill expands the role of a veterinary surgeon to enable vets to certify breeds of dog. It is hard to imagine another profession that deals with dogs so regularly and this expertise should be acknowledged.

The bill also recognises pedigree certificates issued by the Australian National Kennel Council and its members as acceptable evidence of a dog’s breeding. In this bill the minister has provided practical solutions for the community to keep young children safe and to ensure that our pets are safe for families and localities. I commend the bill to the House.

Ms FARMER (Bulimba--ALP) (8.49 pm): I rise to speak in support of the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2010. There is nothing more precious than our children’s lives. Each time we hear of the death of a child I am sure that the heart of every member in this House breaks just a little, feeling for the parents of that child and for the lost future that they face. That is why our job in passing this bill is so important. It is imperative that, in a state like Queensland, where we have so many backyard pools and a climate that irresistibly tempts young children into those pools as often as they can, we put legislation like this in place to ensure their safety. The bill, quite simply, delivers the most fundamental shake-up of pool safety legislation in nearly 20 years. This sentiment--to shake things up--is manifest in the bill and I am proud to be part of a government that has adopted such an innovative and comprehensive approach to pool safety.

This bill will be effective because the provisions it contains, many of which are the first of their kind in Australia, address pool safety from a number of different perspectives. Although implementing best practice safety standards has been proven to save lives, this bill also introduces a suite of measures designed to ensure the functional operation and enforcement of such standards. The mandatory point-of-sale and lease inspection systems, for instance, ensure that the owners of non-compliant pool fences are required to upgrade them. Importantly--and this is something on which I would like to speak in particular--the bill also introduces a mandatory immersion incident reporting system. This system will not only improve our knowledge and understanding of the factors which lead up to immersion incidents, it also means that the right remedial action is undertaken whenever and wherever an immersion incident occurs.

The rationale behind the immersion reporting system is very simple: by opening up the avenues of communication between those who are at the coalface of immersion incident response and those who collate, analyse and assess immersion incident information, we can improve the consistency and validity of immersion incident data. Although we are only too aware of the tragic figures surrounding drownings in backyard pools, unfortunately, we simply do not have accurate data around immersion incidents. Without that, we cannot fully understand what we need to do to address pool safety issues in the best possible way.

Under this bill, ultimately, if a child is submerged or partially submerged in any pool and their health or wellbeing is adversely affected, this will be sufficient to trigger its reporting as an immersion incident. This is a key reform as it will, over time, improve the accuracy of reporting in non-fatal immersion incidents. Closing this data gap will improve the quality of research and analysis into the antecedence of all pool immersion incidents and will allow relevant organisations to more accurately assess pool safety issues. This will improve the quality of the solutions we can propose. Obviously, to achieve the greatest benefits of this system, relevant organisations or individuals must report immersion incidents in a consistent, regular and uniform manner. So the bill places mandatory reporting obligations on public and private hospitals as well as on the Queensland Ambulance Service. It also provides protection to individual health professionals who voluntarily report immersion incidents.

The bill contains an obligation for the Queensland Ambulance Service to provide written notice to the chief executive of Health when and if the service is notified of a pool immersion incident, and a similar obligation is applied to the person in charge of a hospital. In both cases, the notice must be provided within five business days and contain, as a rule, the name and date of birth of the child involved, the date of the incident or examination, the address of the child’s parents and the address where the immersion incident occurred. The bill does not require an investigation to occur and the information is only mandatory if it is known. In this way, a conscious effort has been made to only require information that is usually gathered in the course of day-to-day operations. This will mean that ambulance staff as well as nurses and doctors in emergency departments are not burdened by red tape and can remain focused on their lifesaving activities.

As well as these mandatory obligations, the bill empowers individual health professionals to report to the chief executive of Health any information relevant to a case they believe involves a pool immersion incident. It does so by explicitly removing any concern that health professionals may have about their legal liability in the situation or their compliance with a code of ethics, etiquette or professional conduct. The aim of this is to give health professionals the confidence to report immersion incidents to the chief executive of Health, thereby helping to make sure that there is comprehensive and accurate collection of immersion data. Once the chief executive of Health has received notice of a pool immersion incident, the bill provides five business days to give notice of the pool immersion incident to the Pool Safety Council, the relevant local government, the Commission for Children and Young People and Child Guardian and the chief executive of the Department of Infrastructure and Planning. Once the relevant local government has received this notification, they must inspect the pool. In this way, any necessary problems with the pool fencing will be identified and fixed.

The mandatory immersion reporting system will encourage compliance with safety standards. Ultimately, it will promote accurate and comprehensive data collection on immersion incidents. There is no doubt that these innovations will play a critical role in ensuring that we are making the best informed decisions in the future about how to improve pool safety for our young children.

I congratulate the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning on his genuine dedication in bringing about these reforms and on his work with all stakeholder groups to ensure that the reforms are suitable and acceptable but also tough and right for the job they need to do. This sort of legislation is so important. Looking after our kids is so important. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr RICKUSS (Lockyer--LNP) (8.56 pm): I rise to say a few words on the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2010. I would like to acknowledge the presence in the gallery of Andrew Plint from Hannah’s Foundation. I am sure the minister’s office has had a lot to do with Andrew and his wife, Katherine, who have been very involved with Hannah’s Foundation since the unfortunate passing of their daughter Hannah. The minister acknowledged Hannah’s Foundation in his second reading speech for providing some assistance with some of the regulations in this bill. He acknowledged also the Royal Life Saving Society, the Queensland Law Society, the Real Estate Institute of Queensland and people like Laurie Lawrence and general community members who have always been interested in this sort of thing.

I had the good fortune of having a meal with Andrew tonight--I am sure he will not get into trouble with Katherine about that--in the Strangers’ Dining Room and we discussed some of these issues. It is an ongoing learning curve. I must support the amendment that the member for Gympie has brought into the House. It seems to be a common-sense amendment. The community as a whole would probably support that amendment, too. There are arguments for and against leaving the legislation as it currently stands, but I do feel that the amendment is probably justifiable as we have already legislated for the mandatory installation of safety switches and smoke alarms in houses at the point of sale. So this is probably not a bad amendment as well.

We do need to be careful. It is about supervision as much as it is about regulations for fencing. Parents still have to be careful. On my own property in Laidley we have a pool with the appropriate pool fencing, but through the fence is the Lockyer Creek, which at the moment would be about 18 feet deep. So people have to supervise continually. The same principle applies to blow-up pools, and the bill’s provisions regarding fencing now apply to the reduced depth of a pool of 300 millimetres from the previous 450 millimetres. People need to be aware that particularly small infants can still drown in those sorts of things. They can drown in bathtubs as well. It is a shame.

I must congratulate Andrew, Katherine and the other members of Hannah’s Foundation. Not only are they interested in pool regulation and child safety, but they also act as a consulting and support network for people who have suffered such a tragic loss in their families. This service has been sadly needed. When Hannah did pass they realised this sort of support network was missing from society. It is people like Andrew and Katherine who actually do make a difference to society. They have put a lot of work into it, even through a lot of heartache. I say congratulations on the great work they have done over the years.

All we can do is look to the legislation that has been introduced. It is great to see the movement on this since 1 December, when stage 1 was introduced. We are now dealing with stage 2. I imagine that pool regulations will be toyed with over a number of years and, hopefully, we will see emerge the regulations that will enforce the safety standards that we need. Terrible tragedies can happen in spa pools and children have had their hair caught in pumps. Myriad mistakes can be made. Many of us have a lucky story where one of our children has fallen into a stream, creek, dam or pool and we have managed to pull them out in time. Supervision is really important.

Some of the data relevant to the bill has been collected from groups such as Hannah’s Foundation, the surf-lifesaving association and so on. It shows that a percentage of drownings happen in the early stages of the occupation of a new home. That is vital information that people must be aware of when they buy a new home or lease a new property. It is good to see that the minister has announced improved funding for an education and awareness campaign. We need a continual process of improvement in education and awareness. That is an ongoing program that needs to be continually improved. Unfortunately, at times the wrong people watch the ads. It is very important that we reach busy young families. Perhaps the department can distribute kits to the maternity units in hospitals so that the information is available to parents when their children are very young. We need to make families aware right from the start. That idea has come into my head as I stand here.
Mr Ryan: You almost opened yourself up there.
Mr O’Brien interjected.

Mr RICKUSS: That is right. They definitely do not. I do have a bit of original thought, not like a lot of the people sitting opposite. I support the bill and I support the amendment. It will be interesting to see whether the minister will take the amendment on board.
With the restricted dog legislation, unfortunately at times it is not about bad dogs but bad owners. We have to have this sort of legislation to ensure--
Mr Lawlor: Do you want to put the owners down as well?

Mr RICKUSS: That might not be a bad idea. Some of them probably do deserve to be put down. Definitely there are some bad owners. I have heard a statistic, and I am not sure whether or not it is right, that most people who are bitten by dogs are bitten by labradors. Maybe that is because labradors are popular family pets.
Ms Darling: I have a beautiful labrador.
Mr RICKUSS: Just check it out. I have heard that somewhere.
Ms Darling: Not my dog. You must have read it in the Courier-Mail

Mr RICKUSS: I might have read it in the Courier-Mail. I am sure the minister will be able to enlighten me on that statistic if it is not right. On the issue of the sustainability legislation about the privacy laws, some of the councils have gone overboard with the enactment of privacy laws. It has gone almost to the point of stupidity. I honestly feel it is a misinterpretation of the act. I encourage the minister to enlighten some of the councils about what they should be doing with some of the laws, because it is frustrating for constituents who are trying to find out information about privacy laws.

The legislation dealing with the RNA showgrounds is common-sense legislation. It should be put in place. My brother owns a block of land at the top end of Bowen Hills. He is fortunate that his block is in the UDA and will probably make him a squillion dollars. It was good luck that he bought in Bowen Hills 30 years ago when the land was not worth much money and now it is worth a lot of money.
Mr Hinchliffe: You’ve made a declaration, now.

Mr RICKUSS: He is my brother. It is not my land. I do not get any benefit out of it. It is opposite the showgrounds, in the area of interest. An interesting development will happen along that road and I congratulate the minister for that.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (9.04 pm): I rise to speak to the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). Along with every single person in this chamber, I believe that the protection of people from drowning is an important element of the bill. More particularly, the protection of children, especially small children, from drowning is critically important. Significant improvements have been made since the introduction of mandatory pool fencing to protect small children. Earlier, the member for Nanango and I were talking about this issue. She said that the safest thing around any pool is adult supervision and she is so right. There is no substitute for that.

Therefore, the changes to the legislation in relation to pool fencing are reasonable. A good education campaign to alert homeowners to any new obligations is very important to the success of the legislation. It is one thing to be able to hit people over the head with a stick if they do not comply, but they need to have full knowledge of their requirements. They need to be well advised of their new obligations. There is much that we can do in relation to pool fencing. I put on the record my appreciation to the many paid workers and volunteers who undertake lifesaving duties. They provide a wonderful service. However, as I have said there is no substitute for parental vigilance.

The bill clarifies the situation in relation to American Staffordshire Terriers, which are also known as Amstaffs. Certainly I have received my fair share of correspondence from American Staffordshire Terrier owners claiming that their dogs are safe and well behaved. Most dogs are wonderful. When a dog has a bad temperament, you have to look at the owner and see where that--
Mr Schwarten: Most dogs are better than most people.
Mrs CUNNINGHAM: I agree with the member for Rockhampton. If I were God, I would have picked dogs to work with.
Mr Schwarten: They love you unconditionally.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: Yes. The clarification in the bill is important. It will certainly give some peace to the owners of American Staffordshire Terriers. The dogs that bite the most are ones such as dachshunds, and our Aussie blue heeler is pretty well known for biting. Members should look at the statistics. The most unlikely dogs bite and little dachshunds are the worst. They are close to the ground and have to look for something to bite.
Mr Schwarten interjected.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: I am not going to touch that with a 40-foot pole. Some breeds of dog rate surprisingly high in terms of biting statistics. I commend the minister for giving some certainty and clarity to the owners of American Staffordshire Terriers.

The bill deals with the protection of the RNA Showgrounds, the Ekka site, for future generations. Again, I commend the minister for that. The showgrounds have a very sentimental place in the hearts of people right across Queensland and particularly those who live in the south-east corner. Whilst it is important that this development goes ahead in a private partnership, it is also important that the site be retained for future generations, not only because of its practical use but also because of its historical significance to the community. I support the legislation.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (9.07 pm): This evening I rise to make a contribution to the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2010. The purpose of this legislation is to amend swimming pool safety laws and it is the second phase of stage 2 to introduce mandatory pool safety inspections. The objective is to help reduce the incidence of pool related immersion injuries and deaths for a very vulnerable section of the community, children aged under five years. The bill introduces requirements for pool barriers to be regularly inspected by competent and qualified inspectors to ensure that they comply with a uniform pool safety standard. In the past pool-fencing laws have been successful in saving the lives of young children, and the aim of these reforms is to ensure the laws continue to achieve this objective in the most effective manner possible.

It is widely acknowledged that supervision is the first line of protection for children where swimming pools are involved. However, an effective pool barrier provides added protection in cases where supervision breaks down. Research undertaken by the Queensland Injury Surveillance Unit in 2002 suggests that at least 70 people are alive today because of the introduction of pool-fencing laws in the early 1990s. The LNP has concerns regarding the implementation of these laws, particularly regarding the rushed implementation foreshadowed to come into effect on 1 December 2010.

Between 1 January 2004 and 18 May 2010, 35 children under five years of age drowned in Queensland’s residential swimming pools, as well as two drownings in wading pools and one in a homemade pool. It is estimated that 50 young children present at emergency departments each year due to immersion injuries, some of whom will suffer permanent brain damage. Interestingly, I have my own personal experience with the near drowning of my son, Gregory, when he was just 18 months of age, but unfortunately this legislation does not cover the manner in which his close encounter occurred.

I took my son to a local nursery to buy plants and my son was busy taking the names of plants out of pots and putting them into different pots, just to confuse potential buyers. I went inside the nursery to purchase plants and I heard a splash. I luckily did not ignore this and ran outside to find my son submersed in a timber barrel, which are often used as planters. These barrels are filled with water before they are sold so that the barrels do not crack. Unfortunately this instance almost caused the drowning of my son. So I guess the moral of the story is that you cannot even go to somewhere relatively safe such as a nursery and not have an almost life-threatening incident occur. Luckily also for my son I am a nurse and I was able to give him CPR. These barrels of course are not captured in this legislation.

Defective fences remain a significant factor in the findings of coronial reports on fatal immersion accidents, with young children commonly shown to have gained access to a fenced pool through a gate or door. Such circumstances include where a pool gate has been propped open--often a result of pool gates that do not close or latch automatically--or a child gaining access to a pool via child-resistant doors, which were permitted for pools built before 1 February 1991.

Pool safety laws introduced in 1991 required all outdoor residential swimming pools to be fenced. These laws have contributed to saving 70 young children between 1992 and 2001. The LNP has concerns that training programs for inspectors who will implement these laws are yet to be finalised. There is yet to be a Pool Safety Council set up by the government, and the LNP has grave concerns that the inspectors carrying out these repairs to existing pool fences are yet to be certified so that the safety components of this legislation can be effectively enacted.

Under this legislation, the buyer of a property has 90 days to comply with the legislation and this will have an impact on local governments in the enforcement of these responsibilities and liabilities. The Liberal National Party will be supporting this legislation as the aim is to bring about improvements in pool safety. However, we continue to have grave concerns about the implementation of these important reforms. The consistent message amongst stakeholders in the review of this legislation was that, whilst everyone supported this as a move to improve safety for infants and young children around water, there still remained substantial concerns regarding the implementation of this legislation.
I note that my colleague the member for Currumbin mentioned the much lauded program by Laurie Lawrence, Kids Alive--Do the Five, which includes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. Fence the pool
2. Shut the gate
3. Teach your kids to swim--it’s great
4. Supervise--watch your mate and
5. Learn how to resuscitate
XML.Hansard-Body: This is particularly relevant in the Mudgeeraba electorate given that I do have a Laurie Lawrence swimming centre in the heart of the electorate. In addition, in my recent Bates Bulletin , I ensured that all residents residing within my electorate were aware of the upcoming changes to the legislation so that they could make provisions when buying or selling a property in the electorate.

Whilst the LNP welcomes any changes to legislation which will affect our most vulnerable, our children, there remains some reservations on how the implementation of this legislation will affect consumers and how effective this will be.

Mr RYAN (Morayfield--ALP) (9.13 pm): I rise to contribute to the debate on the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The key focus of this bill is to implement the next stage of this government’s pool safety reforms.

It is often said that one of the great Australian dreams is to own your own home. It may also be said that the great Queensland dream is to own your own home with a pool in the backyard. Queenslanders love the water. We love our lifestyle. But, sadly, the great Queensland dream can sometimes turn into a living nightmare. Sadly, families all around Queensland have been dealing with terrible tragedies involving children and swimming pools. What is worse is that some of these tragedies could have been prevented. There is no denying that these accidents can happen and may always happen. However, some of these accidents can be prevented. Even if this government through its pool safety reforms can prevent just one of those accidents into the future and save just one life, then these reforms have achieved something. The safety of our children is the key priority guiding these reforms.

As you know, Madam Deputy Speaker, this bill represents the culmination of the Queensland government’s swimming pool safety improvement strategy. It builds upon this government’s previous reforms and seeks to introduce a nation-leading implementation and compliance scheme for a strategy designed to reduce the incidence of immersion injuries and fatalities. The reforms outlined in this bill will reinforce the effectiveness of swimming pool legislation and will help protect young children from the risks associated with residential swimming pools. These risks are real and they are often frightening.

As consecutive stages of our pool safety program have been rolled out and particularly through each legislative initiative that has advanced this strategy, this House has heard exactly how many children have died each year because of incomplete or inadequate pool fencing. To remind you, Madam Deputy Speaker, and the House, in the period from 1 January 2004 to 18 May 2010, 41 children drowned in Queensland swimming pools. Of these 41 deaths, 10 occurred in public pools, 33 occurred in in-ground private pools, two occurred in above-ground pools, two occurred in wading pools and one occurred in a homemade pool. Last year alone, we lost eight children under the age of five. Even these figures are dwarfed by the number of immersion injuries that present to emergency departments each year. Children who survive are all too often robbed of a lifetime of opportunity due to permanent brain damage.

In spite of such sobering statistics, these tragedies are not an inevitable part of Queensland’s future. I wholeheartedly support this government taking decisive action to improve upon that record and promote the safety of young children around swimming pools. If this legislation, if this whole strategy, saves even one life, then it will all have been worth it.

As parents and carers are the first line of defence against an immersion incident, I am pleased to see that this government will promote supervision and vigilance as the primary means of ensuring a child’s safety around swimming pools. Teaching children to swim as early as possible is an effective means of preventing drowning tragedies. In recognition of these facts, I am pleased to see that this state Labor government has more than tripled its funding for this year’s summer safety campaign. The government’s campaign will again remind parents that supervision and swimming skills are the primary forms of defence against an immersion incident involving a young child.

I understand that the opposition is supporting this bill but will move some amendments. I particularly understand that the opposition will move an amendment to make the pool safety inspection a condition of sale. From my background as a property solicitor, I have some reservations about the foresight that goes with that particular amendment.
Mr Gibson: No different to smoke alarms or the earth certificate.

Mr RYAN: Perhaps if the member for Gympie had spoken to the self-appointed champion of property conveyancers, the member for Kawana, who has often spoken passionately in this House in defence of property conveyance lawyers and also real estate agents, he would know that one of the primary aspects of property transactions is providing certainty to both buyers and sellers. One of the primary aspects of providing certainty to buyers and sellers in property transactions is to limit the number of options for people to get out of their contract. The priority of this legislation is to improve pool safety. The priority is not to create additional burdens and uncertainties for purchasers and sellers of residential property. So the obligation is correctly placed in this legislation on people to ensure that pool safety is improved but will not create additional uncertainties and burdens on people who are parties to property transactions.

Although I welcome the opposition’s support, the particular amendment that will be moved by the member for Gympie poses some threat to the certainty surrounding property transactions for buyers and sellers and does not improve on the safety position in the legislation as it is drafted. Whilst I appreciate that some people may question the rigorous extent of these pool safety standards, it is critical that we place the safety of children first. It is important that this parliament now act to further improve pool safety as soon as possible. I take this opportunity to commend the minister, his staff and the department on their work in respect of the bill. With those comments I commend the bill to the House and encourage all members to support it.

Mr WENDT (Ipswich West--ALP)
(9.20 pm): I rise today to support the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I specifically intend to concentrate my comments around the point of sale inspection system but also the Sustainable Planning Act. This government--and I am sure all members in fact--believe that stronger pool fencing legislation can help save lives. That is why this bill introduces a new point of sale compliance system.

To ensure that this groundbreaking legislative scheme is effective, it has been drafted to cater for a wide range of circumstances where pools are used. This is vital to ensure that the lives of young children are protected whenever they use a pool or, just as importantly, visit other homes and places that have pools as well.

For some pool owners upgrades will not be necessary or will in fact be minor while for others there may be more substantial work required. However, I think it is fair to say that pool owners will be given ample opportunity over a five-year period to comply with the new laws unless of course they sell their property first. What this means is that pool owners will have a five-year period in which to prepare unless they sell the property before that period.

It is this sales trigger which is to become a key element of this bill and which will deliver on the government’s commitment to phase in the new pool safety standard for existing properties. It is felt that this will optimise the uptake of the new standards as it was also specifically designed to address the unacceptably high number of immersion injuries and deaths involving young children that occur shortly after families move into new and hence unfamiliar premises.

I think it is widely known and accepted that numerous pool safety organisations agree that the risk of drowning is highest among young children during the first six months of occupying a property. This is why the point of sale inspection system has been introduced. As such, if the seller already has a compliant pool fence, as evidenced by an approved pool safety certificate, they simply provide this to the purchaser. However, if a pool safety certificate is not in effect for the property the seller must provide notice to the purchaser and the chief executive of the Department of Infrastructure and Planning that such a certificate has not been obtained and that the pool fence may not comply with the appropriate standards. This notice must also state that the purchaser may need to complete upgrade work on the pool fence.

In cases where pools are sold without a pool safety certificate, the certificate must generally be obtained by the purchaser within 90 days of settlement. It is considered that, in this way, those families who purchase homes with pools are alerted to the potential dangers of non-compliant pools and their obligations. At the same time, this will also protect young children and families who may visit them by ensuring that pools are brought up to the new standard.

This legislation has been drafted widely to apply to both shared and non-shared pools. By way of example, shared pools include those located in unit complexes and motels. As such, a non-shared pool will most commonly be associated with a private house. For shared pools, if a seller has not already obtained a pool safety certificate then before they may legally settle a sale transaction they must also provide notice to the owner of the shared pool, which is usually the body corporate for the complex. In this way, all of the relevant parties are notified of their potential obligations. This will trigger the body corporate to bring the pool up to the new standard providing added protection for all unit owners and visitors.

By requiring that the chief executive be notified, the state based pool safety register can be appropriately updated with this information and subsequent follow-up action can be arranged and taken in relation to the potentially non-complaint pools. In addition, by notifying the purchaser the seller is informing the buyer of their obligations before the contract is settled, making them fully aware of the risks involved with the pool. It is considered that this will encourage vigilant supervision of young children around the pool.

In addition to these reforms, I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak about the reforms that this bill makes to the Sustainable Planning Act 2009. The planning and development online, or more widely known as PD online, facility has been utilised by many local governments for many years and is considered to be a valuable tool for providing easy access to information by the community about property details, planning scheme requirements, mapping and development application activities. I can attest to the fact that the community has long demanded ready access to this information. I believe that councils have welcomed it as an opportunity to demonstrate the openness and transparency of the process involved.

However, the Information Privacy Act 2009 that applies to local government from 1 July 2010 has meant that if any of the information provided on PD online contains personal information its publication may be in breach of the privacy legislation. As a consequence, PD online has to be removed from or partially closed at least on some council websites. I think this would be of concern to some community members, including councils, who have become reliant on this information being readily available on PD online.

In view of this, an amendment to the Sustainable Planning Act 2009 is proposed to remedy the situation by authorising the online publication of this material. This amendment simply authorises that the material may be published. It is significant that the amendment is not a strict requirement so the discretion remains with the council to decide whether to publish online or not. That is very important.

It is well known that the development application process under the Sustainable Planning Act 2009 is a public process and the council must make the development application and related material available to any person to view freely at the council’s office. As such, it is seen that having the information available on PD online simply facilitates accessability to this information and allows community members to avoid a personal visit to the council office.

However, it is also considered that council will have the discretion to remove the name, address and signature of persons making the submission from the publication of the submission about a development application as is the case when councils make submissions available for inspection over the counter. Council will also retain the discretion about whether to publish information or documents containing sensitive security information.

I believe that this bill successfully balances the need for ready access to development application materials with the protection of an individual’s personal information. Further, it also balances the need to grant pool owners sufficient time to prepare for reducing the danger inherent in high-risk pools. As such, ultimately it balances practical considerations with community safety to achieve the best possible outcomes in terms of public interest. It is for this reason that I commend the bill to the House.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP)
(9.26 pm): I too rise to speak in the debate on the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Legislation (No. 2). From the outset, let me add my support for any piece of legislation that looks to improve our ability to keep our kids safe, particularly when it comes to drowning deaths in swimming pools. When this bill came up for debate and we received the swimming pool safety laws brief put out by the Queensland Parliamentary Library I took the liberty of forwarding it on to a constituent of mine, Mr Harry Wrangell. The minister may remember that I mentioned some of the submissions that Mr Wrangell made to the review committee. Unfortunately, Mr Wrangell replied by saying that he still has not heard back from the review committee or anyone to do with the swimming pool safety law review which is a bit frustrating for not only Mr Wrangell but also me.

He still has a number of issues that I think are worthy of raising. I hope the minister will take a moment to listen to some of the concerns he raises. The research brief itself mentions that over half of fabricated metal fencing does not comply with the standard for strength. Substandard fencing is still being used. The brief, and certainly the legislation, does not go any further in terms of mentioning strategies to enforce the standard of fence panels nor have any fines or the like been imposed on manufacturers or suppliers of faulty products.

I think Mr Wrangell is right in suggesting that this may become a bit of an issue for pool inspectors when they try to determine the strength of the pool fencing. It is still the case that kids can get through, get around or push down some fencing. As Mr Wrangell suggests, testing for such standard compliance requires special hardware which is normally performed in laboratory type environments. It is going to be very difficult for pool safety inspectors on site to determine whether that pool fencing is up to standard.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Mr Wrangell suggests--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Other safety products must have a permanent label attached stating the relevant standard of compliance. This is why I suggest that pool safety panels, posts and gates must display this permanent marking. This is the only way that pool owners know that they have been supplied with an authorised product.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Wrangell is also very passionate about the gates and the locks around swimming pools, and he made a submission specifically around some of the work that he has been doing on alternatives. He strongly believes that many deaths and near drownings have been attributed to young children climbing up some movable object, reaching the release knob and gaining entry. He states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is beyond belief and logic thinking that the standards do not stipulate a minimum force which must be applied to release any locking mechanism.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Locks which use electromagnetic attraction to hold a locking bolt in place have a bad safety design defect. The locking feature can easily be negated by simply placing a metal washer over the magnet’s pole face. (the bottom half of the assembly).
The gate will still close perfectly, but it will never lock.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: If we continue to use substandard gates and locks then we possibly still have not got this right. He goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Another feature of this type of lock is that the force required to release the lock is insufficient, as well as the fact that the magnetic attraction on the plunger forms part of this force.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He suggests that--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... locking devices should be included in the Australian Standard (or State building codes), which would require that the locking pin arrangement be completely enclosed to make it tamper proof. Methods are available to do this.
XML.Hansard-Body: Ultimately, though, my biggest concern in terms of correspondence I continue to get from Mr Wrangell is that he has failed to receive any response or even acknowledgement from anyone involved in the pool safety law review. It really pains me to know that a constituent of mine is going to such effort to contribute to the debate, to contribute to the making of legislation and to contribute to the making of policy in this state and yet we cannot even acknowledge it. He concludes by saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I would appreciate a response as to how my suggestions were received, and if any of them look like being adopted. Incidentally, I requested some help on pool safety matters some five months ago--first to the Institute of Building Surveyors, and then to Building Codes Qld.--I am still waiting for a reply to the question I asked.
XML.Hansard-Body: If the minister has an opportunity in his reply to respond to some of those issues around the strength of the panelling, the gates and the locking mechanisms, I know that that will go a long way to assuaging the concerns of Mr Wrangell and me in those matters. With that, I commend the bill to the House.

Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP) (9.31 pm): Tonight I rise to contribute to debate on the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2010, which addresses pool safety, clarifies that the American Staffordshire bull terrier is a different breed from the American pit bull terrier, and sets out to protect the Ekka site should the RNA become insolvent. I will limit my comments to the pool safety components of the legislation.

I also add my congratulations to the officers who have put this legislation together. I congratulate the bureaucratic side of this government in terms of the policy that they have put together and recognise the work that they have done in bringing this legislation forward. However, I do have some concerns about this legislation. I have concerns about how this legislation will be implemented. While we applaud the sentiment and applaud anything that is a step in the right direction for pool safety, we are mindful of how this legislation will be administered, how it will be managed and the processes that will be followed.

In the first instance there is the creation of a new entity. The Pool Safety Council will be largely responsible for administering this new regime that is being rolled out. There will be a pool safety inspection regime and there are questions about how that might be managed and implemented. There are issues with the pool safety certificates in terms of how they will be managed. There are also questions about the pool safety inspector training regime and the courses that they will be put through. There are questions as to how that will be administered, how that will be delivered and who will deliver it. These are all critical questions in ensuring that this legislation is correct and does deliver what we want--that is, zero drownings in Queensland. If we can get this legislation right, we will be well on the way towards achieving that.

So we have all of those questions. There are also questions around the registration of all swimming pools. I took the liberty of talking to officers from Redland City Council today. Those officers believe that they are well on track to have that register ready to present to the Pool Safety Council. Their work is underway. This bill is obviously quite a significant piece of legislation in that it is going to affect an estimated 325,000 existing pools across Queensland and it is a huge task to manage that. The legislation also ensures that those same pools comply with the most recent regulations. Again, this is an important step forward.

Part of this bill relates to the requirements for portable pools or those pools with a depth of 300 millimetres, down from 450 millimetres. I would ask the minister during his summing-up if he could clarify some of the steps that have been taken in amending regulations requiring fencing or whatever instruments may be required in that instance. I take on board that that issue probably sits better with the Minister for Fair Trading in terms of those types of areas where these pools are purchased. However, the questions I have are around what information will be available at the point of sale. Again, I realise that this is not this minister’s responsibility, but there needs to be some connection between those two ministers and maybe in his summing-up the minister can touch on those issues. There are not only the requirements at the point of sale but also the requirements in terms of the packaging. What information will be available on the packaging for these portable pools? What sort of education regime are we looking at rolling out, because without getting those three things correct we will be no further advanced? We will not be achieving what we need to achieve in order to ensure pool safety.

I am absolutely certain, based on what I have heard from the minister’s second reading speech, that it is certainly not his intent nor is it the government’s intent, but there is the potential with this new regime of pool safety inspectors to create--and I have heard other members mention this--a set of circumstances as occurred with the insulation program. New businesses blossomed overnight. We need to ensure that we get the mechanisms right not only for the training but also for the type of people who are performing these functions. We need to ensure that we do not create another insulation type debacle or allow another water tank installer type business to blossom overnight. As we know, overnight business opportunities attract the opportunist. We need to ensure that everything is done to make sure that does not happen.

There is also the question around these same pool inspectors becoming repairers. Again, this is an opportunity where someone could introduce themselves as a legitimate pool inspector and quite legitimately be a pool inspector. During the audit period they may find some issues with gates, with fences and with latches in terms of minor works and see the opportunity to create their own small business empire. They are the questions I have for the minister.

This is about ensuring that we get all of that detail right, and we should not lose sight of the fact that we have very compressed time. This becomes law on 1 December and three months later everything needs to be up and running. There is that transition period, and I heard the shadow minister reference how we address that transition period and how the regulations will be able to be delivered upon. Looking at the legislation that has been put before us, none of these things has been finalised and that leaves me with an uncomfortable feeling. An issue that has been mentioned a couple of times and something that I have a great deal of difficulty in understanding is why the government would allow a vendor to, as it were, leave the scene of the crime and not make the home good before they move on.

I draw a parallel between selling a house and selling a motor car. I do not see any difference whatsoever. When I go to sell a car I cannot do so without having a roadworthy certificate for it. Why should I be able to sell a house without having the house fully compliant? It is simply one more check that needs to be made. You have to have your safety switches in place, you have to have your smoke detectors in place and you have to have your pool certified. That is what should be before this House today. Again, I am pleased that the shadow minister will be moving an amendment along those lines. Hopefully, those opposite will support it, because I think it is common sense.

It is absolute certainty that is required in this instance instead of passing the responsibility to the purchaser. As we have heard, vendors have 90 days in which to make the pool fence compliant. In that 90 days there is the highest risk of new pool owners, new families, moving into a home, experiencing a drowning or an immersion incident. I know absolutely that if we can get this legislation tidied up, it will be good legislation and it will be something that will start to achieve the target that we are looking for, and that is zero drownings.

I also draw the parallels between a sale of a property and a change of a tenant in a lease or rental situation. I wonder why there is this disparity between the two. If you change your tenant, your pool must be compliant before a new tenant can move into that rental or lease property. Why would the situation be any different for a new family taking up ownership of a home? I cannot understand how that would be even remotely different--
Mr Hinchliffe: You were citing evidence about high risk. It is the higher risk space. Rental properties are the higher risk.

Mr DOWLING: I take the interjection. High risk is anyone moving into a home with a pool when they have not had one before, be it a rental property or be it an owner-occupied home. It is the same risk. We cannot split hairs on this issue. If these pool safety regulations are to be successful, they need to be consistent in application and consistent in administration.

The minister might also address in his summing-up how and why the council building inspectors are deemed to be authorised pool safety inspectors for the first year but then presumably are required to go through re-accreditation, a new licensing regime and/or pay for a new licence the following year. Historically, the council has always been a strong ally of the government in pool safety regimes, pool inspections and the administration of pool safety. I am just wondering why there would be that movement away from that relationship and why council inspectors would not be considered to be appropriately licensed or accredited inspectors for the purposes of pool legislation. As those council officers are inspectors for the first year of this legislation, why should that system not continue? I would also ask whether or not these council pool inspectors would be required to undergo training each year or each time their licence comes up for renewal. The minister might also be able to touch on that matter in his summing-up.
This morning I took the opportunity to talk to Laurie Lawrence to get a sense--
Mr Gibson: How did you get hold of him?

Mr DOWLING: I take that interjection from the member for Gympie. I just phoned him up. His number is in the White Pages . This morning I talked to Laurie to just get a sense of pool safety from one of Queensland’s most passionate pool safety advocates. He has been one of the leading voices in pool safety for I do not know how long and I will just paraphrase some of his comments. He said that pool safety is not a silver bullet and that this legislation will not achieve it on its own. But Laurie did say that it is obviously a step in the right direction. He highlighted a number of things that he felt really needed to be addressed at a state level. Obviously, one was pool fencing, and that needs to be ongoing. The pool fencing regime and all the pool regulations need to be an ongoing process. It is a moving feast. Laurie also said that pool safety is about doing the five: it is about drown-proofing littlies and children, it is about swimming lessons, watching your mate and resuscitation. He again emphasised all of those--
An honourable member interjected.

Mr DOWLING: He went on a little along that line, but he also stressed that education is one of the things that is missing at a Queensland level--that federally funded campaigns are running but that the state has probably dropped the baton on those education campaigns a little. Laurie’s comment was that if we get all of those things right--and he was by no means critical of the government--we will give ourselves the best chance of having no drownings.

While talking to Laurie I obviously took the opportunity to say, ‘Look, this is our position. We will be moving an amendment on this legislation. What are your thoughts in relation to the settlement issue and when the pool must be made compliant? When should that certificate come into place?’ He agreed that the time really needs to be at the point of sale and that the vendor needs to be the one who makes good and not the incoming person. Laurie quoted a number of statistics--and we have heard them all here tonight--about how critical those first six months are. We have taken the first half of that time to allow new owners to come up to speed. I suspect and I suggest the--

Mr Rickuss:
You’re supporting the amendment?

Mr DOWLING: I am supporting the amendment, but I also suggest that, while we might sit in here and say, ‘In 90 days you have to get the pool right’, I suspect that it will take considerably longer than 90 days. I know that people will have all the excuses under the sun. The pool needs to be compliant prior to settlement.

Laurie did say that anything less than that is really compromising the safety of the young people moving into the house. So I look forward to supporting the amendment moved by the shadow minister and hopefully we will hear some answers from the minister in his summing-up.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP)
(9.46 pm): I rise to speak in support of the Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2010 and in particular the introduction of a single uniform safety standard for all pool fencing in Queensland. The introduction of this standard is the defining feature of this legislation and the central component of the government’s swimming pool safety improvement strategy. It incorporates modern, best-practice principles and endeavours to reduce the number of fatal and non-fatal immersion incidents involving young children in residential swimming pools.

Although this legislation can never replace parental supervision, it acts as an important safety net for that brief window where supervision fails--those few brief minutes that it takes for a child to drown. In those minutes, a compliant pool fence could mean the difference between a close call and a tragedy.

This bill is the result of the most significant review of our pool safety laws since they were introduced in 1991. The 1991 reforms heralded a dramatic and sustained reduction in drownings. Last year, Queensland lost eight children in residential swimming pools--more than any other state in Australia--and this government is determined to do better. It is abundantly clear that legislating comprehensive pool fencing laws is an effective means of reducing drowning deaths and immersion injuries. With the solution so readily apparent, we are simply not prepared to accept the risk that swimming pools and faulty barriers pose to young children.

Principally, this bill creates an obligation on all pool owners to ensure that, by the prescribed date, their pool is compliant with the new uniform standard. However, there are over 300,000 existing pools in this state and while some require only minor improvements, others might require substantial work. Although the most extensive work will be for fences nearing the end of their serviceable lives, we cannot pass this legislation today and expect every pool owner to upgrade tomorrow. The industry could not sustain the demand and pool owners would be robbed of the opportunity to evaluate their situation, make a practical decision and order their affairs to accommodate that decision. Consequently, the government proposes to implement a five-year phase-in period for compliance with the standard. Owners will have five years from the commencement of the legislation to upgrade their pool unless they sell or lease their property first. This phase-in period will keep demand at sustainable levels and facilitate a more gradual and comprehensive method of monitoring and enforcing compliance.

The phased implementation of this legislation is an essential feature of the Pool Safety Improvement Strategy. It will allow pool owners sufficient time to prepare for the new laws while also limiting demands on the pool safety industry to manageable levels. Maximising the number of pools in Queensland that are compliant with the standard increases the chance that there is a safety net in place during those fleeting minutes it takes for a child to drown. Thus the new standard will have a broader application. All regulated pools will be captured regardless of when they are constructed or whether they are new or existing, indoor or outdoor, shared or personal. There are currently 11 different sets of pool fencing standards in force which results in a confusing and onerous compliance paradigm. Homeowners and pool inspectors will no longer need to consider a number of potentially applicable standards.

The new standard will also be extended to include pools associated with a wide range of buildings, including houses, townhouses, unit complexes, hotels, motels, backpacker hostels, caravan parks, transportable home parks and caretaker residences. Portable wading pools that are filled to a depth of 300 millimetres or more will also now be covered. Previously portable wading pools could accommodate water to a depth of 450 millimetres without requiring fencing, but the significant risk of drowning in such pools will now be recognised in law. This change is an adoption of a national standard. While the effectiveness of this standard will be bolstered by its broader application, this government understands that an effective policy must have enough flexibility to be applied in a wide variety of situations and this bill strikes that balance by providing a number of exemptions for situations where it would be highly impractical to expect owners to comply fully with the standard.

Pool owners may apply for an exemption on the grounds that it is physically impractical to comply with the standard, while people with disabilities can obtain an exemption allowing appropriate access to the pool. Applications for exemptions will be made to local governments who are best placed to assess the individual circumstances of each pool and each pool owner. These exemptions are aimed at accommodating people’s varying circumstances without sacrificing the safety of young children. Thus the bill only allows exemptions to the extent that they would ameliorate the difficulty for which the exemption is being sought. In effect, the new standard applies wherever an exemption does not. In this way deviations are minimised and the standard can still be used as the primary means by which owners can ensure the compliance of their pool fence.

Exemptions may also be made conditional upon any requirements or conditions that a local government deems necessary to ensure that young people are adequately inhibited from accessing a pool. In this way Queensland’s pool safety laws are not only the most comprehensive in the nation, but also offer appropriate flexibility to pool owners facing different circumstances. The bill empowers local governments, having granted an exemption, to revoke that exemption in certain circumstances. For example, if the exemption was based on false or misleading information or the applicant has not complied with a condition the local government may issue a show cause notice. If no satisfactory reason is provided then the exemption may be revoked and a penalty will apply if the applicant does not comply. It is important to note that an exemption for disability is specific to a particular person, while an exemption for impracticality is specific to a particular property. This has important implications for pool owners because the legislation provides that an exemption ends when it is no longer applicable. For example, if a person with a disability no longer resides at that property then the pool owner must upgrade the pool, whereas an impracticality exemption survives a change of occupier.

Finally, I conclude by reiterating that the new safety standards are based on best practice. I believe that this bill will help make Queensland pools safer. However, nothing can substitute parental supervision. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mrs Attwood, adjourned.
Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (9.53 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House do now adjourn.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP)
(9.53 pm): Great things are happening at Nerang State Primary School which has adopted a number of programs to change the school community’s approach to healthy eating and the use of fresh produce in the day-to-day lives of its 380 students and their families. About 20 percent of the school population comes from a Pacific Island and Maori background which, of course, have different diets as well. Whilst the school has successfully implemented the Stephanie Alexander School Garden Program this year and now has a flourishing vegetable garden, it is also educating parents and carers of the importance of using healthy food in their cooking.

The school has started a cooking program for parents and carers in an effort to show families that fresh food is important in their family diets rather than packaged and takeaway food. Parents are able to bring along their food to a cooking class and are shown how to make a delicious and nutritious casserole to feed their young. Principal Rod Kirkland told me last year and then two weeks ago that staff were noticing an increase in pre-packed food in students’ lunchboxes but now students were adapting their tastebuds to more fresh fruit and vegetables. The Stephanie Alexander Garden Program has been highly successful and has encouraged a whole group of young gardeners at the school. The students can choose food that is healthy and then engage in fun and hands-on experience in growing, harvesting, preparing and sharing fresh and delicious food. Rod Kirkland told me that most students would not normally eat fresh beetroot but after making chocolate and beetroot cake in the classroom recently they could not get enough of this vegetable. As well, the garden is increasing students’ knowledge of vegetables. Out of 90 students, one knowledgeable student correctly named a Jerusalem artichoke. Students are currently picking lettuce, rocket, beetroot, chard, parsley and radish.

The garden has been a big community effort with 40 volunteers needed each week to run 10 classes. The school is finding it difficult to get this many volunteers with all the pressures of busy lives these days. The school hopes that the garden will lead to students and families creating their own gardens at home and also help students make life-long decisions on better food choices. As well, the garden program is being used in other subjects at school such as science, English and maths. Nerang is the only school on the Gold Coast with the garden program.

As mentioned earlier, the school has a high Pacific Islander population and has two clubs for older Maori boys and another for younger Pacific Islanders and Maoris where they can learn dances and songs about their own cultures. Recently I spent part of my Saturday helping out at the school fete which was well supported by the community and raised $8,000. Coming up shortly is the Nerang’s Got Talent competition which is being jointly run by the school along with Nerang State High School and Worongary State Primary School. Congratulations go to principal Rod Kirkland, Steve Bell, Carol Randall, Anne Panitz and all the hard-working staff and volunteers at Nerang State Primary School for making a difference in the lives of their school community.

Mrs SMITH (Burleigh--ALP)
(9.56 pm): World Suicide Prevention Day is a time to reflect on the fact that each day seven Australians take their own lives, a day to remember that more Australians commit suicide than are killed in car accidents and a day to publicise the fact that suicide is responsible for 25 per cent of all deaths of men aged between 20 and 34. Men over 75 years are also potentially at high risk and Indigenous suicide rates for young males in some remote communities are up to four times higher than comparable non-Indigenous rates. Suicide and self harm both bear huge individual, family, social and economic costs. The latter alone runs to billions of dollars. Conservatively, for every suicide six family members and close friends are left behind. They have to grieve the loss of a loved one and deal with a whirl of emotions and questions such as whether the suicide could have been avoided and whether anyone could have done more.

Research indicates that the most promising way to prevent suicide and suicidal behaviour is early recognition and treatment of depression, substance abuse and other mental health issues. Improving public knowledge about mental health and suicidal behaviour is an important goal. It may contribute to suicide prevention by changing public recognition and attitudes towards mental illness. It includes promoting awareness that many suicides are preventable.

Reducing the stigma associated with mental illness, substance abuse and suicide is one of the keys. While we need health services to address suicide prevention, we also need to be able to discuss the issue openly and honestly. We could go a long way to reducing our suicide rate by accepting people as they are and removing the social taboo on talking about feeling suicidal. A person simply talking about how they feel greatly reduces their distress. They also begin to see other options and are less likely to attempt suicide.

Given the stigma that exists around suicide, it is understandable that more is not being said or written in the media about the issue. Taboo is a powerful force in society and it requires courage to break the silence. There have always been suicides and there always will be. However, if we focus on the issue with the same vigour as we do for problems such as the road toll and cancer, we can make a difference. Governments can fund programs but only societies can wipe away a stigma and talk about how we can best help people who have plumbed the depths.

As a patron of Care For Life--Suicide Prevention on the Gold Coast, I want to particularly acknowledge Raylee Taylor. She has been a dedicated volunteer for suicide prevention for 16 years and was recently presented with a Premier’s Award for Queensland Seniors. Raylee has overcome the tragedy of losing her own son to suicide to work hard at suicide prevention and assist families to work through their grief of losing loved ones. I admire her strength and her ‘never give up’ approach. I truly believe there are people still with us today due to her unflagging efforts to promote awareness of this issue. We must never give up. Too many people are depending on us.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Road Safety, Warrego Highway; Recycled Water
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr RICKUSS (Lockyer--LNP) (10.00 pm): I rise to say a few words about another accident on the Warrego Highway. This highway continues to have a high accident rate and, unfortunately, much of this is due to pure driver error. The truck that rolled over yesterday was an empty semitrailer. It happened on a section of road that is well marked. The driver just apparently mistook the turn, went to sleep--I do not know. It was pure driver error and he ended up crossing both lanes of the highway. Fortunately, he was only taken to the local hospital so his injuries were not severe. I urge the motorists who are travelling on our highways to take care. As much as millions of dollars will be spent this year on improving the safety of the highway, the motorists do have to take some care themselves.

The other issue I would like to raise as it relates to my local area is recycled water. The recycled water project has been ongoing for something like 15 years now. It really is a travesty that this water is going to waste. It is a bit like the Traveston Dam, unfortunately. This project is complete. It is sitting there at the Wivenhoe Dam with good access to the Lockyer Valley, but the water is not being utilised except for the small amount that is going to two power stations. This is a total waste. It is going to be a cost burden that will be imposed upon the local water bodies. Unfortunately, the whole of the state is paying for it. Surely, it is time that this water was used in industry and agriculture. The only big user of the recycled water project will be the agricultural industry in the Fassifern, Lockyer and Brisbane valleys.

It is about time this government bit the bullet and actually put this water to good use. It is just atrocious that this pipeline that goes all the way to Wivenhoe Dam--only 20 kilometres from some of the best agricultural land in Queensland--is not being used. I cannot understand how this government can hold its head up and talk about its efficiencies and what it has done for society when this water is just sitting there. The amount of $2 billion has been spent on this water project and none of it is being used. It is a shame.
