It would actually supplement the fruit and vegetable industries in South-East Queensland, which would make some of these farms much more sustainable. It has to be provided to the farmers at a realistic price. Every pedestal user in South-East Queensland has to realise that they have to subsidise this water because the price that the government is trying to charge the farmers makes it totally unviable. We are helping to clean up the bay. The government cannot leave a $2 billion project sitting idle doing absolutely nothing. I cannot believe this government has put up with this sort of project.

Mrs MILLER (Bundamba--ALP) (10.03 pm): Last Friday marked the official opening of the Goodna State School community hall. At a cost of nearly $3 million, it is a top class facility in Goodna. It is not just a hall, but a full-sized basketball court, a canteen, a conference room and a big stage with a top-class lighting and sound system and change rooms out the back.

Are we proud of our NAPLAN results? We sure are in Goodna. Our students at Goodna State School are on a pathway to academic excellence. That is our aim and we are achieving it. At Goodna we have had big improvements across-the-board but especially in years 5 and 7. Academic excellence is our mantra and with our step into prep, language immersion, playgroup and the oral language project, we are making great inroads into educating our local children. We are not just teaching children. With Bremer TAFE, we are teaching English to their parents three days every week. The Survivor English Program is going great guns.

So Goodna is a school for adults learning literacy, for children and for also the wider community. If you can sing you can join the Goodna community choir based at the school. The choir sings at the school and at civic events and has instilled a great pride into everyone in the Goodna community. Our Pathways to Peace Program, which has been running for several years, continues to be successful year in and year out. You can get a lot of hugs, words of encouragement and a helping hand at Goodna, all with the aim of accessing academic excellence. Everyone is valued at Goodna State School.

To top it all off, last week Goodna State School was one of the Queensland state schools selected for free eye screening through the One Sight Program. Good eyesight is critical to learning and our community thanks One Sight, the not-for-profit arm of the eye care company that owns OPSM for their professional care of our students throughout the screening process.

I would like to say good on you, Goodna State School. With 615 children enrolled and growing every week and with 20 adults enrolled at the school learning literacy three days a week, we are achieving academic miracles with the support of an excellent principal, Margaret Gurney, our deputy principal, our teachers and ancillary staff, our parents and community members. At Goodna, we are showing the rest of Queensland and Australia how a caring, peaceful community can achieve academic excellence.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (10.06 pm): Recently I had the chance to attend the Nambour and District Care Association annual general meeting. This association has been servicing the Nambour and surrounding community for the past 26 years. It currently operates from its own premises in Doolan Street, Nambour. It now receives Home and Community Care funding to support its service. The service was developed to assist people to meet their range of needs to maintain a reasonable quality of life so that people are able to remain living independently in our community, thus preventing the need for them to move into a nursing home or a hospital facility.

We have a carer support group, which meets regularly, with 27 carers attending during the year. Since last year’s annual general meeting, the workers have provided 45,853 hours of care to 1,623 people on 33,950 occasions. Our day respite centre has had a total of 138 people attending during the past year. Some of these people attend daily and most attend more than one day each week. Of the people who attend the centre, 41 per cent are aged over 85 years and 19 people are aged over 90 years of age and one of our elderly clients is almost 99 years of age.

Our centre is open for respite services Monday to Friday from 9.30 in the morning to 2 pm and on Thursdays afternoon sessions commence after 2.30 pm. Transport to medical appointments for clients is one of the most frequently requested services. I understand that 611 people were assisted this year on 6,047 occasions. Also, a total of 367 people have been assisted with shopping during the year.

The centre is not solely reliant on Home and Community Care funding and this year the centre raised $9,960 from raffles, $4,391 from unsolicited donations and sales from the gift shop raised just over $700. It received $77,335, which was generated from a collection of fees for services provided and an additional $21,222 has been paid by people who attend our respite centre.

The home modification service is another service provided by the centre and the centre is used almost every afternoon. There is a great management team which supports our manager. We have great community involvement. I would like to use this opportunity to put on the public record my appreciation of the great services provided by the Nambour and District Care Association. It is truly a commendable service. I would like to take this chance to table for the benefit of all members and especially the minister for communities a copy of its most recent annual report.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Nambour and District Care Inc--Annual Report 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mrs SCOTT (Woodridge--ALP) (10.08 pm): I would like to thank the Premier and her cabinet for a very successful community cabinet meeting held in Logan City on 6 September and for the diverse range of activities held throughout the city, where each of our six state members was able to host an event specific to their electorate. The Hon. Peter Lawlor and I started the day at our Logan City Special School, meeting with Acting Principal Anne Nystrom, P&C Chairman Wayne Ernst, teachers and a number of students. Always eager to meet visitors, the students had beaming smiles. We know that they are going to enjoy their new bus, which will be purchased following a grant from the Gambling Community Benefit Fund.

While cabinet met at the Logan Entertainment Centre, I joined my colleagues Barbara Stone, Evan Moorhead and a number of Logan City councillors to tour Yarrabilba, one of the chosen sites in South-East Queensland for major development. The CEO of the Urban Land Development Authority, Paul Eagles, was on hand to explain the development, which will give a major boost to jobs in the area and increase the options for housing. I then joined the Premier and the Minister for Transport, Rachel Nolan, for the major announcement of a new bus station for Logan Central which I shall speak about in greater detail at another time. It was then time for all to gather at the magnificent Logan Metro Indoor Sports Centre where in excess of 300 of our Logan community members joined us, with many gaining access to the ministerial area of their choice.

Working dogs are taking on more and more duties. After lunch I joined our primary industries minister, Tim Mulherin, to view the superb abilities of two fire ant detection dogs. Their supersensitive noses can sniff out two small plugs smelling of fire ants buried in a vast paddock. They are a great addition to the team helping to defend our outdoor lifestyle from the blight of fire ants.

The Attorney-General, Cameron Dick, next visited the Logan legal advice service at the Youth and Family Service. This was a great opportunity for staff to acquaint the Attorney-General with the very valuable service they perform, along with our solicitors who give freely of their time, and to approach him about an extension of their services. Finally, I joined the Attorney-General back at my office, where he recognised the huge contribution of two of our long-serving JPs, Brian Cochrane for 25 years and Kelvin Abraham for 40 years. In fact, Kelvin has almost reached his 50 years and I hope to see him recognised, once again, in 2011. Brian and Kelvin were joined by their wives. They have expressed their deep appreciation that the Attorney-General took the time to spend an hour or so chatting over a cup of tea in a very relaxed fashion. They will treasure the memories of that meeting.
I commend the Premier and all of her ministers for making themselves available to our community in such an informal way. It was much appreciated.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP) (10.11 pm): I rise to speak on a very important issue to the Kawana electorate--that is, the Palmview development. In the past the minister and I have had discussions about this development. I am glad that he is in the chamber tonight, because this is the three minutes of his life that the minister needs to hear on behalf of my electorate.
Mr Hinchliffe: It’s three minutes I’ll never get back.

Mr BLEIJIE: The minister will get it back. For 1 years the community has been liaising with the Sunshine Coast Regional Council in relation to the Palmview greenfield structural plan that the council had to get developer ready. At a meeting in March 2009, the community put forward numerous suggestions to council. It then released its position paper. Unfortunately, a lot of the major issues that the community wanted addressed were not addressed in the position paper. Council then released another position paper, being the structural plan, and asked for community feedback before it went to the honourable minister.

The community held another successful meeting with the Sippy Downs and District Community Association where the major issues were highlighted. The council sent that to the state. Once the state had responded, we were advised that the council still did not take on board the major issues in the community. This year the issues were again addressed at a local community meeting with the Sippy Downs and District Community Association.

The major issues include some form of highway access or service road, the green link that is going to rip through the heart of the Sippy Downs community--obviously, the Sippy Downs community do not want it; they want it rerouted--the sequencing of the development and the upgrading of Claymore Road. I thank the Minister for Main Roads and the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning for sitting down with the community and discussing these issues with them, and giving the commitment that once the final structural plan is received by the state they will certainly look at it and take on board the issues of the community.

Unfortunately, council does not hold the same view. Last week council voted on it. We do not know what the council’s current position is. They said they are very happy with it. From the rumour mill I am hearing that the community will not be entirely happy with the result. Tonight I call on the minister to give the Sippy Downs and District Community Association another opportunity to respond. I believe the minister will receive the documents from council on Friday. A 10-day period will follow.

I never thought I would say this in the chamber, but the minister may be our last hope with respect to getting a community development that is acceptable to the current Sippy Downs community and that addresses the major issues such as the highway access and the green link. If we shove 14,000 people into a development that will negatively impact on Sippy Downs, that will not benefit the Sunshine Coast.

Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (10.14 pm): Last week was Child Protection Week and a time to put the spotlight on the abuse and neglect of children. A child who is nurtured and grows up happy and well adjusted faces the world with confidence. When they start their own family, they bring all those experiences to that challenge. A child who is brought up with abuse and neglect faces the world with fear and mistrust, and often uses alcohol or drugs for confidence or suffers low school achievement or depression. When they come to start life relationships and a family, do they have the tools to do better for their children?

That is why the Bligh government has made it our priority to enshrine protection for our precious children in legislation and to increase funding to community organisations to prevent neglect and abuse in vulnerable families, and to enable children and families who have suffered abuse to work through the trauma and co-dependency issues and move on with their lives. Those are services that have been changing people’s lives.

In Redcliffe, Chameleon Youth Housing, Redcliffe Youth Space, Redcliffe Community Association, church organisations and foster and kinship carers are our front line. The success of the Bligh government’s work to eradicate child abuse is marked by the way the Redcliffe community has begun to act to support vulnerable children. Saint Vinnie’s Give a Child a Chance Foundation hosted 150 people at a fundraising dinner to support children to get a fair go in education. This money means children who would otherwise not have breakfast, lunch, uniforms or school books or be able to attend school excursions will be supported in those areas so they do have a fair chance at a good education.

The Redcliffe Hospital Foundation held its Child Abuse Awareness Family Fun Day on Sunday with free rides and activities for children. Redcliffe residents came out to play, but they also took away the message. Several families shared how they had turned their lives around because of support from Bligh government funded services. Those are the outcomes of this Labor government partnering with community groups to prevent abuse and to heal the damage done through abuse. This is an important focus of the Toward Q2 plan to build a strong community. Strong communities are built on happy, well-adjusted children in functioning families. Only the Bligh government has increased funding and quality assurance in child protection to ensure good results.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (10.16 pm): This evening I rise to speak on behalf of the residents and frequent users of Worongary Road. We are absolutely appalled that the Minister for Main Roads, Craig Wallace, insisted that the $1.1 million he announced on 7 September was new money and that his department had already spent $1 million on upgrading Worongary Road. Neither the residents nor I can see any sign of where his government has spent that $1 million. If $1 million has been spent already to fix the 0.3-kilometre stretch of road between Uplands Court and Brixton Court then the minister must take the locals for fools. There has been no work done on this section of road since it was first announced in the road implementation plan. This is an absolute outrage and a slap in the face to residents who drive this treacherous road daily. Either the minister misled parliament in his answer to my question on notice or he misled the media and residents of the Gold Coast last week. A sum of $1 million had already been allocated from the Safer Roads Sooner program to address the 0.3-kilometre stretch of road and was reannounced in the 2008, 2009 and 2010 budgets.

I have been calling for Worongary Road to be ‘demained’ since March 2009. Residents have had enough of the buck-passing and it is time the minister got serious about the safety of motorists along this stretch of road. This road has seen an increase in traffic of over 1,400 cars per day and is a fatality waiting to happen.

The minister needs to get out of his ivory tower, take a visit to Worongary so he even knows which road he is talking about, meet with the Gold Coast City Council and hand over the road like he said he would 18 months ago. He was in the area only last week but failed to come and see the condition of the road for himself. Instead, he made comments on the road from kilometres away. The minister said on Channel 9 Gold Coast news--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is extra money on top of that so we have already spent that million dollars we announced in 2008. We spent that all on safety works on the road and the road maintenance.
XML.Hansard-Body: If the minister stands by his comments then, by my tally, residents are owed $2.1 million of upgrade for the road instead of filling potholes, which is all that has been done so far. Show me the money, Minister! Worongary residents are sick and tired of this arrogant, out-of-touch, on-the-nose state Labor government. With the Premier promoting ‘Walk a day in my shoes’, I propose that the minister drives a day in the cars of motorists who have to put up with the patchwork quilt that is Worongary Road and which will remain this way until the minister comes good with his promise to demain this dangerous road.

Ms O’NEILL (Kallangur--ALP) (10.20 pm): Disability Action Week from 5-11 September celebrates the experiences of people with a disability and aims to raise community awareness of the benefits of building communities where people with a disability can be genuinely and meaningfully included. This year’s Disability Action Week Awards have again recognised those individuals and organisations whose work is directly related to disability, as well as individuals and community organisations that have chosen to include a disability focus within their wider role.

On Tuesday, 7 September I was invited to attend this year’s Disability Action Week’s fabulous function at the convention centre, because an inspirational young man, 19 years old, from Petrie in the beautiful electorate of Kallangur had been named Outstanding Young Achiever in the Queensland-wide awards.

Tristram Peters, described as a wheelchair sports ace, who captains and coaches Queensland’s wheelchair sports teams, is seen as a role model for young people with physical disabilities with whom he engages in his work for support organisation MontroseAccess. He has helped improve the quality of life for many clients by leading and engaging others in physical activity programs. His can-do attitude and independent lifestyle foster confidence, help build self-esteem and motivate his peers with a disability.

Apart from his wheelchair sport prowess, Tristram promotes MontroseAccess’s Walk with Me event, mentors people in wheelchair skills and physical activities, and is a hydrotherapy facilitator. He works tirelessly to encourage others to engage in activities and healthy behaviour and participate in community activities, especially through local PCYCs.

Tristram was presented with his award by disability services minister Annastacia Palaszczuk, who kindly arranged for me to be present on stage to congratulate him. His proud parents were there to see him collect his award. Tristram told me he was a bit embarrassed by all the fuss. Like most local heroes, he did not seem to think he was anything too special. The decor for the event was reminiscent of a high-end night club, complete with butterfly lights and fantastic table decorations. The stories of all the recipients were inspirational, and the commitment of the organisations represented was outstanding.

I was pleased to attend and felt very fortunate indeed to have the opportunity to be there. One of the highlights was that I had the pleasure to see my first ever signing choir. Rockhampton’s Crescent Lagoon State School signing choir performed three songs --We are Australian , Speaking Hands Listening Eyes and Eagle Rock . The skill of the choir and the joy on the faces was awe-inspiring, and they received resounding applause. Some of us in the audience may have joined in during Eagle Rock . We were also very lucky to see the Western Suburbs Special School choir perform several songs, and I would say that after Lean on Me there was not a dry eye in the house.
Congratulations to Tristram, his family and all who worked so hard to arrange and present outstanding performances and an exceptional event.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 10.23 pm.
